[b]TL; DR[/B] Helldivers is frantic chaotic and great; it is a game that shines in multiplayer, but which is also a lot of fun solo. Naturally, I hope that the servers will remain online for years to come.

[b]Note:[/b] I have played with a lot of strangers and have never had any issues with finding a team, but I have also not found a single person purposefully ruining for others. Hopefully you would have the same experience. 

[h1] Story [/h1]
Super Earth, our home, is governed by managed democracy, a system so streamlined and perfect that you don't need to vote a computer does it for you. 
But our way of life is under attack the aliens want nothing but our total eradication, Super Earth will not buckle, we will not give in, we will spread managed democracy until peace and prosperity reigns again! 

Would you believe that this game is a satirical? [i]Starship Troopers[/i] is one clear influence as evidence by several achievements being quotes from the movie. If you delve deeper and read the in-game news that preface and outro a frontline you will find other interesting things such as implying the entire war was based on a lie, and that they did not have the destructive weaponry Super Earth claimed, or that anyone who doubts Super Earth’s official stories on their Casus Belli are labelled “sympathisers”. I would say the game has a sort of sardonic wit and style, so I found myself enjoying reading the various entries backstories and the tactical information on your enemies. 
With that said the writing is completely optional, there is no storyline or anything like that only the Galactic Campaign where you defend Super Earth's right to suppress protestors with SMGs.

[h1] Presentation [/h1] 
[i]Helldivers[/i] has a remarkably diverse set of enemies, the three factions all have their own unique style from a cybernetic body horror to crustacean insects, and within each faction you can easily tell everything apart. It is very easy to know what you are fighting, so it is easy to know what tactics will be effective. You might have been able to confuse certain enemies, however, these are typically exclusive to different difficulties, and so they pose no issue when actually playing the game.  
There are also themes for each faction, and yeah, they are also great, adding further personality to each faction and solidifying them as different experiences. There are variations with different intensities for each faction to accompany the added difficulties of higher drops which works really well, remarkably I have never gotten bored with the soundtrack, but my personal favourites are the high difficulty Illuminate or perhaps the boss themes.    
There is also some variety with planets snow, volcanic, swamp, deserts of cities, but in all honestly all planets of a type look the same, which is not lovely, but it is not something I hold against the game either, luckily there are certain changes depending on the faction that controls it. 

Since [i]Helldivers[/i] can get very hectic it is a good thing that the developers tried to remedy that with aural and visual cues. Helldivers will call out when they are reloading, when they drop down, and the countdowns for stratagems are very explicit so you rarely get a tank dropped on your face if you are paying attention, but in war all kinds of things happen. 
The voiced callouts are the best and most fun, I really like how they shout out their hatred of the enemies of democracy as they are firing, and being able to quickly and easily communicate within the game and its four basic audio emotes is cool, but sometimes people do not ”stop” when you ask, them and so they get a face full of lava. 

You are also given customisation options to differentiate your own helldiver from the masses. I always love this in games so of course I love it here, but it's not all sunshine and roses, it takes a while to unlock all options and a lot of the cooler armour pieces are DLC. 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
The key to defeating the alien scum that threatens Super Earth is acquiring contribution to the Galactic Campaign. As players collect more and more we push our enemies further away from our home world and closer to theirs, eventually we can launch an invasion and hopefully deal with them for good, but if we do not collect enough contribution they will push us back, and if Super Earth falls then all will be lost 
So completing planets, especially on higher difficulties, is important to winning but so is defending regional capitals so as to stop their advance. It helps that the city centres are the most fun missions in the game, at least in my opinion. 

Regardless once you have a planet you can choose to do drops, each one has a selection to choose from but on your standard planet you will need to compete them all to gain contribution. Once done you can choose your loadout from a large selection of weapons with different benefits and drawbacks as well as powerful perks and game-changing stratagems. You get missile strikes, heavy weaponry, vehicles, and various defensive measures. If you are in a team you may want to coordinate your equipment, but unless you are playing at the highest difficulties or if you are bad, it will not make a major difference as long as you use something that is somewhat useful. 
Once planetside you will need to make a lot of decisions, which objective to tackle first, what route do we take, do we circle around the patrol, do we kill them? And many more. 
It is often the case that you will try and kill patrols before they sound an alarm otherwise you will quickly be swarmed with enemies, both options are fun but ideally you will actually complete the planet and to do that it is best to have good synergy and a common goal with your team. Certain players are definitely sample-addicted and will beeline towards any research they see, and since you share a screen that can be annoying, but it only rarely jeopardises the mission. 

There is also a lot of variety in the actual drops, you always get a selection of different missions and they require you to do various things, from assassinating a target, disarming mines, escorting someone, defending missile launchers etc. 
Failing a mission does not mean that everything is lost, as long as you evacuate you will receive all research you collected (used for upgrades), however a low number of deaths, no failed objectives and full evacuation is required for full contribution. Since each criteria corresponds to a third of the contribution it might be useful to destroy the objectives yourselves if you have already failed one, so as to make the run faster and not waste valuable resources, or lives.
Added to this is the differences between factions against the Cyborgs it is hard to fully stealth so it turns into a tactical strike in a warzone, against the Illuminate it feels more like a special operation in hostile territory while the last one is a bug hunt. I enjoy all of them and I enjoy fighting all the factions, I love the variety and it has kept me interested in the game. 

Worth noting the differences between KBM and a controller, I have used both, but all my PC playtime is with a keyboard. A lot of people agree that aiming is more precise with a mouse, but it is called "twin-stick-shooter" so it is not like a controller is useless. 
The more important difference is grenades and stratagems, with a mouse they land exactly at your cursor, provided your throwing arm is strong enough, but a controller is more flexible, you can throw grenades or stratagems off-screen, which can be the difference between calling in an artillery strike next to you or on a group of enemies. Ultimately it is down to preference, but they are also best suited for different things.

This game forces you to buy DLC with All-Terrain Boots. Otherwise, say goodbye to winter missions on higher difficulties. Annoying.

Don't get me wrong. The game is cool overall, it is this DLC policy that is really outrageous. Yes, you can say that this DLC is cheap but why should I buy something that must be in the base game to start with or absent from it altogether?

I am ok with this difficulty mod on winter planets, which require you to play more carefully and avoid patrols to not get killed easily. I am not ok with people spamming these All-Terrain Boots and forcing others to move faster and kite hordes of enemies when it is simply not possible in snow (even with Jet Packs, yes. Because you tend to lose them upon death).

To not have this DLC means that if u join someone to assist with their winter mission, you just end up like a burden and receive a negative feedback from full stacks or even 1-2 people with DLC content. It would be better if we won't even have these boots as an option, DLC or not. This sucks for co-op game. It shouldn't be this way.

Little bit of a learning curve coming in. You don't realize how much you don't know until you find out lol. Once you're in the thick of it though and especially playing multiplayer it's a freaking blast. I could burn through hours playing this game and not even realize how long it's been. My overall synopsis honestly I can summarize but just saying "good sh*t".

Wage war and defend humanity! Three alien species with different looks and feels are attacking the human homeworld, and it's up to the players to push back and neutralize enemies! 

Campaigns are shared across the playerbase, and if one species is wiped out then they're down for the entire community until the war resets (upon clearing the other two invaders). As you press forward towards the enemy homeworlds, the worlds get tougher and encourage stealth play and bursting out the scouts before they can raise the alarm for all but the most hardened of soldiers. The missions are simple but the enemy is plentiful. Some weapons, especially from the expansion content, is especially helpful. LAS weapons are always a welcome sight as they don't expend ammo unless they overheat, making them very sustainable for casual and somewhat difficult missions and players.

Thought I'd drop a review of this beauty of a game.

Definitely wholeheartedly recommend it, especially if you have friends to play with, if not chuck out an SOS beacon and you'll get backup from other helldivers. Many hours of fun to be had.

Just don't buy the sequel, it'll infect your PC with the shittiest DRM known to man and potentially even brick your system, all for the sake of a cash shop. It's a shame Arrowhead couldn't even fork over the money for a reputable DRM despite adding in a pay-for-convenience cash shop for Helldivers 2.

So anyway, Helldivers is a great game, skip the sequel.

Sign up with the Helldivers and see all that the galaxy has to offer. Stride across alien worlds with your team at your side, the sun hanging low in the horizon as you stitch enemy patrols with fields of interlocking fire. Guide precision strikes against armored targets, and handle heavy ordinance with deadly and graceful confidence.
Hit the deck to take cover from gunfire, or to dodge supersonic resupply Hellpods fired from orbiting starships, drawn to your teammate’s poorly thrown beacon as they are pressured on all sides from the alien menace. Avoid the gatling guns of cybernetically enhanced monsters, but also your own defensive turrets that lack any pesky safety mechanisms and have a habit of belching deadly streams of lead in great scything arcs.
Do it all to defend the freedom of Super-Earth and all her inhabitants, and to preserve the purest form of governance devised by mankind: Managed Democracy.

Long before Deep Rock Galactic, and long after Left 4 Dead's hayday, one of my most fun and casual drop-in co op games was Helldivers.  You could jump in, do badly, and no one really chewed you out.  Losing was just part of the fun, and if things got too bad people would just leave the mission rather than rip you a new one.

Even in now here in 2024, nearly a decade later and a few days before Helldivers comes out, the extremely chill atmosphere is still there.  People are still dying to stupid things and not worried about it.  All of the last-minute reinforcing, nail-biting seat-of-pants wins right at the end still happen.  All of the hilariously absurd slaugthers of a squad 30 seconds in to a mission still happen.  All of the "hey sorry.  hey, no sweat" exchanges happen.  It's still good clean fun where the worst you'll probably encounter is someone with their mic open and their TV playing too loud in the background or people mumbling in languages you don't understand.

A top down game where I have to share a screen with the whole squad is not a problem ,but playing tactical and focusing team play to complete objectives really sets me up for the vibe!

Context - I played 106 hours (only counting mission time) of the PS4 version of this between February and November/December 2016.
I bought it again here to play on Steamdeck, which it runs perfectly on and is 100% functional. I have never tried playing it with a mouse & keyboard so I don't know how functional, if at all, that is.

It is a fantastic game and is absolutely worth the full price with all the DLCs(which give you access to new weapons, stratagems, perks and cosmetics), even better if it is on sale.
However it can be very difficult if you aren't ready or haven't had enough practice and can require a good team effort or a lot of dedication.


It's a hardcore, mission-based, 1 to 4 player, top down, twin stick shooter. You select a mission from the ship, choose your loadout then drop into the level and must complete the listed objective and then extract. 
All players stay on the same screen at all times and have to work together.
Each mission will typically last from 5 to 25 minutes depending on the difficulty of the mission and skill of the team. 


As you and other players around the world complete missions against a faction it gets closer to completely defeating that faction, at the end everyone can do special missions against that faction's home planet and once those are completed the faction will be removed from the map until the next War (kind of like a season). Once all three factions are completely defeated the War will end and a new one will start, completely resetting the missions and faction progress.

Everyone in a team can see the entire loadout of their teammates on the confirmation screen so it's easy to cooperate even without voice or text chat. 
In the actual missions you can also see each players' primary and support weapon, how much ammo they have of their currently equipped weapon, how many grenades they have and the cooldown timer of their stratagems.

You have limited ammo for your weapons which can only be restocked by calling for an ammo resupply with a stratagem or finding crates on some missions. 
When you reload your gun, all remaining ammo in it is discarded - This isn't an FPS where you reload after every single shot

If you die, your teammates must call for a reinforcement with a stratagem, then you will be dropped back into the mission in a new pod. Your ammo will be reset to half capacity and any items you had on you (support weapon, backpack etc) will be on the ground where you died.
If all players die but someone was able to call for a reinforce in time, they will drop the beacon and all players will come back at the same time.
In single player you will be automatically revived once, and get an additional auto revive each mission objective completed.



The only potential issue I have, which is very minor, is that the PC version seems to have a couple bugs that I never encountered on the PS version, such as sometimes being killed immediately after starting a mission because your teammate's drop pod lands too close to or directly on top of yours, or rarely scout enemies not sounding the alarm after detecting you.

As twin stick shooters go, this one plays pretty decent. The basic setup of being a soldier in a galactic "democracy" is fun and gives plenty of openings for starship-troopers-esque jokes and one liners. Most of my criticisms come from the aged feel of the graphics and moment to moment gameplay. Theres a layer of slight annoyance with the military airdrop style powerup/bonuses that you call in to deal with different challenges. While theres a lot of cool tools and weapons to call in, you have to open a menu and input a frustrating DDR type directional code to get anything. That issue extends to interacting with literally everything while youre boots on the ground. You cant call in support, start an objective, open a machine, disarm a mine, or do ANYTHING without that stupid code input mechanic. I understand that every game needs a series of distinct and focused mechanics to be the body of a games gameplay loop, but WHY does the single most common thing you do have to be that inconvenient every time is pops up and slows the game to a halt. 

Aside from the singular annoyance I have with the code inputting, I enjoyed the rest of the game enough to recommend it to anyone who likes good old fashioned twin stick shooter goodness.

Enemies are "searching" for you, but somehow have an auto-lock on your position despite you doing nothing to alert them. I walk on one side of an area, they head that way, i turned around to walk up behind them, they turned around immediately. "Dogs" in the game will charge and pounce on you, knocking you down and leaving you defenseless as you're shot at, get grenades thrown at you, and they charge at you again right before you get up.
It has unique aspects that alone would have been fun, such as everything killing you including your own weaponry and evacuation ship. I can see how this could potentially be fun should it be played by someone who knows what they're doing, but as someone who is thrown into serious missions solo after a brief tutorial that explains the basics, it is not fun at all. 
No AI helpers, no real consideration for someone who cannot get a single person to join their lobby throughout multiple attempts.

All in all, worst experience i've ever played. Dark Souls, Hotline Miami, and every Vampire Survivors clone i have ever played is more fun and welcoming than this. There is fun-hard and then there is frustratingly difficult. This is the latter.

One of the best games I've ever played and a complete steal for 7,50 Euro which I bought in current sale with all DLCs. It's similar to L4D2 in a way you can just boot it up with friends and have a blast together or listening to music and relaxing while playing with randoms or solo.

You might be worried you won't find a group to play with, but I assure you as of now the community is very much alive. I have zero issues finding players in matches especially for harder difficulty missions where they're most needed and so far haven't faced any serious toxicity from anyone, the worst offense is someone rushing ahead pulling the shared screen toward them and away from the rest of the squad, but if you are the host you can kick them or anyone who refuses to comply with your rules. That said this is a co-op PvE so be also considerate - don't hijack your whole squad to journey across the map for 1 sample. Everyone wants to have fun and compromises have to be made.

The game has 15 levels of difficulty, each getting progressively harder. The gameplay starts with you choosing location where to deploy on the map and then you can start calling in your gear while hopefully undetected. Enemy patrols the map in small sized groups which upon spotting the helldivers at certain distance call in reinforcement which are basically entire armies in comparison to the patrol sizes, so you can and ideally should stealth through missions as much as possible, but that's much easier said than done and the combat is so much fun it doesn't even feel like a punishment. Decent variety of weapons and large variety of skills to bring into each match.

I haven't mastered anything in the game yet, but I certainly want to play more and I can only recommend buying it, especially when it's on sale with all the DLCs.

The game itself is pretty fun, lots of weapons and equipment and such, 3 different factions to fight and a whole satirical tone. 

But the game has a major, stupid game design choice: it uses a "war" system were the community needs to conquer the different regions of the game. And any region already conquered cannot be played by anyone anymore until the next rotation. 

This means that if you play too close from the end of a rotation, the most fun regions will have been completely conquered, and you won't be able to play them. Why should I have to even pay attention to when I play a game to make sure I have fun? Why would you lock two thirds regularly?

I love this game. Unfortunately, I didn't get into it until years after it declined in popularity, but there's still a good player base, evident by the fact that galactic wars continue progressing every time I play. 

First off, it's Starship Troopers and that's one of my favorite movies. You fight the bugs, you have the propaganda, you yell hilarious lines like (have a cup of Liber-Tea). Second, there's a ton of weapon options, strategems for support, enemy variety. Extracting at the end of a mission when you're under enemy fire and you've rezzed your friends multiple times is so exciting and fulfilling. Third, I like the upgrade system, but I do have to say you level up way too slowly in this game. I've been level 18 for over a year.

The downsides to this game, are that you really need friends with mics to play this game. There are no bots to help you, and playing by yourself is doable up to about difficulty 6 planets. Even with 2 or 3 players I haven't been able to play past difficulty 8. You can say we just suck, but we've all put quite a few hours into it.

Overall, I have always had a ton of fun with this game. I wish I could muster a team long enough to beat some of the more difficult missions but medium-difficulty missions have their own charm as well.

Get it, play it. Get ready for Helldivers 2 next year.

Even though the structure of the game is... Fundementally flawed, Its alot of fun, and its community is very friendly. What you see is what you get- but if you DO get this, you should keep a few things in mind.

Cons
1. More than just a few guns and stratagems are either quite useless, too situational, or inferior. You can use some of 'em, sure, but your probably not gonna find any unexpected synergies outside the meta. 
Also its basically mandatory to bring an ammo drop stratagem if you're packing solid-munitions, so for most general purpose loadouts, you're probably gonna be using an energy weapon.

2. Finding weapons/stratagems that can take down Bigger foes is annoying as hell-  Alot of them aren't powerful enough to do the job, or very unergonomic and put yourself at risk- Anything that you can actually count on will have very little ammo or a very high cooldown.

3. Snow planets are ass. like, serious ass. The snow slows you down, which makes traveling around the map obnoxiously slow and survival ALOT harder if you don't bring your Snow shoes. Fuck snow.

4. The game Isn't made to accommodate Solo play and it shows. Lower difficulties will be boring as ever, but medium-difficulty missions will be very time consuming. Don't even think about going above 10 unless you're a badass whose ready to put themselves through the wringer.

5. Depending on how the War is going, You can't always chose to fight against your preferred enemies, and thats kind of a drag because I've literally met noone who actually *likes* to fight the Illuminates, but eventually you'll probably have to do it.

6. ALOT of useful gear is locked behind DLC. It alone is a sin that the Snow Shoes are locked behind a DLC because of just how shitty ice planets are.

Edit: Changing review to negative after playing some more. Looking back at my review below, I have no idea why I made it positive to begin with.

[h1][b]Helldivers[/b][/h1]
[b]A satrical vision of earth were it taken over by America at some point during or before space exploration.[/b] Helldivers puts you in control of an unlimited amount of SUPER EARTH soldiers and all the lack of saftey and proper training that comes with. Mostly an enjoyable experience kneecapped by it's own encouragement of multiplayer aspects. This is not a good singleplayer game at all and you should avoid it if you do not intend to play with three other friends looking for a game that doesn't respect it's own hazardous and humorous volatile munitions.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1470888011

[h1][b] Gameplay [/b][/h1]
[b]The second biggest selling point.[/b] Right up there next to it's over the top humor and stylistic art that I assume is intended to parody starship troopers and ape halo's ODST delivery system(or some other game I dunno who did it first). The gameplay at it's core is solid, but favors controllers a little too hard. Twin stick shooters are often made for controllers, but actually work best with a mouse and keyboard when the developer has a strong enough grasp of coding to make it work.

Among the framework for the game you'll find joyous punchy gunplay and giggle worthy lines of dialogue spewed from your character. Aiming and firing in this game is about as good as it can get and I only think Alien swarm does a better job. But that's a game that DOES respect mouse and keyboard play so it's not really a fair comparison. You also have diving, running, grenade throwing and strategems.

Strategems are a hugely important aspect of the game that seperate it from most top down shooters. Enabling you to summon reloads, airstrikes, reinforcements, turrets, vehicles and all sorts of other shit. And with how over the top this game is you can expect many mistakes and boons from the giant pods that deliver these. Allies killed by a tank you dropped. An enemy killed by an ammo reload you dropped. Calling in a railgun to kill a huge enemy and killing them with the delivery crate. Killing an ally when summoning another ally back. It all happens at some point to varying degrees of hilarity and frustration.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1470890925

And with this the first element of why this is a 'multiplayer only' game to me comes to surface. While you will go down when you're low on health and can get back up on your own, there are few situations at middle to late game where you will ever get back up if you go down. 

Not only is the game MASSIVELY HARDER playing solo, once you're outta lives you lose. This is even more frustrating when you have completed all the objectives and get killed waiting for evac. Respawn and send a guy down (why?) and then die again and lose. This is bad game design and also makes no sense. Seriously this is the second worst part of the game.

So what's the worst part? Well it's the fucking view. In singleplayer it's pretty tolerable. You can aim a direction and the camera will shift that way to help you see further. It's rare for the view in singleplayer to suck ass. In multiplayer though the view struggles to keep the camera around everyone.

Holy.
Fucking.
Shit.

What atrocious game design. I don't give a fuck if this is intended to be 'funny' or 'goofy' this is horrible. More often than not we'll have one guy who gets seperated from everyone else and now suddenly we can't fucking see and then can't fucking move farther to get away from enemies. This causes at least one person's death. Why is the game like this? This is stupid as hell and is almost bad enough to not recommend the game from solely. If it wasn't for the rest of the game being so good then I'd tell everyone to steer clear of this abomination. Split screen cameras were made FOR SPLIT SCREENS. Don't enforce it on players playing online.

And I wanna point out that the difficulty in this game is regularly too dependant on you rushing. I fucking hate games that rush you. If you don't rush you won't have enough supplies to make it through. And some later missions really require you to have heavy weapons or you can't even kill some of the enemies. This sucks. And with the way the views work you will often find yourself being run down and instantly killed by an enemy you couldn't even react to. What piss poor design choices there.

Ok so I got that off my chest. If you can believe it, the rest of this game is pretty great. I disapprove of the forced 'galaxy' war system that they have and the forced 'end of war cutscene' you have to watch every time you login after a week, but it's a pretty good game. I think the gunplay for this is some of the best in the top down genre and that there aren't that many that match it. The Halo twin stick shooters have some nice gameplay too, but they're fucked cause they don't have multiplayer.

[h1][b] Graphics [/b][/h1]
[b]The area between mobile game quality and something good.[/b] Because the camera is often zoomed out a decent amount the graphics are often pretty tolerable. But only just so for the majority of the time. Some of the environment look really nice as well. I like the chosen colors for the players and I think the models are well made. I like seeing the enemies start to fall apart as you damage them and I do definitely feel some heart in how the graphics were made.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1470888939

But augh, the homeworld have this really UGLY tint to the screen. The bugs have yellow tint. The cyborgs have red and I forget what the others have. AUGH. GROSS. It's very distracting and ruins the invasions of the enemy homeworlds. Not to mention the environments don't even LOOK different. They just have this ugly tint.

Speaking of the enemies, they have some nice variety. Cyborgs aren't something done in many games so I enjoyed to have them around. The bugs are just bugs. Most games have that sorta alien. They're satisfying to kill though so I won't complain. The sorta energy based aliens are my favorite though. I really like energy based aliens and I also find them to feel the most unique. Unfortunately they're also the most frustrating to understand how to even fight.

[h1][b] Sound [/b][/h1]
[b]The clink of a near empty magazine is what seperate good sound design from average.[/b] Although I feel they failed in making the views and graphics really noteworthy, their sound cues are top notch. You'd be surprised how uncommon it is to have the 'click click click' of a near empty clip and how often you miss having sound cues rather than visual to let you know something. This game seems to understand that sound cues are important has a ton of them. Enemy being signalled or letting you know they're about to signal. You get a visual and audio cue.

[h1][b] Story [/b][/h1]
[b]Let's not be silly here, there is no real story.[/b] But I will point out that you're just SUPER EARTH and you're being assholes and taking over the universe while fake propaganda calls you the good guys. That's it. Don't pay this game for the story.

[h1][b] The Developer [/b][/h1]
[b]This is the Magicka devs.[/b] I currently don't feel strongly about these devs. And the reason behind that is I'm not sure who's at fault for shutting down 'Magicak: Wizard wars' since it's reportedly on paradox interactive's shoulders (they're a publisher). So I'm reserving judgement. That means I have no strong feelings either way about them. Strictly meh.

[h1] In Conclusion [/h1]

HELLDIVERS is a very enjoyable experience if you like chaos, friendly fire, and bombastic sounds and effects. Friendly fire is a major selling point, do not feel bad if you kill your teammates as you will very much one shot and be one shotted by many weapons including from your allies. The game also rewards skill and thinking under pressure, if you have played magicka you will know how Arrowhead Studios handles their coop combat games. Abilities called stratagems, are activated by inputting a series of inputs be it a D-pad on a controller or WASD, once the correct code is inputted, your character holds a beacon that you must throw to call it down wherever you wish. The fun part begins here, as you unlock deadlier stratagems, the danger for you and your allies increases as well. You can call down support weapons like anti-tank weapons and heavy machine guns, and end up being able to call down artillery barrages, missile strikes, napalm walls, heavy cannon strafing runs, and then a tactical nuke. Enemies are relentless and will not stop spawning throughout the entire mission, that is if you are spotted. The stealth in HELLDIVERS is all about blasting the patrols before they detect you instead of sneaking. Once you are detected, the enemies will spawn near the edges of your screen or sometimes on top of you and then things get intense. Those stratagems from earlier are very useful here and inputting the codes under fire and in the ensuing chaos is something that will save you, your team, and the mission, that is if you don't throw it at your feet.

HELLDIVERS does have a fair amount of references and easter eggs to many pop-culture and science-fiction works, like novels, films, or other video games. Admittedly, the game is lacking in lore and background, and there is no story, but it is meant as a couch coop twin-stick shooter and lack of story here is not a drawback.

The skill ceiling is high, and players who can input codes quickly, clutch a revive stratagem, or know what to do in different situations will help their team and finish missions. You will get killed A LOT, and you will kill your teammates, A LOT, but as long as one player is alive, they can call down a revive stratagem so all hope is not lost. The game rewards cooperation and performing under pressure, as the enemies and your weapons are very deadly. You are still just a human in the end, and the enemies will stop at nothing to use what is available to them to kill you, as you will use what you have to do the same to them.

Helldivers is a top down twin stick shooter where you play an elite soldier deployed in futuristic intergalactic warfare. The game is intended for co-op and up to 4 players at once but being a chronic introvert I actively try to avoid the scenario this game was optimised for.

The gameplay is a tactical arcade-y affair with a focus on resource scarcity as your gun runs out of ammo and grenades are in limited supply. This brings in the real time strategy aspect as you are constantly calling down supplies, turrets, and vehicles using long strings of d-pad inputs like you're performing a fatality. Combined with the large open levels with key objectives it feels like an action oriented Warcraft 3 by way of Starship Troopers.

If you're in a team I could see things being more frantic as you cover each other, call in drop pods, and take on hordes of robots and bugs but as a solo game everything feels desolate, empty, and slow. You empty your magazine, call in an ammo drop, wait, collect it, repeat. I just don't think it's intended to be a single player experience so it's not one for me.

It's one of the best co-op games I've ever played. The gameplay is great, it's so much fun to mow down bugs/cyborgs with tons of different weapons. I love that the ammo mechanic is magazine based. Which means, if you reload with some ammo left in the magazine you discard, that ammo is lost. Just like in the good Battlefield games. It helps with the immersion of being a soldier on this hostile planet surrounded by enemies. There are loads of vehicles, airstrikes, drones, turrets and more, that you can call in, adding to the fun.

I think there are only 2 flaws to the game. On higher difficulties, tank units spawn very often, so you're kinda forced to bring lots of anti-tank equipment. This essentially limits the loadout variations drastically. If you play on high difficulties all the time, the only thing you can really change are your main weapons, because most of your equipment will stay the same to deal with the constant tanks.

The second flaw is the online-only campaign. The campaign being online and all players adding to the progress, makes you not very invested in it. The contribution you deliver is basically nothing in the grand scheme of things and often campaigns are won and lost with little to no of your involvement. The game may as well not even have a campaign because it never feels like you contributed anything to it.

Despite those flaws, the game is still great and you should buy it now!

Time to spread Liberty and Democracy in 3rd-person.

Lets start off where all good things do. With context.

HELLDIVERS is a top down, 4-player cooperative shooter. It is set in a hyper parody sci-fi universe in which the democratic Super Earth is fighting in a 3 front war for the sake of freedom. Very cool, very fun. Takes itself very seriously.*

Lets get into the gripes and grandeur of this title right away, starting with the issues of the game.

[1.] Lack of Story
The second you get into the game, the entire story is laid out for you. If you don't understand it, it is unlikely any amount of playtime will get you there. There is simply not a focus on story in this title. This is made up for in other aspects of the game's mechanics and playstyle that make the lacking story a rather unimportant side detail. Still, if story is an important aspect of a game for you, this is certainly something to consider.

[2.] Required Cooperation, "Required" Friends
This game is no joke. You are diving into a hellscape of whatever you want to call the aliens you're fighting, and I mean that literally. If you're playing on any difficulty higher than game journalist, the fact is that there are enemies and there is a lot of them. This means that the higher difficultly (and by extension, higher amounts of fun) missions quickly become impossible for a solo player to overcome and can certainly lead to frustration. 
The good news? This game has a fairly dedicated and (mostly) non-toxic fanbase, who are often playing public lobbies open for you to easily hop into and join the Zurg slaying fun. Still, having your own friends who are willing to play with you or just having cracked gamer skills is certainly going to make the game easier and (again, by extension) more fun.

[3.] Galactic "Campaign"
Here comes my first real gripe in the game's systems, and I don't really have any jokes about this one. 
The Galactic Campaign is a fairly unique campaign system which dictates the missions you will go on, the environments they will be in, and the enemies you will face. The galactic map is fairly large and 3 factions are available at the beginning of a war to fight. The 3 factions are very different to fight against. Some are big, sloppy bugs. Others, cyborgs with miniguns and cannons. And herein lies the issue.
The largest draw of this game is its fun, alien destroying combat. It's fluid, its well put together, and feels natural. Players are usually incentivized to move between the 3 factions to unlock new gear and get a better understanding of the challenges each faction provides. There is an issue with this only because the way the galactic campaign is set up means that oftentimes, the easier or more fun to fight factions can be quickly defeated. When this happens, the faction CANNOT be fought again until the start of the next war, which can be days/weeks/months away from happening. This means that players might not get to experiment and try out all of the content in the game, despite having paid a nice $20 to do so.
((IN SHORT: THE CAMPAIGN SETUP MAKES IT SOMETIMES IMPOSSIBLE TO ACCESS THE GAME CONTENT. THERE IS NO WAY TO ACCESS THE OLD REGIONS AND THERE IS NO PERSONAL, OFFLINE CAMPAIGN.))

Now that is out of the way, we can move on to what makes HELLDIVERS fun. I'll keep it short.

[1.] Expertly crafted mechanics.
All of the actual gameplay mechanics in this game are seasoned to perfection. The combat, movement, and more all are fluid and natural feeling. Players can quickly pick up how to move around, shoot, aim, and even call down stratagems and other equipment. This means a fairly small portion of the game is you having to spend time learning HOW to play it and spent actually playing.

[2.] Cooperative leaning gameplay.
While the needed cooperation on harder difficulties can be frustrating when you want to play alone, the reality is that HELLDIVERS is much more enjoyable with other players anyway. There is nothing quite like finding a team that can expertly work together and communicate to bring a mission to a close. There will be the times of struggle, of people accidentally teamkilling, but this is just the beauty of HELLDIVERS. If you play, you'll understand why it cannot be any other way.

[3.] Highly configurable playstyles.
How do you want to play HELLDIVERS? Do you want to run around with a sniper rifle picking off the far enemies for your team? Want to call down heavy turrets and stationary defense to protect the objectives or close off enemy pathways? Or maybe you want to summon giant, armored mechs with autocannons for hands to rip apart the gunners attacking your squad with heavy gunfire. 
The beauty of the game is that you can do any of these things, and there are a million other possibilities. A large selection of optimized, powerful weapons for the base arsenal and a massive amount of options for high powered stratagems means you can absolutely find a loadout that works for you and allows you to be an asset of destruction and team player all in one. And believe me this makes the game fun.

There you have it. Lets end on a final note in which I tell you with complete honesty that this game is very, very good. It's well put together, fun to play, and allows for endless, arcade style fun to be had. With a sequel not far away, (coming later this year) and a complete asking price of $20, you will certainly get bang for your buck with this title. I could not recommend this game more, despite it's very minor shortcomings, due to the very real fun and laughter that is to be had in this game.

Best of luck to you, Helldiver.

I recommend it on sale, but there are some things that I didn't enjoy. The pros are that there is surprising variety in how you can accomplish missions due to the loadouts you can bring into the levels as well as the generally different enemy types. 

The big negative is that at higher difficulties, the game just stops being fun because they will spawn enemies infinitely and it the game comes to a standstill as you need to crawl your way across the map while be swarmed by a dozen tanks and squads at the same time. The way to prevent this, in the game, is to kill a patrol squad before they can send out the signal. But I don't think this is good game design since it's rather difficult to do and can have a chain reaction since failing one squad execution leads to a skirmish and thus makes it almost impossible to kill the other squads before they call in backup. 

Overall really good, but I don't know how they expect you to beat or enjoy difficulties above 10. And for difficulties below 7, it's going to play very similarly each time. I mean, the weapon and loadout variety is good and playing with teammates adds replayabiliity, but you will have the same missions and the same enemies (depending on difficulty) so it's more that there is relatively limited content.

One of the best top-down games of all time - hands down.

I have played Helldivers since its release in 2015, with intermittent pauses here and there. What I think is most telling about this game is that even without the enormous budget and huge backing of a mega studio, without any constant content releasing stream of news and "reminders" to the world that it exists, it still has a loyal and firm fanbase that keeps coming back to it week in and week out. And the reason - it is that good. 

It does not have graphics that push your brand new RT GPU to its limits. It does not have artwork that will blow your mind with its depth and complexity. It does not have a story, or characters that can spawn a TV series. But what it does have is a unique combination of great gameplay, endless replayability and most of all - edge-of-your-seat fun and suspense, and the following sense of relief and achievement when you pull a split-second save or evac off.

I have reached lvl 50 on Playstation in 2016 and then started from scratch on PC last year. I am planning to reach lvl 50 here, too and enjoy this game for a long time.

For those of you who are wondering whether to go for it - trust me, you will not regret it. Don't mind the reviews that you need friends/couch buddies to play it - far from truth. I have almost always started a session solo and teamed with random people online. And I have made one or two digital friends that way along the way.

If you're looking for a game that will put your shooting skills to the test while also challenging your coordination and communication with your team, then look no further than Helldivers.

At its core, Helldivers is a top-down, twin-stick shooter that gives you a variety of weapons and abilities to take on alien threats across a range of dangerous environments. But what sets this game apart is the emphasis on teamwork, where you and your fellow Helldivers must work together to complete objectives and fend off enemy attacks.

But don't let the emphasis on teamwork fool you - this game can be downright hilarious in its chaos. Accidentally shooting a fellow Helldiver, calling in an airstrike on your own position, or getting killed by a stray bullet are all too common occurrences in the heat of battle.

Despite the potential for friendly fire mishaps, the Helldivers community is surprisingly supportive and friendly, with players often offering tips and strategies to help their teammates succeed. It's up there with other cooperative games like Deep Rock Galactic in terms of fostering a positive player base.

All in all, Helldivers is a challenging and chaotic game that rewards skill, communication, and teamwork. It's not for the faint of heart, but if you're willing to dive in and get your hands dirty, you'll find a game that's as entertaining as it is challenging. So grab your gear, take aim, and get ready to fight for humanity's survival!

1) No quickslots for Stratagem. You have to hold down one key while inputting a code that consists of arrows up, down, left and right. When things get hairy while playing solo it is almost certain death to try to input those while under attack. A simple quickslot, one key press, would've done wonders for this ability but instead it is tedious at best.

2) Gun magazines are extremely low capacity. You get like 4-5 shots with pistol and maybe 6-8 with rifle. You are constantly reloading and takes away from the combat. And when down and being attacked by packs of 3 cyborg dogs in groups of more then one means you'll run out of ammo and not be able to fend them off long enough to rez.

3) Enemies just spawn on top of you and can kill you before you can escape. Makes no sense that they just "POOF" out of nowhere and they are right on top of you. Would've been far better to have them drop beacons and spawn from that.

4) Enemy patrols just appear out of nowhere and they don't have a base or whatnot that they spawn out of so seems rather dumb. And they are infinite which is something else I do not like. Would've preferred an option or even on lower difficulties to have limited number of enemies and be able to clear a mpa and not have them respawn in.

5) The pointer is not 100% accurate. I'll have the enemy square in the middle of target and I am somehow missing it and they are in range of my shots. It is frustrating especially when magazines are so low which means shots NEED to count even more.

6) Can't fire while prone. All prone seems to do is avoid weapon fire. Not sure if you can just stay down there forever and not be hit or if you can only be damaged by melee. Needs further testing but not being able to fire while prone is terrible.

7) The pointer turns into a shadow. It is cool but I would've preferred to have an option to leave the pointer on all the time. I can lose it during action unless I constantly have my aim on which is not efficient.

[h1] One of the best co-op games ever made. [/h1] 

Helldivers is already a bit on the older side but at the time of writing this review the game is on sale for 5 bucks with all expansions. It is one of my favorite multiplayer games ever and for that price it is an absolute recommend from me. 

[hr][/hr] 

[b] What is it?[/b]
Helldivers is a cooperative mission-based top-down-shooter set in a world that is largely inspired by the Starship Troopers movie. You are a proud citizen of Super Earth and joined the Helldivers to spread FREEDOM and DEMOCRACY™ to the galaxy...with guns. 

[b] What is the main gameplay like?[/b]
You and up to 3 friends (this really is a coop game, you can play it solo but it isn't as much fun, trust me) team up to complete objectives on planets belonging to one of 3 distinct alien races: 
- The Bugs, an insectoid species making use of swarm mechanics and monstrous super-units. 
- The Cyborgs, twisted former humans that are now more machine than man. 
- The Illuminates, an advanced Alien civilization that uses advanced technology and specialist fighters against you.

Before each mission you choose the faction you want to fight as well as the difficulty (there are 12!! different difficulties available). You then select your loadout. You will then have to complete multiple missions on the planet before you can extract. These missions range from capturing enemy territory to diffusing minefields or assassinating enemy boss units. You can even achieve this stealthily by avoiding or eliminating the many enemy scouts roaming the map. 

After completion your progress will be counted toward the war effort (more on that later)

There is no skill tree, however you will be able to unlock vehicles and abilities by completing certain missions and you can research weapons and upgrades by finding science packs during the mission.

[hr][/hr]
 
[b] What makes the game so great?[/b]

[b] [u] The Graphics: [/u] [/b]
Although the game is from 2015 thanks to the stylized art style it still holds up surprisingly well graphically. The visual effects and sound are done so incredibly well that they even surpass a lot of modern games in my opinion. All in all very impressive.

[b] [u] The Enemies:[/u] [/b]
Every faction's units have their own character and unique strength and weaknesses. Some are bloodthirsty maniacs that just come after you relentlessly, some create barriers to separate you from your team mates or invert your controls with mind tricks. Once you are detected they can also become quite dangerous; even just a few hits will lead you to bleed out and be quickly finished off if your teammates don't come to your aid.

The unique thing about enemies in this game is the armor system. Most standard units are not armored at all, some have light armor that might force you to shoot a certain part of an enemy unless you are using a weapon with a bit more punch and some are heavily armored. Those you will not be able to damage 
[b] at all [/b] unless you are using a dedicated anti-tank weapon which makes good coordination with your team while choosing your loadout essential. 

[b] [u] The Weapons: [/u] [/b]
Except for a few stinkers (cough Arc-Shotgun cough) most weapons feel incredibly fun to use and are quite varied: Each gun has it's own unique feel as well as up- and downsides. Attributes like shot spread, ammo availability, reload speed as well as upgrades like poison bullets or a bayonet can have an immense impact in the hectic fray of battle. 

[b] [u] The Stratagems: [/u] [/b]
This is a system completely unique to Helldivers and I am quite surprised that i have never seen anything like it in newer games because it is really fun. With a system not unlike a rhythm or fighting game, where you have to input the correct combination of 'up' 'down' etc you can call down drop pods containing equipment (and yes, you can drop those hyper-velocity pods on enemies and it's very fun) as well as support in the form of artillery strikes, turrets or vehicles. You can equip up to 4 different stratagems before each mission which gives you more tactical opportunities than in pretty much every other shooter that I have ever played. This includes the ability to equip an additional weapon like a rocket launcher, a mortar or a god-damn shoulder-mounted auto-cannon!! as well as a multitude of support items like ammo packs, shields, drones etc.

[b] [u] The Co-Op: [/u] [/b]
No other game that I have ever played has nailed co-op quite like Helldivers. For one, you are actually forced to play and stay together: Your entire team shares one camera that is centered on the group so one guy can't just run to another part of the map. You will have to figure out together where to go and how to distribute tasks. 

You can also make use of cooperative weapons. For example your buddy can equip an anti-tank rocket launcher but give you the backpack with spare ammunition which will give you the ability to reload his launcher a lot faster than he could on his own, something that I have never seen in another game. 

All the vehicles also require multiple people to make full use of. The APC for example needs a dedicated driver and gunner. I am quite confident in saying you will be hard-pressed to find another game with as much thought put into the co-op as Helldivers.

The game also has all the friendly fire you can hope for which often results in hilarity. 

[hr][/hr]

[b] Now to the bad [/b] 

Helldivers is an amazing game, one of my all time favorites but it has one major flaw that multiple reviewers have already pointed out:

[b] [u] The War-effort: [/u] [/b]
Helldivers uses a community-driven global progress system. After each mission your progress will be transmitted to "Central Command" and be counted towards the war effort. If enough people complete missions in a system that system will then be counted as conquered and no longer be available  until you reach the enemy home world or, if you fail and the enemies retrieve it. 

There are two main points of critique I have of that system:

- Your own contribution matters very little: To finish a system a certain amount of points have to be contributed by the entire community. That can make your own contribution, no matter how hard you fought for it, seem completely insignificant. After having barely survived a mission against all odds seeing all your hard work being represented by a small number that doesn't move the progress bar at all can be really disappointing. This is a relatively minor issue but still something that had a negative impact on my experience.

- The only major point of critique I have of Helldivers is the fact that once you conquer an enemy homeworld you will no longer be able to play against that faction until the war is won and the map is reset. This is a completely baffling decision by the developers. With each faction that is eliminated fewer and fewer players will contribute, drawing the war out more and more.
 
Sometimes only one faction will be available to play against FOR WEEKS and then, once the map is reset all players of course want to play against the factions that weren't available FOR WEEKS which inevitably results in those factions being wiped out and the same faction as before being the only one left until the cycle begins anew. 

[hr][/hr]

We had great fun with the game overall - it is intentionally punishing and difficult and makes many things intentionally difficult leading to slapstick-moments that lead to deaths or even the end of a mission (when everyone dies).On the one hand that is part of the game and fun, if you can accept that you will often die or lose. On the other hand I understand some people get very annoyed by this setup quickly and give up on it because they feel they are being punished unfairly. For example it is hard to find your own character sometimes, since you dont have special colors or well visible markers. It is also hard to see where u aim unless you equip the red laser dot and even then u might end up hitting ur friends accidentally. Exiting a vehicle in a way it is still rolling a bit and hits you upon exiting leads to your instantenous death, this can also be frustrating. Some missions are tough challenges that you can only master by optimizing and adapting your loadout.

So overall how do you play: you run around in top-down view and separately control movement and aiming, you have to keep reloading in mind and track your ammo. If your ally dies you revive them with a combo of arrow keys that you need to enter while holding a button. This process is the same for all extras you request, including extra ammo, vehicle drops, special weapon drops, or to fulfil mission objectives, they are all done with key combos that you can fail and have to then repeat which is an interesting challenge and adds to the whole time pressure aspect well as you will stand undefended and immobile while doing so. As you traverse the map you will see enemies and some of them contain scouts. IF a scout sees you they will call in reinforcements which is a huge impact to your chances of survival so you always want to pick out these scouts.
And here goes the first grievance we had with the game: sometimes scouts saw us although we couldnt see them (they were offscreen). It was impossible for us, despite standing close to each other, to see the scout and therefore kill them, before they saw us. This does not happen often but when it happens it feels extremely frustrating since you dont know what to do about it. Another problem we had is that the world has a progression influence by all players. You might come back to play the game after some days and you get 10 cutscenes you dont care about since you had nothing to do with them and then you realize now you can only pick one type of enemy planets (one enemy race) as target for the time being. NOT FUN. We like to pick enemies at our will and we effectively are constantly locked in and locked out of options. I dont see any purpose in this game design decision.

Overall it is a fun coop game with a lot of challenges and interesting design decisions, although it is surely not perfectly balanced and not suited for anyone with a low frustration threshold. If you like hardcore games and like the gameplay and setting, this might be just perfect for you

Pros:

Fun and challenging gameplay: Helldivers is a top-down shooter that offers fun and challenging gameplay. The game's difficulty is well-balanced, and the gameplay mechanics are tight and responsive.

Co-op support: The game supports up to four-player co-op, which allows players to work together to complete missions and objectives. This creates a fun and engaging social experience.

Customization options: Helldivers offers a lot of customization options for weapons, gear, and appearance. This allows players to tailor their loadouts to their playstyle, which can be satisfying and rewarding.

Active community: The game has an active and dedicated community, which means that finding matches is never difficult. This also allows for a lot of player-created content, including mods and custom missions.

Cons:

Steep learning curve: Helldivers can be a challenging game to master, especially when it comes to the game's mechanics and strategy. This might be off-putting for some players who are looking for a more casual experience.

Limited enemy variety: While the game's enemies are well-designed and challenging, there are only a limited number of enemy types available. This can make the gameplay feel repetitive over time, especially for players who have been playing for a while.

Limited mission variety: While the game's missions are well-designed and fun to play, there are only a limited number of mission types available. This can make the gameplay feel repetitive over time, especially for players who have been playing for a while.

No single-player content: While the game's co-op mode is fun and engaging, there is no single-player campaign or story mode available. This might be disappointing for players who prefer to play games on their own or who are looking for a more narrative-driven experience.

A tactical and funny twin-stick shooter that's still going strong after many years. The controls are tight, the servers are still strong, there are a number of challenge levels for everyone, and the power balance between you and your enemy feels just right. But there's a particular thing that makes Helldivers really stand out. 

Obliged teamwork in games, particularly games with action elements, has often been a really hard thing for game devs to get right. We've all played a game where you just need someone to "get on the point" or "push the button" or whatever it is, and nobody's doing it. And then you lose because your allies are off doing whatever the heck they do when they choose to play team games alone in a crowd. It'd be easy to blame the individual players for that behavior (and oh, I do!) 

But when it comes down to it, the developers who make those games should know what players do in games. And-- since they DO know that, those devs should have designed their games with those behaviors in mind, urging and/or compelling players toward teamwork or, failing that, choosing to make a different game with different goals.

There a number of elements in Helldivers that address that very issue. Without getting the weeds, just know that they succeeded. Players (mostly) work together and accomplish objectives like they should-- a tough nut to crack for many creators, but Arrowhead pulled it off.

A fair warning: if you approach this game like a straight action game you won't make it very far and you'll probably end up frustrated. In Helldivers you play as commandos. As such, your goal is to move quickly from one objective to the next without getting bogged down in long engagements. Leave the front line fighting for the off-screen infantry; the waves never end and later difficulty levels you shouldn't expect to be able to kill all the on-screen things before resuming objective work. You'll need to be doing both at once.

Thinking of the enemy as an obstacle, rather than an objective, is key to success. 

Your choice of gear is important from one mission to the next. Keep an eye on what your team takes, fill in the holes in group's loadout, avoid things that kill your friends more effectively than they kill your enemies, and you'll find that the game's a lot more manageable than it often seems to new players at first.

And it's very worth your engagement: this a smart action game for smart action people that rewards understanding the underlying systems, prioritizing objectives tactically, relying on your team and, naturally, shooting straight. But it doesn't require a bunch of stat analysis and grognard stuff.

Have you ever watched the movie Starship Troopers by Paul Verhoeven? Did you like it? Well, this is the game. It's super cliche, there isn't anything really innovative or special, the gameplay gets a bit repetitive and old fast but still a fun game to play online cooperative. It's the simple formula well done. Grab a gun and burst some ugly aliens for the glory of mankind!

This game is excellent, and I find myself picking it up whenever I'd like to get one or several 5-15mins of gaming time in, as the games can be pretty quick if you want, or if playing solo you can take your time on some of the less difficult maps. You don't have to play with people but the game is a lot more fun and feels a lot cooler if you do, and it's super easy to join up with someone or drop into an ongoing game.

The combat is simple; twin-stick shooter but incredibly addicting and fun to watch and take part in. It can go from calm to absolute chaos in a few moments, and the more people on the screen the more difficult it is to be coordinated but also you have more firepower.

It comes with a perk system, weapon unlock, and 'power-up'/call-in system called stratagems (my one complaint here is that these all use the same currency: research points). Additionally there are planet and level up unlocks that you get as you play. 

At this time it's still pretty easy to find people to play with, and I've had no issues. The only thing is I wish it was easier to add people to my friends list from playing with them, as there is no easy way to do this without searching the persons name on steam or getting/giving a friend code but the former doesn't seem to work all that great and the latter is not as streamlined as it could be.

Enemy variety is pretty good with 3 factions and each have distinct units, abilities, strengths and weaknesses. There are 12 difficulty levels (or 'planets') but I personally haven't played much past difficulty level 5-7. These higher level missions are easier with more people; but they are soloable with the right build and a lot of practice I think(i read that somewhere).

The music is awesome and the sound effects for all the guns are weighty and destructive. The weapons seem relatively balanced and even the standard rifle is pretty damn good for a while, at least it has been for me.

I kinda wish people would go after research points more when playing in a team, that's not really a gripe with the game just an observation.

I bought this game on sale for I think $5? Well worth it, personally I think it's a little steep at $20 though. I would pay that price I think knowing how good it is, but I'd be more comfortable if it was $15, because it's a seven year old game.

Online co-op top-down shooter where you get to call in airstrikes, orbital lasers, etc. by throwing "Stratagem" beacons. Stratagems can offer offensive/defensive abilities or supply certain items. Large variety of weapons keeps the game interesting, along with mostly useful & interesting upgrades. Stratagems are also upgradable.

Some weapons are rarely equipped by people and just plain weak - though still fun to mess around with.

AIMING:
Mouse & keyboard has a huge accuracy advantage because it has aiming crosshairs showing you where bullets/lasers/attacks will go. Controller players don't have the aim icon, and will typically have <50% accuracy - this can get annoying on sweaty hard missions when they can't aim at & quickly kill enemy patrols that are far away from their character. These small-sized scouts need to be killed quickly or they'll raise the alarm, calling in more tough enemies.


Controller players have 1 slight advantage where they can throw Stratagem beacons off screen much farther - throw distance is based on how long you hold the throw button. Mouse & keyboard is based on distance from player to their crosshairs - which stays on screen and can't go past the edge. M&KB has the advantage where you can more accurately place Stratagem beacons for precisely calling in bombs, strafing runs, railcannon strikes, etc.

Something else I should mention is that you can bind custom macros to mouse and keyboard buttons with a variety of software (Logitech Gaming Software, Corsair's iCue, AutoHotKey, etc). This can be vital for rapidly  throwing out Stratagems in a few milliseconds, like those that respawn your teammates. Controller players are stuck with manually inputting the cheat-code-esque button sequences to activate the Stratagems - even if memorized it's nowhere as fast as automated button sequences.

I really can't recommend this game. It has the potential to be really great, and there are times where it is fun, but there's some specific design decisions that very much ruin the fun of what could be quite a good game. I'm just going to outline them in this review, then it's up to you whether you can overlook this and enjoy the game. I can at times.

1) 'Squad' based camera - Probably the worst design element of the game, and the one the developers are the most stubborn about, even despite the significant backlash. In HellDivers, the camera operates not around your position, but places itself in the middle of where the general squad is. There are a huge litany of issues with this approach, like:

- Due to the colour palette and lack of good U.I., it can be very difficult to actually distinguish your own character from other players
- You can't play tactically. Say you want to split up, so one person can get aggro, and the other person can shoot a bug's exposed rear. The camera will punish you significantly for doing this, and you're likely to get killed.
- Say you get downed. The camera will consider you dead, and will wander off to where your team is. This often means you will find yourself off screen (indicated by an arrow) with basically 0 chance of actually getting back up. 
- The camera will result in you getting one shot by enemies you had very little, if any, way of anticipating. They will be aggro'd outside your visual range, especially if you're just playing multiplayer, and their attack goes across screen. 
- An intended design choice, it makes the game very claustrophobic. 

All in all, I consider it (and quite a few others) the most negative feature about the game. It doesn't encourage teamwork in the slightest, it encourages you to group up, and people mistake this for teamwork.

2) Enemy design

This is also a pretty weak point of the game. At the beginning, the enemies are fairly interesting and the gameplay is creative. At the higher end, the game developers felt enough work was done, so what they did was reuse the same enemy designs but just make them tankier and make them spawn way more.

- Due to the claustrophobic nature of the game, you are both forced to group together and punished for doing so in the form of hostile game design. Plenty of enemies, especially bugs, have either AOE attacks or, like illuminates, ways in which players are forced to split apart, which as mentioned you are punished for doing so. It results in awkward gameplay that stops being fun. 
- BUGS - At the higher end, bug games became a case of stratagem spam, because they are very tanky units without any weaknesses except hitting them with something hard. All their attacks are basically insta kills.
- Illuminates - At the higher end. they are just annoying to play against. Again, some fun things could be here, like controls being reversed, your playable area being cut in half, but the camera makes it frustrating rather than fun to play against. You can get one shot from an enemy off screen, and poor unit design means you (too many players really) will be confused as to which side of the screen they're shooting from until they actually take the shot.
Cyborgs - Probably the most fun, up until they start spamming IFVs, and it becomes a tanky bug problem game, but its to me the most fun I had on this game.

Having defeated the bosses for each faction, each have the problem of being way too tanky, it gets very boring playing them. They could cut the HP in half and it'd be better. Also typical insta kill shenanigans, small arena issues etc. 

Why do I keep mentioning higher levels? Problem is that the lower levels are far too easy, and the enemy design poses no real challenge. Again, the issue is they didn't develop any proper middle level challenge, so it's either too easy or frustrating. 

3) Gameplay

This game is pay to win. There are some top stratagems and small arms that will make your experience significantly more fun if you get them (entrenched and support DLC is pretty mandatory, and if you don't believe me do a high level snow map with no all terrain boots to experience 'fun'). 
- At the higher end, the game is just stratagem spam. I literally took out the illuminates boss with a rando lobby who just spammed incendiaries (which enemies don't cross) and spammed rockets and ammo resupply until he was done for. This is the cheesiest gameplay you can imagine, it's not fun, it's just standing in one corner, spamming explosives, and dodging attacks, because anything else is just far more of a pain. 
- There are some really annoying quirks. Going prone is basically suicide. You can't use weapons (because that's real life ;) ), your movement is uber slow, and you are vulnerable as you stand up. 
- Some levels are just plain unfun. The ones where you're stuck in a very small arena, and enemies spawn anywhere (and often right next to you). These are the least fun by far.

I'll probably still play this game because it does scratch a fun itch, and there's a lot of good things going for it. But it's a game I would not recommend. It's not about "get good", I've done the hardest levels, and they're not engaging, they're just very unfun and once I did em I didn't want to do them again (and neither did the lobby). If you can overlook all that, you'll have some fun. But I doubt you will.

A fun game with powerful weapons and equipment (walking mechs, rocket launchers, flamethrowers, grenade launchers, mini nukes, bombing runs, and more). There are some items that require two or more people to operate, e.g there is an anti tank missile launcher that needs one person to fire and another person to load, and it's great fun when you make it work. This is also a downside, because you might not get to use some items very much if you usually play alone.

You upgrade equipment by finding research samples around missions (you usually have to walk around the entire mission and search away from objective areas to find samples, but it is no guarantee). Every 10 samples gives 1 research point, and each upgrade costs anywhere from 1 to 5 research points. Samples carry across between missions, so if you need 4 samples to get your next point and you find 6 samples, the extra 2 samples will count towards your next point.

I can't really think of anything bad to say about this game, except maybe that the environments are a bit basic. There are deserts, swamps, tundras, mountains, volcanoes, ruined cities, giant factories.. But they are all very flat, and there is no vertical movement - when you consider that this game is designed to work on PS VITA (a handheld console), it kind of makes sense that the design is simple.

whatever you learn in the first few hours know that your death however prevent-ably will reach a point of inevitability and the real strategy begins, utilizing the reinforcement system, get your team back in the ring before you become new lubricant for incoming tank treads.

I bought this game on its last sale after being recommended it from a friend whose taste in games I trust.  From the get-go the artistic direction of this game is fantastic, which one should expect from the same devs that made Magicka.  Plenty of satirical propaganda to make one chuckle (or worried) tied in with a killer musical score and just enough lore to make the game interesting without making it overwhelming or tiring.  For a game that's nearly seven years old as of this review it looks great.

Mechanically it's a twin-stick shooter, but with a Magicka twist: while your main weapons are twin-stick staples your specialty call-down items and attacks (called Stratagems) are summoned by inputting various WASD combinations (or + combos for controller users).  You can get bigger guns, vehicles, or various air/artillery supports, though placement and timing are key lest you get killed (again just like in Magicka).

Likewise, completing in-game objectives often requires interactions that also use these WASD/+ combinations, though only one objective type has the potential to backfire on you and kill you outright.

Here's where the game's shine starts to really darken: just like the titular Helldiver you are given a brief tutorial and then thrown into the grinder to learn everything.  What stratagems are best to use?  Gotta learn that yourself!  How do you put yourself out if you're on fire?  Figure it out!  When do I unlock this gun I like?  Look up up!  The game would have absolutely benefitted from having some more things spelled out.

And then the great big caveat of the whole game: it is an online co-op game.  Yes, you can technically unplug your internet and play offline, but the game was designed and constructed to play with other people and later difficulties (especially 13-15) effectively require a full team of four.  Even if you have a group of four playing on your couch none of your effort will count towards the campaign progress unless you are online.  While this might not normally be a problem there is also a much smaller community now than there likely was seven years ago.  These hardened veterans are very nice and helpful most of the time, but you are still likely to stumble across players who are bored playing at levels you are struggling with.

All in all, even with the online requirement and being forced to learn all the nuances under live fire this has been an enjoyable experience, albeit confusing and stressful at times and best played in doses.  If Helldivers 2 is ever a thing there are notes I want to pass on to the devs, though.
