Short short version: You're a Halo ODST fighting for the Starship Troopers government against zerg, cyborgs, and protoss. Also expect to die a lot.

Edit: Since I've now put a bunch of hours into the game over a week, it's about time I update my review.

SHORT VERSION: Helldivers is an up to 4 person coop game where you all share the same screen. You go on missions to collect samples for upgrades and get influence for completing planets. That influence goes into the region goal, where if enough Helldivers manage to fill it you advance one region. Once you run out of regions to take, you attack the faction's homeworld, hopefully get enough influence to conquer it, and then go on with your day against the surviving factions.

LONG VERSION: When loading into Helldivers, you first need to select a region (or more accurately, enemy faction) you want to fight against. The three factions are 
1) In the top left are the cyborgs, a bunch of medium -> heavy armor enemies with guns that shoot you and dogs that knock you down and, as one person put it, "are Germany's leader in WW2's spawn". It's fun to bayonet them and watch the chunks of their corpses fly past you at full speed though.
2) In the top right are the bugs. Think the bugs from Starship Troopers, the Zerg from Starcraft, or the Tyranids from 40k. They're a lot heavier armored but are entirely melee oriented.
3) On the bottom are the Illuminate, basically an Eldar from 40k looking faction that functions like the protoss from Starcraft. They're very lightly armored, however they have shields which absorb ALL damage from a shot until the shield goes down. Doesn't matter if it's an infinity damage nuke, it'll absorb all the damage even if the shield goes down midway. You've likely seen people say that everyone hates fighting the Illuminate. I thought that was dumb and I'd fight them. I. DESPISE. FIGHTING. THEM. One enemy can flip your controls so up is down and right is left. Another can spawn a wall that blocks movement unless you brought the jetpack as your backpack equipment. And let's not even get started on the railguns. It's H E L L.

Once you select a region you want to fight, you can pick a difficulty. Each planet has 2-3 missions you need to complete, and a different difficulty up to 15 in numerical order. The difficulties to highlight are
1- Dive in the park, where you fight only enemy scouts
5- Challenging, where heavy enemies begin appearing. You need AT to kill them.
10- Suicide mission, which is as difficult as it sounds
12- Helldive, which used to be the hardest difficulty until the last major update (afaik)
15- The Inner Circle of Hell, S U F F E R.
"16"- Enemy boss planet where you fight against the boss and endlessly spawning hordes. No rewards except lots of influence. Do at your own risk.
There are also capital city fights, where you fight on difficulty multiples of 3 (3, 6, 9, etc) to earn influence and double xp as you attempt to hold onto a region. If you don't get enough influence fighting on the capital, the region is lost and the next region is attacked where you can then defend the next region. (RIP Winter Hold, we fought like hell to hold you o7)

Once you select your difficulty, you can select your loadout. Loadouts consist of a perk, weapon, and four stratagems. Stratagems come in three general types
1) Blue, which are support stratagems. These include vehicles, mechs, ammo, and anti-tank stuff.
2) Green, which are utility. These include things like turrets, barbed wire, mines, and the UAV drone to find samples (if it's level 3)
3) Red, which are your offensive stratagems. These are entirely focused on dealing damage in an area and range from a wall of fire to a tactical nuke.

Once you set your loadout, you can finally go on the mission. Jump in, call down any stratagems you plan to use, and get to work running to objectives, completing them, and then extracting. Planets are procedurally generated, so while you'll still run into areas that look the same as you've seen before, you won't get exact duplicate planets normally. In the 50 hours I've played, I've only noticed a duplication once with the SAM site objective being rotated. Overall I haven't noticed this though.

Do I recommend this game? Well let's look: I bought this game for $10 with all DLC with the intention of playing with a friend of mine who said we'd play all weekend who didn't wind up showing up since he was simping after an internet gril. So, I bought the game AGAIN for a different friend of mine and we played together. Then he wasn't around so I bought it for ANOTHER friend, who then questioned if a third friend might like it. That friend decided that if I'm paying, he'll play it. I have now bought the game 4 times for $40 in total. Then another friend of mine said they might like the game so I bought the base game and the terrain pack DLC to help with snow planets for them since the sale ended and I'm running out of money buying Helldivers, so that's a total of $65.

Tbh the limiting factor to my enjoyment of Helldivers is that I don't have friends to play it with (you can play with randoms though, as they can be really cool. I've even friended two of them), as playing with friends always increases the fun factor through the roof. I can comfortably run difficulty 6 solo if I run cardio perk + Justice rifle w/ the ammo, EAT, UAV, and Exo-44 mech stratagems while not going down at all, but with 3 friends we'll have a combined total of 20 downs on the same difficulty and 3 almost wipes. It's hilarious and a ton more fun with them but still fun to play alone!

So yeah, 11/10 would buy this 5 times again (though I don't have friends to buy it for except for the people who would play it amongst themselves and ignore me)

I used to play this game a ton when it came out on PS4 and was super excited to see it was on Steam too!  If you like challenging games that can get absolutely crazy in no time flat, I'm sure you will absolutely love this game.  If you get angry easily at games, you'll want to give this a pass, because you will die A LOT (most of it being accidental TK's too).  The only downside I have with the game is it can get repetitive; but you can stave that off for quite a while by constantly swapping weapons, stratagems, enemy faction, or difficulty

I've never had any trouble with getting kicked from games and only had to kick one person for trolling, and while a lot of people won't talk much more experienced players spend a lot of time helping other players unlock equipment. (Always thank the lvl 18+ in a difficulty below 7, they are there to help you)

A couple tips for a new player to reduce some of the bad experiences others have had:
1) Try to stick to missions with a difficulty rating only 1-2 lvls higher than your current lvl.  If you're lvl 5 trying to join a mission 8+, you'll probably get kicked because you'll be more of a hindrance than a help
2) Play some of the super easy missions alone or with a friend, this will allow you to get a feel for a lot of objective types and unlock useful equipment to bring to higher difficulties (recoil-less rifle or some other AT type is a must get to play 7+ difficulties)
3 Be mindful where you're shooting or throwing stratagems; 1 accidental TK is forgivable, 2 is annoying, 3 is frustrating, 4+ will probably get you booted (especially if the host is the one getting TK'd)

A unique concept of a game. Similar to Alien Swarm, this game has a scifi futuristic look. The loadout inventory consists of primary weapon like the assault rifle and machineguns , a subweapon such as a pistol, and a tertiary add on with the choice of a rattling gun or supply crate. You can play co-op couch or online multi-player. The tutorial does a great job of showing you the ropes with the controls, and weapons. So why did i give this review a 'no'? Unfortunately, this game is way too repetitive. The objective of the game is to capture the point, defend the point and then find the extraction point to escape. As you progress, you encounter more enemies and the capture point takes a longer time to finish. I'm not really a big fan of games with the aerial camera setup like Diablo.

Literally 100s of hours played on Playstation.  So very happy to see this game ported to Steam client.  

This is an ultimate top-down co-operative experience that you've been craving.  It literally forces teamwork.  If someone isn't playing accordingly, just boot, and eventually another will port in and take their place.  No loss in mission progress or penalty.  Next thing you know, you're with the same 4 person crew for the next hour and having a blast working out the challenges together.  The community is quite awesome really.

Each player has a unique game style (a plethora of gun, gear, and support combinations) and it is so much fun meshing strategies.  Throwing down razor wire then watching a teammate set it on fire with a flame thrower to further its effectiveness for example.  Or bypassing a 6 second artillery weapon reload by instantly changing mags from your teammates support backpack.  Believe me, 6 seconds can be a loooong time in certain situations.

Super light on storage and hardware usage, like 9 or 10 gigs(ish) with all the DLC content included I believe. This Alienware laptop (i7 with a 3070 integrated) runs at a mostly constant 62 degrees C. with graphics cranked up full nuts.  About 42 degrees C. just chilling on the desktop.  No crazy spikes or anything like that.  Laptop fans run like a tower and not like a jet engine (as per normal when gaming) so that is refreshing.

The in-game voice chat is excellent.  No need for Discord but there is a solid Discord community if that's your style.  No "join my Discord" spam exists that I have seen.  And if you're bashful, chat box available for us keyboard clickers.  

Hope to see ya on the battlefields!

So yea, I spend 5 bucks for the base game and then another 7.5 for a game I already had and all the DLC.

With that out of the way, this is a 8/10 game for me and I plan to play more. I had better communication and teamwork with randoms than friends playing this game, for a console import, keyboard and mouse controls are tight, tighter than games more recent and more fleshed out games. The loadouts might seem annoying to you until you realised that you 
having teamates kind of breaks the game cause you get up to 16 different stratagems which are 75% of your loadout. 
For guns, there's variety and good fun, tho you will figure out that some guns are better than others, but more so through mechanics rather than numbers. Your starting gun? It's good, it will be relevant, there's better guns but nothing stops you from doing all missions with it. No mechanic or numbers that just cockblock you.

>Story
Story is fun and if you don't like the tips shown during the hellpods dropping, you have something wrong inside. 
The Campaign is a 3-way war between The Zerg, The Protoss and The Emperium of Man, oh sorry, wrong ones, it's The Bugs, The Illuminate and The Cyborgs. Tho all these factions have scouts, infantry, heavy guys and other categories of units, they play out very very differently. It seems people like to kill the bugs. 
For example, scouts. Scouts send off alarms that summon more units as to kill you, scouts for the different factions are:
Bug - 3 bugs that each can spread spours to alert the other bugs
Illuminate - Invisible drone that screams when you commit a micro-aggression
Cyborgs - 3 light infranty units + a normal guy that sends out a flare

TL;DR  8/10, worth even the 25 bucks

TERRIBLE. I have no idea why this is positively rated.
-Tethered camera: When playing co-op you can not move away from your friends. You're all stuck in the same tiny area. When a friend lags behind, you can't see ahead of you so you get shot from off screen. Unacceptable for a PC game.

-Tedious Repetitive missions: The missions are short, the game play areas are small, the objectives are boring, and they're almost all the same, You're just supposed to play them over and over to grind out new weapon unlocks and small upgrades. The gunplay doesn't save it.

-Awful graphics: The game isn't that old but there's hardly any options in the graphical settings, and even on max settings it looks like it's running on a potato.

TL;DR: Fantastic 4-player multiplayer-focused action shooter you can really sink some hours into, perfect for controllers on the couch with friends. However equipment is everything in this game, and the best equipment is locked up in DLC packs. The Ranger pack is almost essential (just to get the UAV, it reveals Sample locations on the map which you need to upgrade all other equipment) if you plan to really grind out some hours on this game. If it's on sale and you're already interested, buy the Deluxe Edition to get all the DLCs at a discount, because you'll definitely want them all later.

Pros:
- Very strong Starship Troopers vibes. Kill endless swarms of bugs. Spread Democracy throughout the universe using violent and explosive negotiation tactics.
- Feels very arcade-y, in a good way. The gameplay loop is extremely action packed, and feels very good even during the game's most stressful moments. Skill & accuracy matter just as much as how well your equipment is upgraded.
- Instant in-and-out local 4-player multiplayer, perfect for controllers & couches. Even if you're in the middle of a mission, someone can pick up another controller and drop right in from orbit. Local and online multiplayer at the same time. (You'll need it too, see Neutral section below.)
- Always-on full friendly fire turns what would otherwise be a blind, dumb, shoot-em-up fest into a game that requires some tactical positioning considerations at all times.
- Very cool "Stratagems" system that plays into the "drop everything from orbit" theme & mechanics of the game really well. These are special beacons that you throw like grenades that mark the location to drop ammo, secondary weapons, character upgrades, vehicles, and mark the location for artillery/air strikes. Besides weapons and perks, these are your core considerations when designing a loadout, you only get 4 slots. To choose which one to activate during gameplay, each has a different "code" sequence of up/down/left/right directional arrows you need to enter in order. There are different difficulty levels of these sequences that make certain Stratagems take longer to use: e.g. a basic air strike only requires hitting 3 right-arrows in a row, but dropping an auto-turret requires hitting 5 arrows of all different directions, and a mech walker suit has a code 6 arrows long. It's like a fun little mini-game that adds to the arcade-y vibe, and is something you'll get faster at over time at as you memorize the "codes" to your favorite Stratagems.
- Great variety to all the objectives. They're like minigames that don't ever pull you too far out of the action, yet still require a decent amount of focus & concentration to get right quickly. Some like Activate SAM sites is a variation on the "arrow-codes" with a timed wait element, then there's bombing the shit out of bug nests, using a mine sweeper to find and disarm bombs, and pretty soon you're escorting survivors from dropship crash site. Some objective types are only available on the higher difficulty levels, and all of them are designed to be easier with friends (or turrets) watching your back.
- Even tho getting squished by incoming friendly orbital drops sucks, the game somehow still makes it seem pretty funny.

Neutral:
- Multiplayer, specifically a full party of 4, is basically required to experience the majority of the game. The difficulty ramps up really really quickly, there's 15 different difficulty levels, ending at "Inner Circle of Hell". You start at 1- Dive in the Park, then 2- Very Easy, but by the time you're ready for 3- Easy (maybe about 10 hours in, max), the game itself says that these levels are meant to be challenging for a single person. Endgame most certainly requires 4 players no matter what. (There's still usually a few hundred other players online at any given time as of this writing in summer 2022)
- Even though this game was obviously designed to be enjoyed with a controller, yet again, as always, using a keyboard + mouse will give you far better accuracy. This might really start to matter a lot more at endgame, but for now I'm getting by just using an Xbox 360 controller.
- No real story, you get thrown into the action pretty much immediately. The intro movie and tutorial fill in the majority of the background story you get. As soon as you finish the tutorial, you can choose any enemy race at any difficulty. (Bugs are the most popular, of course)
- Very grindy. While the gameplay loop is fun, progression is very slow. It would probably take close to 100 hours to unlock & upgrade everything. (*without the Ranger pack DLC, see below)

Cons:
- Some really damn-near essential equipment is locked behind a paywall in the form of DLC packs. For example, you probably want at the very least: Terrain Specialist Pack, which contains the All Terrain Boots perk. Without it, on snow levels your movement speed will slow to an absolute crawl, and the rest of your team who all already have it will start to get pissed off at having to wait up for you the whole match. (The Cardio Accelerator perk can be used as a substitute in a pinch.) And the Ranger Pack, which contains the UAV Stratagem. Once fully upgraded, it shows you the location of every research Sample on the current map, which give you more research points needed to upgrade all weapons & Stratagems. These upgrades are the main & only progression loop in the game, so anything that directly helps you gather more of them & faster, is going to directly impact the speed and grindy-ness of the whole game. And the rest of the DLC packs are mostly just much-more-powerful versions of the stock gear items.
- Stratagem "arrow-code" sequences aren't shown in the text description of them when you're safe back on your ship. This is silly because these activation codes don't change, and memorizing them offers significant value to gameplay. Even just seeing how many arrows a Stratagem requires to be activated would be of great help when choosing your loadout.
- Levels appear to be procedurally generated. While it sounds cool in theory, "never play the same map twice!" just like other games that have it, in practice what it means is every map ends up looking the same. Every map is very flat, features repeat themselves, and the only discerning characteristics between them become the different biome types themselves: is it a forest/desert/swamp/volcanic/snowy level? Because other than that 1 factor, each level looks and feels the same as the last.

Overall, besides the deceptive DLC packs, this is still a fantastic game I plan to sink many more hours into. And if you're looking for a 4-player party game with RPG/progression elements, there's very few other options out there that are this good. (Champions of Norrath on the PS2 comes to mind, but that's more of a Diablo-type game I've already dumped hundreds of hours into, and is starting to show it's age.)

HELLDIVERS is best described as a mix of Magicka + Alien Swarm + Irony.
Got your attention? Well, let me explain some bits here:
Magicka is definitely to be found in the raw backbone of the game (4-player with single player possible, dark humor and a harsh take on the "subject") and where Magicka was a tongue-in-cheek take on norse mythology with world eating snakes (easy kill for a meteorite, who would've thought?) and lots of friendly fire in the hectic of battle or out of boredom, HELLDIVERS has you and up to three friends drop into a combat zone to spread democracy and liberty among hostile alien aggressors.
And of these there are numerous! No storyline you can easily wander along enjoying the sights, it's almost always a run through territory crawling with enemies (sometimes literally) and they're always ready to drop some heavy, unfriendly blokes into your group.

Alien Swarm saw you and up to three friends follow the story of an infested colony, trying to rid it from crawling space bugs. The levels were gorgeous and the story pieced together through audio logs scattered in the levels.
You had your pistol and some main weapon, be it a flamer, grenade launcher, shotgun or whatever.
It's a good example of dedication to crafting nice levels and lots of little details that pop into focus when you play the second/third run. Since it's still free on steam: Go and give it a try. You most likely won't regret it and if you do: HELLDIVERS might not be the right game for you.
But that crafted story was also one of the downers: You played the same time and again. Sure, updates/mods allowed for other stuff but even these were the same after a while.
The first run was always tense and some trigger happy moments led to accidental team kills, the second was easier because you had a rough idea where the enemies would pop up and the third became a definite been-there-done-that run.

HELLDIVERS is different in that each player is contributing to the overall campaign, the War SUPER EARTH is fighting against the Bugs (which by PURE incident turn into bio fuel on death, totally not the reason to fight them and keep the industry going!), Cyborgs (which want liberty of the single being and think man & machine could work in the same body. Everybody knows that the managed democracy is the best way for humans to live in prosperity and liberty!) and Illuminates (which are a total threat to SUPER EARTH because they don't want us to have their advanced tech and also they're producing WMDs to eradicate humanity!).

Now, these missions are generated on randomized maps, with the outline of the combat zone hardly ever the same (apart from arena fights where you have to kill a certain amount of enemies to teach them a lesson!) and on these maps you get an area that might be using the same models of rock outcroppings, bunkers, cyborg AA emplacements, battlements, wrecks and the like but these assets are always rotated differently, so that you won't see two in the same orientation soon. I played 47h now and I haven't.

Controls are responsive enough with either Mouse & Keyboard or controller though in some cases you can clearly notice it was made for controller with twin stick and d-pad controls.
Your trooper moves fluidly, diving for cover in the direction he's facing (that often saves your behind, if you remember it) and generally shooting where he's looking.
Shooting? You'll do a lot of that and with a load of weapons. Aim to get a crosshair (otherwise your cursor is invisible) and unleash a salvo of slugs, blasts of shotguns or laser beams.
Because... if you don't shoot the enemy patrols will notice something's wrong with you, you not being a six-legged bug/heavily implanted mind-linked cyborg/descendant of jellyfish and signal for backup to ... cleanse that problem.
This backup -depending on the mission difficulty- might consist of some simple worker drones (boots up and stomp 'em out!) up to tanks (argh, another one? We're running low on AT ammo here!).

And that is the moment where the real fun starts.
See, every HELLDIVER starts his/her mission with a pistol (which can become quite a capable tool to dish out democracy), a rifle of one sort or another, one perk (an always-active item of equipment like incendiary grenades or a cooldown reduction for your stratagems) and four stratagems. These are marvelous.
They can be anything from an ammo drop to recoilless rifles vs armored targets, grenade launchers, artillery barrages, auto turrets, napalm, cluster bombs, mechanized assault suits (bad if you think they look like Warhammers Dreadnoughts) and many more.
These equipment drops can themselves be used as a weapon. Because, you see, they're dropped from a Hellcarrier in orbit. And they drop fast. And are heavy. And don't really brake before hitting the ground...
Anything standing under or next to them takes damage. A lot! No matter if it's your comrade, your teams APC or a bug Tanker: They're squished. Add to that the ability to upgrade them between missions and you go from "cluster bomb to take out infantry" to "laser guided bunker buster with side munitions to clear the area". Or for rifles from "the second shot goes in the same direction" to " four shot salvo dead center".

Overall, HELLDIVERS is a lot of fun thanks to the friendly fire incidents that are often times hilarious; the backstory that's brilliantly deliverd by NPCs (nice voice acting there, too!) and the Encyclopedia on the Hellcarriers; and the satisfaction from completing a stressful mission against the odds, evacuating all HELLDIVERS just before the shuttle is overrun.
Matchmaking is as fluid as you can wish for, just step on the teleport pad on your carries bridge and select a mission on some world and difficulty you like, short moment later: BLAMM, you're dropped into combat.

It might not be the right thing if you can't handle satire and are from the best damn nation in the world but even then:
Ignore the story, come for the shooting.
And the explosions.
And the laughter when another well meant and poorly placed artillery barrage takes out not only the enemy but your team...

Sure there's stuff they could've done better, like a planet rotating under the Hellcarrier to bring the later missions required to "liberate" it in sight, but the way it's now (left side with the Hellcarrier in geosync orbit and part of the planet with mission markers in the corner below; right side for mission details) you can select where to start.
Want to keep the mission with "Assassinate cyborg leader" for the end? Sure, go for it. Command thought it should be number 1, but it's your choice where to drop first and wreak havoc.
And maybe more than one climate zone per world. That'd make for a nice difference in appearance. Right now it's a Star Wars universe: desert worlds, snow worlds, jungle worlds, city worlds... but no variety. If it's one climate, that's it for the whole globe.
But that might be asking too much from a very fun, light take on guns-blazing-democracy.

In April 2022 (THIS YEAR) This game peaked with 3,458 players. In the last 30 days, the game has had an average of 1000+ plus players brewing a "Nice Cup Of Liber-Tea."

The game was already reaching about 1000-2000 players at peak times month after month, but the latest Steam Spring sale blew the player base threw the roof! 

Imma put this in perspective:

Do you want a casual game that allows you to pick up and put down in 15-30 minutes? 

Do you want a game that can be a piece of Super-Earth pie, but you can take the difficulty to extreme levels of chaos? (When you know "Democracy" MUST be spread no matter the cost of your time and or personal life?)

Then you need to visit your local recruiting office on Super-Earth today! 

This game is definitely made for a teen to adult level of play, but has appeal that transcends age. I played this game with my middle-aged dad with split-scream, and now he's fully "diving harder" with his own copy of the game. (I'm in my 20's and can't get stop spreading "FREEDOM")

Do yourself a favor and support the creators of this masterpiece. Also, if you really want to experience everything this game has to offer and more, the DLC is an absolute Must-Have. From the "all-terrain boots" DLC that let you run through winter-covered planets, to the "Pilot DLC" that gives you an anti-tank cannon mech, the cost is but a ticket to ride.

(Look, you don't have to buy the DLC, in fact, I don't usually buy anything with DLC because I often find the regular free items better than the paid.)

But after giving hordes of indigenous hostiles a "taste of freedom" with both paid and free loadouts, I can say with confidence that if you like the look of this game, you will 100% enjoy pretty much everything you buy for this game.

Short Version: 
Its a fun game with satire and lots of splat.
Reasonably short maps.
Reminds me of Magicka but with guns.

Longer Version:
It hits with the same kind of humor as Starship Troopers. The flavor of the scenarios aren't exactly deep to get into, and it is steeped in a tongue and cheek look at reality. It is amusing to me to put out in caps lock "FOR SUPER EARTH!" This is of course, followed by firing whatever weapon  I have until the clip goes empty and loosing every grenade in my arsenal. The game is designed for a character to likely die, and die frequently. On the higher difficulty planets, I saw like nine deaths still get the bonus exp for clearing. 

The "strategems" are a pain in the neck to start. Luckily, when you're learning them, you're probably not using them for the first time. Eventually, you will have say two seconds to fire up the command, rapid fire the entry, and revive your squad before you have to dive out of the way of some other angry thing trying to make you pay. You got some decent loadout things you can change according to your playstyle, but overall, if you don't have a plan, you're going to be in for a rough ride. 

There are different missions for each map. There are different objectives, and progression isn't entirely locked to level advancement. You get a good group together, you can crank out the research needed to advance your gear along the way. If this game is on sale, I totally recommend it, especially with the nifty DLC. If its not on sale, probably use your best judgement on that expendable income. I've had a good time so far, even when someone accidentally spawns and splats another squad member. Its just the life of a helldiver.

This is a highly polished game made for Co-op. For those of us familiar with the PS2 golden era with Metal Slug and Neo-Contra, this will give a familiar shoot-em up vibe. The main difference here is how brutal the game is if you don't play by the rules, especially above medium difficulties where enemies are a lot tougher. The means in which enemies spawn in the map are mainly by patrols/scouts detecting the players. You're given a variety of powerful tools and weapons to deal with your enemies but are mainly limited by your ammunition and the amount of times you can respawn. The game mechanics HIGHLY favor Co-op so get some friends to play with you or make new friends to play with along the way.

Things I like:
1. The game is polished; in graphics, sound design and mechanics. It looks good, it sounds good and it plays well.
2. The variety of strategems you have at your disposal to unlock, upgrade and use gives everyone a chance to experiment with different playstyles.
3. There is no consequences for defeat or loss. It just means that a mission is failed and you have to start over. Sure you lose the samples you collected in a mission for upgrades but that's about it.
4. There are no in-game micro transactions! Everything else is sold in DLC packages which are really cheap when discounted.

Minor gripes:
1. The music is very over the top and generic Starship Trooper propaganda music. I wish there was variety.
2. The camera can be very janky as this was built to be played Coop on the PlayStation. If 4 players decide to head in 4 different directions, the camera is going to stay still and everyone is going nowhere.
3. The upgrade system is rather grindy. You have to collect 10 research samples in each mission to get 1 upgrade point. The amount of samples increases based on the difficulty of your missions. However, if the other player (s) in your team decides to play the objectives than collect samples, your efforts become a lot slower.
4. At some point of time, the game becomes repetitive once you master a difficulty level, but that gives the incentive to tryhard and attempt even crazier difficulty levels which is hard to succeed on your own.

Still an incredibly fun and challenging game years after it got published and runs well even on relatively weaker hardwares, hope more players join and for the servers to stay running for years to come

This game is a top down strategic version of Destiny's strikes, except your missions actually matter. All ammo is limited, you can play with randos, friends, or yourself, and you don't need to kill anybody* to complete your missions. If you love PvE shooters that have you going point to point doing objectives and are good at rhythm games, this game is worth a try. The three different factions have a wide variety of enemies, some only spawning in harder missions. I love how unforgiving this game is too. It's so funny whenever you join your friend, and then you crush his head in with your drop pod. Basically everything that you can spawn will intsa-kill you if you stand underneath them, including the escape ship. The strategy you have to put of what you are going to take and how you are going to use it is so exhilarating for me that this is probably the best shooter I have played. There is so much to do in the game that you're only bored if you choose so. if you don't try out a few missions (and if you don't like it you can refund) you are missing out on the best top down shooter. 

*There is one objective on harder missions where you have to assassinate a miniboss.

"No problem, kill as much as you can! I'll never forget your bravery! You will become a legend!"
"I'll get to the shuttle and tell your story to the next Helldivers generation!"
"Before talking about legends, you better watch yourself about not getting squashed under the rescue shuttle!"[/i]

This friendly conversation will wrap the Helldivers Co-op experience in a nutshell. Like every Co-op focused game playing this game solo while it has its challenges, it will get repetitive much faster. The best way to get the most endless fun out of the game is by playing with your friends! Character's monologues during the missions like "Say hello to democracy" or "Freedom never sleeps" are one of the best parts of the game as the game uses this political humor very proudly. 

The core game will offer many handy gears to make the best loadout for each mission. If you wanted more variety of weapons and pieces of equipment, there are lots of great DLCs available to add to your inventory.

Teamwork and good loadout will make a difference in success and loss in these randomly generated missions. Character customizations are not so appealing because of the top-down camera and mistaking your character with others can be a regular accident! 

Thanks to the amazing sound design everything feels deadly. This friendly fire system is one of the best points of the game and it will force you to make better shots or call the pods in better places. It is full of joy and cry at the same time! Lack of the story and more sandbox and non-linear missions is a downside to the game but no one can deny the fantastic Co-op experience that this game has to offer!

10/10 one of the best games I've ever played. Helldivers is an almost perfect top-down shooter. I have, as Steam so kindly displays above this review to see, 25 hours played in this game at the time of this review. What you don't see is that I have roughly 150 hours on PSN of actual in-mission playtime in this game at the time of this review, so I feel I am capable of thoroughly reviewing this game, as on PSN, I have every weapon, every strategem (the equipment you get to call in on each mission), and every perk (accept for a couple strategems in 2 of the DLCs that I have not purchased.

The controls are easy to learn, hard to master, at least at a speed that keeps you alive in high-level missions. As a side note, controllers also work well with this game, and don't have the huge disadvantage that they do in FPS games, for example, which is nice as I am a native console user. There are some advantages to both, at least from what I've experienced.

There are plenty of weapons to use that all handle completely differently and match all sorts of playstyles. There are shotguns, sniper rifles, assault rifles, smgs, and every weapon has not only it's own stats, but many have their own unique perks, such as a mini-stun effect from some smgs and unstoppable rounds from a certain assault rifle, making gun stats not the only thing you look for in a weapon. The weapons feel as if they are their effects, like the SMGs don't pack as much firepower as other weapons, but the stun effect makes them easier to deal with for your teammates.

In terms of player base, it is still easy to find games to play in as of writing this review in May 2020, roughly 5 years after the game came out. Most of the players you find are friendly, but as with any game, you will come off the occasional annoying or just plain rude player. This is one of the few games that 4 people can play on the same PC at the same time. You also don't have to wait until the mission is over to join. Players can join at any point in a mission.

The DLC in this game does add a lot to it. On PSN, I have, as I said before, all the DLCs accept 2, and on PC, I have none yet. Seeing the game with and without the DLCs, I can say that they are certainly worth getting if you have the money. If you do get the DLC, getting all of it together would be the way to go, as you do save some money when you buy it all together. Speaking of saving money, the game goes on sale for half off frequently so getting it then is also advised.

There are 3 alien races or factions that you fight in Helldivers. Each with their own unique units and fighting styles. Each one has weapons that counter better than others, such as weapons with armor piercing rounds that do better against the bugs (the more armored faction, as you might have guessed). As a side note, there are also different planet types that have different hazards and disadvantages too. Both of these factors can influence your loadout in different ways, giving more variety to the game.

Also, as a bit of a miscellaneous paragraph: The game is updated every year on "Liberty Day" (in game holiday on October 26th), giving stuff like new free strategems or gamemodes. There is an official Discord for this game in which you can find people to play with. Even if you are a new player, there are people willing to help you out and help you learn the basics of the game.

TLDR: 10/10 game, nice controls, great weapon variety, good playerbase, multiple factions to increase game variety, and it goes on sale for 50% off often.

Helldivers is a challenging couch Co Op shooter which really nails atmosphere, importance of tactics and communication. It is brutal and unforgiving, but phenomenally satisfying and rewarding when you pull off a mission, overcoming seemingly impossible odds. 

The base mechanic of inputting a series of directional commands to complete objectives or call in powerful stratagems is a very refreshing mechanic, as some people may struggle with this, others may be terrible at shooting but absolutely fly through the command sequences, which opens up the roles team mates can play nicely. 
 
The persistent meta war is a nice feature, and I found myself logging in and being on the edge of my seat by the end of the war report, seeing how close we are to delivering managed Democracy to our enemies, or how close they were to our sacred Super Earth.

The humor in this game is also excellent, and the overwhelming majority of the community is patient and welcoming too. The only frustrating aspect is you can't separately upgrade to the Deluxe Edition after purchasing the game but it's a must buy, especially if you have people to Couch Co-Op with, and are eager to ruin your relationship with them.

This game is basically Starship Troopers the game. Hell, there's giant bugs even. But there's also Cyborgs and Fishborgs too. The Cyborgs are hard to kill and the Fishborgs are easy to kill, but they don't like it when you try to kill them, so they ask you politely to not and go away. For some reason this works. Unless of course, you're wearing an energy shield of some kind. In which case the sound of their voice just makes the barrel of your weapon jam itself down their throat. Very odd indeed.

If you are seriously considering getting this game, you need the DLC that gives the Humblebee UAV. Upgrade that to lvl 3 and you'll get upgrade points like a motherfucker. It spots the tokens you need for upgrades at lvl3.

Another thing I should add, the Illuminate(fishborgs) aren't scary. Energy shield, Punisher(pump action) shotgun and the Grenade Launcher(don't remember the name) and you're good to go. Punisher one shots all infantry and scouts, even shielded ones. The GL can be used to waste the walker tanks and council members(floating chair dudes) with ease. And because the punisher is loaded shell-by-shell, you can have a constant stream of lead headed their way.

Oh, never let your gun run dry. The reloads are WAAAY longer if you do. Even for the punisher. You'll hear a 'Garand Ping' when your weapon starts running dry. For the punisher, you get one before the last shell. That's when you reload. Energy weapons need not apply. You get overheating noise and beeping instead. Let it cool off a second and you'll be good.

This game accurately depicts shotgun, by the way. The punisher is the most accurate, able to fucking snipe across screen. The... other shotgun... is very good at crowd control, decent spread but still able to hit distance shots. The laser shotgun is... odd. But functional. Haven't used the double barrel yet, but it can become a sawn off.

Last thing, before I end this, I'm not sure if the 3 round bust on the standard pistol is good or not. In some instances I'm like 'Yes! I needed those extra bullets!' and in others I'm like 'FUCKING DAMMIT! I NEEDED THOSE EXTRA BULLETS!'. So idk. Wish it was selectable.

A very fun twin-stick shooter.

There's no lengthy story campaign to sit through, you just pick a randomly generated planet and a mission with randomly generated objectives then blast off with up to three buddies to bring Liberty, Justice, and the Super Earth Way™ to the three alien races: the Bugs, the Cyborgs and the Illuminates. All three races are mostly self-explanatory in their theme (the Illuminates are similar to the Protoss from Starcraft if you are curious) and all have a set of light, medium, and heavy units armed with unique weapons and abilities to keep you on your toes. There isn't very much in lore or story as I mentioned, but snippets of game dialogue paint a very satirical backstory for the galaxy, which is ruled by a hyper-centralized 'managed democracy' with some very imperialist and fascistic tendencies hidden behind a facade of freedom and patriotism.

Players can set up a load out consisting a primary weapon, a backup weapon, a perk, and four stratagems. Primary weapons run the gamut of assault rifles, snipers, shotguns, and laser cannons. Your backup weapon is always a basic pistol, unless you select a perk that swaps it out for something like a mini-flamethrower or a revolver. Other perks give you more passive buffs like a laser sight for increased accuracy or quick call-in times for your stratagems. Stratagems are essentially supply drops that can be used by the player to acquire things like extra ammo, heavy weapons such as rocket launchers, or even vehicles such as mechs and tanks.

Weapons and Stratagems can be upgraded by spending Research Points, tokens that are earned from both leveling up and finding 'Research Samples' on missions. All of this combines to make a pretty fun shooting experience with a decent amount of customization.

The only real complaints I have are: the UI is clunky and counterintuitive in some places, especially when it comes to setting up your loadouts. Why can you only set up a loadout when you're waiting in a lobby to start a mission? Why do all weapons of a similar type (i.e. assault rifles) occupy one spot on the weapons list in the loadout, and you have to cycle through them by clicking a tiny arrow? As a returning player I was confused and could not equip one of the assault rifles I unlocked until I realized this.

And: some of the graphics, such as your Helldiver character model, are on par with a PS3 or 360 game. I know it's from 2015 and the camera is zoomed out most of the time, but come on guys...

One of the best combinations of good mechanics, fun and sometimes challenging gameplay, and player teamwork I've ever seen together. The player community is generally pretty awesome. Despite the occasional disgruntled player, I can't say I've ever heard anything horrible over voice chat. The game encourages cooperation, and what I've seen of the community reflects that.

The setting is fun and honestly kinda hilarious, and in-game hints will often offhandedly mention horrifying existential or Orwellian concepts like they're everyday business. It has a lot of Warhammer 40k inspiration, along with some Halo thrown in there for good measure, and the resulting mix is refreshing. The three enemy factions are all completely different both aesthetically and strategically, and force the player to experiment with different play-styles to combat them.

I want to briefly talk about the multiplayer here; although one can technically play any mission solo, it's very clear that many if not most of the higher difficulty missions are designed to be done with a squad of up to four. This has some drawbacks, but the game is undoubtedly well-balanced. Remote Play Together or  multiple inputs are also possible, allowing players to share the full game with friends who don't have it (assuming you can get them to play).
The DLC also doesn't segment the player-base, and players without it are not at a major disadvantage. 

Lastly, the graphics and sound effects are impressively smooth. I particularly love the sound and effect of the Scythe when it fires. It's a really juicy sound for a laser. Not sure how else to describe it.

TL;DR This game has a lot of character and is definitely worth picking up if you want something fun to sit back and play with friends or randoms. Just don't go jumping into the higher difficulties as new player without backup. I've seen many a decent new player accidentally splatter themselves on arena maps because they don't know what they're doing yet.

Helldivers is an isometric co-op shooter that will test the limits of your reactions and limits to your friendship!

The Good:
+Massive variety in guns, perks, artillery, vehicles, and cosmetics.
+Three different alien factions to subdue and bring DEMOCRACY!
+Gunplay is satisfying with enemies exploding into chunks of gore.
+The sheer chaos of a full lobby in a high level mission is something to experience.
+The entire presentation is a wonderful parody of a bunch of classic movies.

The Bad:
-Pretty much everything has to be unlocked. Levels and research is some of the worst to grind.
-Online play is an option, but it'll vary wildly on who you meet.
-The galactic war system gradually locks off enemies, which sucks if you just want to hunt some bugs.
-The locked camera is there to encourage team play, but there's no reason you shouldn't have your own.
-The late game effectively has you only invest in AP weapons.

Bottom Line:
Helldivers can be a ton of fun with ample challenges. It's getting old and there's less people online, which sadly is a huge component. I'm recommending the deluxe edition on sale, as well as having at least one buddy to play with for the best experience.

Helldivers is a great game from many points of view. 

It's basically impossible to play solo, except maybe on the absolute easiest difficulties, and so like it or not, you have to play co-op. 

The method by which it forces players to cooperate is by giving everyone the same view of the battlefield .. if the team doesn't move together you get deadlocked. You also can't see much around you at that point, although enemies [i]will[/i] see you. 

This is where it gets tricky, because incompetent teammates will be the death of you. Helldivers truly is a game in which only the strong survive. 

Friendly fire is active at all times. Players take a lot of damage from being run over by friendly vehicles, from mis-thrown grenades, and even defensive turrets. Players have to be responsible for individual sectors of fire, have to deploy defensive assets such that they won't do more harm than good, have to cover each other as they reload, and have to coordinate flawlessly against heavy enemies while the anti-tank player reloads. 

Patrols will sound the alarm when they find you, and ammo is limited, so the only way to survive is to stay as close to the centre of the screen as possible (so you can see as far as possible around you), be on alert, and take them out so quickly that they don't have time to raise the alarm. 

The wide variety of weapons, gear, and strategems is awesome, but the limited number any one individual can deploy once again forces teams to carefully work together in order to ensure that you have enough ammo, healing, vehicles, defences, or heavy weapons, depending on the enemy race, and mission difficulty.

This will not be everyone's cup of tea, but for those of us who like this sort of thing it's one of the few games which gets so many things [i]right[/i].

This game has the same issue a lot of other progression-based multiplayer games do: it has a community of die-hard fans with all of the unlocks who don't want to play with new people. Prepare to be kicked frequently simply for being a new player, or just autokilled when you spawn into a bunch of enemies and not revived.

+Good shooting gameplay with different weapon types which vary from damage, fire rate, spray/accuracy, magazine size to different ammo types i.e standard bullets or laser weapons which only need to be reloaded if overheated, allowing for essentially unlimited ammo if used properly
+The community war effort on 3 different fronts against 3 different races makes it easy and fun to switch between 3 different enemy playstyles whilst feeling like you're always contributing to progressing the war, every mission you complete and objectives completed within them contribute to advancing the front or defending territory
+Mini QTE-like mechanic for interacting with objectives/abilities leads to pretty intense moments trying to respawn other players by pressing the right key combination in the middle of combat
+Setting and soundtrack remimds me of starship troopers :) 
+Highly replayable with randomised missions with different objectives that can be completed. Made even more replayable with the option to have random weapons/equipment for each deployment, and there's lots to choose from.
+Great with friends and remote play makes it even more accessible and is a big plus as you technically only need one copy of the game to play with 3 other people, However if doing this, they will use your account progress in terms of unlocked items and upgrades, but they can still customise appearance etc. Also might drop in quality with lag or visual quality depending on internet as you're technically streaming your screen to the other players. Just be aware that friendly fire is always on!! Can lead to some annoying or funny times and is usually utter chaos with 4 people on higher difficulties

This game is fun save for one glaring issue.

There is a gun, the LAS-Sickle. Quite simply, it's one of the best guns for the following reasons:
1. When fully upgraded, it has pin-point accuracy. Compared to most weapons it's blatantly superior in almost every single respect due to the accuracy, and the next point.
2. Effectively infinite ammo. The simple fact that if the heat is managed effectively enough, you literally have unlimited ammo and never need to reload. This is a fact shared amongst all the LAS-series weapons.

The Sickle, it's not so much that it's too good imo, it's that some other weapons are too garbage to warrant mention in the same breath.

This game also has a design of enemies finding you, quite frankly, it seems okay at first, but then when you're soloing, it's the most aggravating thing in the world. Throughout the levels, there are patrols, these patrols are tiny and solely exist to detect you. Now this would be fine if stealth was an option but you can't even attack while prone, the perk for it simply doesn't exist, and honestly, it would make no sense that you'd need one. Shooting a gun while prone is, in fact, realistically easier and simpler than doing so while standing. There is no perk that causes your character to crouch down, becoming harder to spot unless sprinting, or hell. No perk that equips Camo of some kind, even a damn guille suit would be nice.

And patrols are basically everywhere, quite frankly only depending on your proximity to objectives, and there is no break in it unlike what the game supposes.

Not to also mention that the cursor on Mouse/Keyboard controls is mostly invisible unless aiming with right mouse button, making span-decisions really fucking hard if you can't fucking see your cursor because go fuck yourself on desert levels specifically, the game has a very bad readability problem with it.

Do I even need to start with how the enemies can "detect" you offscreen? Couple that with the fact that you are practically punished for playing in multiplayer by all players sharing the same goddamn screen, and congrats, you have a """fun""" horde-based twin-stick shooter to smash your dick with.

Drop pods? They land 70% of the time anywhere the beacon isn't, sometimes just directly on you and you may not even have any say in the matter.

I initially got this game because of a meme's comparisons between this game and Deep Rock Galactic.

Deep Rock Galactic is objectively far better in every single metric. Enemies just come at you, you don't have any patrols that summon literally 10x more enemies, drop pods drop on locations that is entirely predictable, All enemies can be defeated with only primary weapons if you really want and there is only one gun that sucks, while this game's weapons, half of them are bad. This game has a railgun that can't damage tanks, fuck off with that honestly. honestly the progression is also better than Helldivers.

I recommend Deep Rock, I've had more intense encounters, and more fun playing that than I have in my entire time of playing Helldivers, because everything doesn't knock you down so you take free damage, and all explosives don't kill you instantly.

Honestly the cursor point, drop pods being unreliable and the weapon balance being fixed would make this a helluva lot better, currently this is a game with vast potential, but it's designed like a Console game ported to PC as a half-assed effort, and honestly? I'd sooner recommend playing Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition for the PC without DSfix, you'll have more fun playing Blighttown at 5 FPS than this game overall.

I may only play this game, but only because it's better with friends in the way that you get to share in your collective misery, and that's not a good thing, even if it's a goal, because that should be a worrying sign that shit ain't alright from a developer's perspective.

Shared Masochism is a red flag, not a feature. While many confuse them all the time, there's a vast difference between a genuinely badly designed game and a really fucking difficult game.

Get Deep Rock Galactic instead. Or get Alien Swarm: Reactive Drop for literally free and have infinitely more fun.

[b]Helldiver is a twin stick shooter that combines gunning and cooperatively perfectly.[/b]

Helldiver gameplay as a twin stick shooter feels responsive. The smoke and bullet trace to the enemy animation made your gun have an impact when shooting them. What helldiver is famously known is for their difficulty. Friendly fire will always on, mech can kill your friend with two step, and even the escape shuttle can crush your whole teammate.

The game also have a stealth mechanic, in which you need to be careful of enemy patrol. If the patrol spotted you, they will call reinforcement. Their reinforcement is endless, which mean if more patrol spotted you, more alien will show up. 

You will play as a helldiver, your job is to protect your earth from three kind of alien that want to destroy the earth. The earth will be strike from three alien at the same time, so you need to think which one you should eliminate first from the war. If one of those alien get to earth and we failed to defend it, the war will be lost. The war is a community effort, which mean everybody help the invasion from the star they earned from mission. Higher difficulty give you more star which can make the war faster. What happen if the war ended? there will always a new one ;P

The game have a unique air support called strategems. Strategems can be the difference of life and death of your team, escpecially in higher difficulty. Strategems can call mech drop, drone, ammo, equipment, and even a nuke. When equipment strategems is called, it will drop a pod that will crush anything (your teammate also) on your marked area. While the airstrike strategems will fire anything on your marked area. I remember killing my teammate while he is riding a mech with an ammunition drop.

The critic I have is boring map and repetitive mission. The map seems to consist of dessert, snow, and jungle. Because each mission is about 10 minutes, you will get to see the same map and mission over and over again. So I hope they will add more map soon.

It also got local coop which is awesome. You can play with keyboard and your friend on controller.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]+ Real teamwork is needed
+Packed with lots of action
+Strategic thinking
- Boring map
- Mission feels repetitive
- Weapon needs a lot of balancing [/b]

After spending a little more time on this game I feel like I'm finally ready to give you my verdict. 
[hr][/hr]

[b]First Impressions Matter[/b]
If you want to start out in this game I highly recommend inviting a friend over for the proper co-op experience. There isn't a single game where I/we have had so much fun sucking at for the first few hours and I'm super glad I could share it!
Starting out, I don't think anyone will be good at this game and dying, failing and accidentally killing each other is both more fun and more forgiving when playing with someone else. While online multiplayer is great, it's a lot more satisfying to yell with and at the person next to you or return some IRL friendly fire. ;)

[b]Difficulty & Gameplay[/b]
As I've said, you WILL suck at this game for a bit, but don't let this discourage you. You do not NEED to be good to enjoy this title. In fact, I probably had the most fun when I was starting out and constantly screwing myself and teammates over.
In terms of challenge you won't be disappointed as mission difficulties range from "Your mom would survive that" to "OMG that's impossible!". [i](There's only a handful of people worldwide who can solo the hardest levels.)[/i]

Gameplay is easy enough to get into and feels great once you get the hang of it. For me a controller feels most natural, I mean... twin stick shooter, but kb&m is just as viable. Most people (90%) will just be playing the basic running and gunning, but for those interested, there are more advanced mechanics to master. 
Apart from the challenge of becoming a mechanical god at controlling your character, there is a great variety in enemy behavior you can study to become a master at manipulating the battlefield.

I cannot describe the gunplay without writing you an entire essay, so I won't [i](Yeah, I realize this review is going to be quite meaty already)[/i]
Let's just say this is no bullet hell shooter with some generic pew-pew. The main weapons already have plenty of variety and the fact that there's still discussions between veterans on what they like or think is weak or strong is testament to that. The combinations in primaries, special weapons and other strategems (kinda like airdropped abilities and/or gear) offer endless combinations in playstyles and anyone should be able to find some favorites. 

[b]Singleplayer & Coop[/b]
Like any game, the experience between single and multiplayer varies. 
Single player is more tense and less forgiving, but a great way to improve yourself. Remain in control of the game or die a terrible death, nothing beats the pressure and elation once you finally manage to overcome yourself on a hard-ass mission.

Multiplayer can either be super chaotic or efficient depending on your teammates and figuring out how to work together as a team (or survive despite your "team") adds another layer of depth and joy to the game. [i]Tip: add people you enjoy playing with to your friendslist; it's great to get used to eachothers playstyle and think up strategies together.[/i]
Coop works very well and while the playerbase isn't as large as it used to be, there are enough players around at all levels to either join their game or request their help in clearing your planet (low difficulty can be spotty as people move on from those rather quick and super new players might not know how to join you or just want to discover the game for themselves).

Overall I'd say we have a healthy community, both in random matchmaking and even more so in the Helldivers Discord[url=https://discord.com/invite/HELLDIVERS] [/url] with plenty of people willing to share their knowledge or even help out with missions or achievements. Apparently toxic players do exist, but they are no more than folklore to me.

[b]Progression[/b]
I quite like the progression in the game, although some aspects don't function as well at certain moments.
Helldivers is a SKILL based game and whether you can complete a mission has no relation to your level and is only partially determined by your gear; I'd say it's 30% gear, 70% skills and knowledge. [i](Sorry, had to be said as I feel like people are often focusing on the wrong things to blame)[/i]
[u]Level:[/u] Unlocks certain perks (like faster healing, lower strategem cooldown, etc.), weapons and armors (visual only).
[u]Research Points:[/u] Can be used to upgrade weapons and strategems, can be earned by leveling up and collecting samples on missions (1 sample = 1 extra research point after the mission).
[u]Strategems:[/u] You get a couple to start out with + whatever is included in the DLC you may or may not have bought. The rest needs to be unlocked as a reward for completing a planet (2-3 missions). Now this is where some complaints might rise. If you play in offline mode or you don't like doing multiplayer, it can be very difficult to clear high level planets to unlock certain strategems. 

Additionally, the game operates around a "Galactic Campaign"; think of an endless war with different stages. Before one war ends and another starts, either all alien races need to be defeated or Super Earth needs to fall. In the event where we lose the war, there isn't much of a problem since the event lasts for a maximum of 48 hours. However, to win a war, we need to defeat all 3 races, and that doesn't happen in one night. This means that one race may be defeated and you can't play missions against them to unlock new gear until the war comes to an end (which can take up to 2 weeks). Now there are workarounds to mitigate this issue, involving deleting the part of your savefiles where the campaign status is stored, but I know many people want a game to "just work".
For the most part this Campaign mechanic isn't a problem, but if you just bought the game when one race is being defeated you may be locked out of some content for a little while, which sucks. Unfortunately there isn't much to be done here other than playing offline, messing with savefiles, to take a break and return later for a proper fresh experience, or just deal with it for a bit and learn to play the other races first. :)

[b]DLC[/b]
I absolutely hate DLC and microtransactions and I think it's a shame Arrowhead opted for this model of releasing content.
That being said, I actually don't have a problem with this game's dlc. The way I see it, you should just consider whether the Digital Deluxe edition is worth your money and be done with it. (Pro tip: [b]IT IS![/b])

[h1] For Libertyyy![/h1]

- Campaign mode that means you only get somewhat advanced missions, even when you just start ? Check.
- Insta-downed if any enemy barely scratches you ? Check.
- Weapons that need 5 bullets to kill a basic trash mob (largely because the spread is so bad only 2 of them will actually hit) but only hold 30 or so ? Check.
- Equipment to summon on the fly by entering commands which force you to stay stationnary the whole time, so enemies WILL hit you ? Check.

I had an absolute blast with Magicka, from the same folks, and thought that the "you need to enter stuff on the fly" would not only be as well done, but also be as fun. Alas, in this game, it just gets you killed. You need to use the movement keys to input the commands, meaning you can't move at all while doing it. In a game where any scratch on your armor paint means you're downed.

DLC somewhat mitigates that, so the "pay to win" mech suit saved my rear end a few times. But it is indeed pay to win. About DLC, too, there are quite a few of them for "visual customization", and still you can barely notice any difference. Can't even change colours.

I do love twin stick shooters of all kind, and own a dozen of them, at least. Never thought I'd ask a refund on that one, but here we are. Even on sale, this piece of dung isn't worth your money. Maybe it's actually fun with friends, if you can tolerate the whole "Space 'Murica, nuking everything for freedom" cringy humor.

Not a single redeeming quality in this one. Even on sale, don't waste your money.

One of my favourite co-op games by far. Tons of weapon variety, ranging from simple small arms ballistics to orbital lasers. Tanks, APCs, mechs, motorbikes, airstrikes, napalm, artillery. You can throw together so many different combinations in your loadout that you can always change things around if you get bored of one play style. This is a busy game. It is loud, action packed, with lots of yelling, explosions and constant gunfire. At higher difficulties, you will be challenged and you will die. 
 Which brings me on to my second point. Friendly fire is permanently a feature. However, the community is small and tightly knit. You won't find many trolls or griefers in this game, but accidents do happen. Take it with a hint of humour and laugh when you get caught in the blast radius of a friendly nuclear warhead or when your ammo drop lands on an ally's head. If you can't cope with that, then this may not be the game for you.
 My third point is regarding DLC. The DLC for Helldivers expands it greatly. It contains a vast amount of weapons and equipment that adds so much diversity to the game. Certain DLCs are more useful than others, and I would very much encourage any new buyers to look on some forums to see which are your must-buys. On the plus side, the DLC packages are very cheap and well worth the content. But certain items such as snow shoes and the UAV are extremely useful and are not available in the core game. I'll say it again; check on some forums if you don't want to buy all the DLC. If you're going to just play the base game, I'd strongly recommend you avoid snow levels though, for your lack of snow shoes. 
 If you're looking for a fast paced, chaotic game with lots of action and humour, then definitely give this a try.

In Helldivers, you play as a titular Helldiver, an elite soldier in a team of up to 4. You are dropped from orbit into a variety of dangerous environments in order to purge xeno scum in a Starship Troopers esque setting using small arms, heavy ordinance and several items somewhere inbetween. Stellar sound design makes every weapon feel powerful and satisfying to use. This is 100% best played with other players as teamwork and specialised roles are essential for survival with specialised equipment with unique team uses not seen in other games are available. While friendly fire is extremely present and a major cause of death, teammates can easily revive you, making incidents very casual and easily brushed off. The matchmaking system works well and multiplayer games seem to be very stable.

While you drop with a primary weapon and backup sidearm, additional weaponry and support can be called in using the unique Stratagem system which is limited by either cooldowns or a single use per mission depending on what it is. Stratagems are called in by entering a combination of directional inputs, which is novel way of restricting the speed of calling in support as opposed to just having a time delay. More powerful Stratagems (heavy missile strikes, or tanks) have considerably more complicated inputs compared to weaker ones (light air support, or light bombardment). 

More weapons and cosmetics are unlocked via increasing your level using experience which is fairly quick if you take on higher difficulty missions and events. Different stratagems, slightly controversially are not always available to unlock as they are obtained from conquering planets which will be unavailable once the community as a whole has ammassed enough points to conquer it, removing it from rotation. This in theory may leave you lacking in particular aspects of your weaponry, such as a lack of  effective anti-tank or armor piercing weapons. I recommend buying the dlc (or deluxe edition) which will give many more options from the get go, although equally effective equipment can also be easily unlocked from low level planets.

One point I would put against the game is that the music selection seems limited and gets old quick. While triumphant military styled themes are thematically appropriate, I have found it to get boring quickly, although it's not to the point of being annoying. 

The level to level gameplay of Helldivers is extremely chaotic and enjoyable with situations capable of devolving from controlled and calculated to absolute carnage. The game seems to still have an active playerbase as I have encountered a mix of other new players to max rank veterans in matchmaking. I would definitely say it's good enough to justify paying full price for, but it does also seem to go on sale often.

Helldivers is from the makers of Magicka, and you can tell: it has the same four-player co-op arcadey destruction, where excess is the name of the game and accidentally killing your teammates is common.

It replaces Magicka’s lovely comedy fantasy with a boilerplate Starship Troopers skin, complete with obvious satire, but the narrative is a thin skin over what’s very much a multiplayer game. You and up to three teammates drop down into a mission with infinite enemies, complete your objectives ASAP, and get out.

It does an excellent job of keeping the tension up, and providing a good variety of top-down shooter combat. It’s easy to pick up, and there are worthwhile, game-changing unlocks.

It’s also highly repetitive, with limited enemy and location variety. How much you’ll enjoy Helldivers really depends on your playgroup, and their appetite for doing the same 15-minute mission over and over again.

That sounds more damning than I intend; it’s a good time, and one I’d happily play semi-regularly. It just is best suited to short, occasional bursts rather than dedicated play.
I wish they would make less DLCs and more base content, but the game is good and fun, I recommend.

Helldivers is a 1-4 player Co-op game that is brutally difficult but one of the best games I've ever played.
It can be played on both console and PC, i have played the most on console (Three hundred-ish hours), but got the game on PC to play it even more and to support the developers of this amazing game.

Co-op:
The Co-op is amazing, although you can play on your own, i highly recommend playing with other people, whether it be your friends or the very friendly community that surrounds this game.
The Co-op feels very meaningful, some weapons, vehicles and equipment requires you to work together perfectly, an example of this is the widely used anti-tank weapon, The Recoiless rifle, which can be reloaded with a support backpack. If you attempt to reload it on your own you are left vulnerable, hunched over on the ground trying to slide the rocket from your back into the weapon. Or, one of your friends could come up from behind and quickly slip the rocket in over your shoulder, reloading it instantly.

Unlocking equipment, perks and stratagems:
Every single thing that the game lets you use is very meaningful, NOTHING is bad, the only time a weapon is bad is when its used incorrectly.
I will say it does get a little tedious later on to level up and the game is not very beginner friendly, but once you get the hang of the game you will have hundreds of hours of endless fun.

Enemies, difficulty and community effort:
As the Helldivers, you are Super earths special ops military force, carrying out dangerous mission behind enemy lines.
The enemies you face are the Bugs, Illuminate and Cyborg.
All of these enemies have a patrol of some kind which will sound the alarm when they spot you, the only way to prevent this is by killing before they call for backup. Sometimes the enemies can be a bit buggy ,sometimes patrols spawn inside objects and their path-finding glitches out every so often, but it really isn't that big of an issue and isn't anything game breaking.
To defeat an enemy race, all helldivers must capture regions and push them back to their home world in a massive community effort, each planet you "liberate" accumulates influence, which helps fill up a bar which determines when an area is captured.
Your goal is to complete missions on planets until they are conquered, there are in total 15 difficulty levels, you will have a lot of trouble when you first play and you will have to stick to easier planets for a long time so that you build up enough skill to take on harder levels.
I personally would recommend practising for a while on difficulty 4 or 5 , because thats when the difficulty starts to spike drastically.

Conclusion:
This is an absolute gem and more people need to play it, this is the only game that I have ever played for this long and i would love to see more people playing it. This game doesn't waste your time with meaningless side quests or hours of waiting, this is simply get in and have fun.

So this game was an instant buy for me after seeing videos that reminded me of the top down team shooter "Alien Swarm" which I played for over 100 hours.  This game is a must for those who liked that game.
	Now, Helldivers is fun on both single and multiplayer mode for me.  For multiplayer, characters must work together since they are tied to the same screen.  Multiplayer can be incredibly fun, or incredibly annoying, depending on the teammates.
	The number of weapons, vehicles, and abilities (Strategems) that are include provide virtually all types of strategies and play-styles.  You want to move fast and avoid damage while using a jet-pack to further avoid damage?  Well, you can.  You love assault rifles and grenade launchers?  Grab 'em and party hardy, Marty.  The load-outs have a generous amount of variation, and trying new things out has been one of the best experiences in any game I've played.  The mechs, tanks, armored apcs (that all four players can ride in) are stellar examples of the vehicle play-style.
	Another very solid design choice was is setting up your gear so that you are always thinking of what to sacrifice in order to meet that sweet spot of player balance so that everything "feels" in sync. Again, the tactical strategy really pulls me in to this game.
	Older reviews appear to have gripes with a possibility of one or two of the three factions being locked while there is a campaign mode going on in the background.  This was leading to players being unable to fight against the faction they wanted until the campaign was resolved by the three factions being conquered.  I believe that would be very aggravating if still going on, but I haven't seen that issue as the devs appear have addressed this.
	One of the big questions for newer players is whether to get the dlc for the expanded items or not.  It is not required to own, but it makes for a much bigger variety of gear, so it has been a must for me personally.  Several dlc items are in my setup repertoire.  
	Another factor to the game which is really rewarding is mastering the different offensive weapons.  Reading several reviews, I've seen a lot of people that like a lot of different gear, and that really boosts the replayability.  So if you are not so locked into one style, you will really appreciate the work put in to change things up.
	With competent teammates, this game has been nothing less than stellar.  The thrill of victory has been very memorable in my gaming experience, and I am still getting into mid-tier rank and difficulty.
EDIT: So the lockout of certain races is still a thing with the campaign, but for me it forces me to get better at all the factions.  However, I see why this would aggravate a lot of people.

This game can be very fun for various reasons, 

 but ironically it's 'weak point' is the awkwardness of the controls, especially the 'strategems'.

 You have to constantly use your 'directional pad' to do 'strategems', 

 problem is that's very awkward, I wish they would've used the right hand buttons to do the strategems, that would've made things a lot more fluid.

 The game is very frantic, fast paced and 'fun', if you play with a full team and run around trying to do the missions etc, doing planet after planet.

 It, however, doesn't have that fluid smooth action feel that you'd expect from a typical twin-stick (i.e. Smash TV etc),

 so it's not as great as what you would expect if you play solo, which is very very unfortunate.

 It's a very good game, and extremely well put together, there's just 'something' missing though and a new 'redux' would probably be very well received, especially if they would have mainly 'shooting' missions,

 instead of constant non-shooting missions  (actually killing enemies missions are very rare in this game).

If that last point is hard to understand  (this confusion is why I first down-voted this game),

 it's because in this game shooting enemies is not actually what you 'think' you'd supposed to be doing, 

 it's more of a 'side-thing' you do just to get your missions done, which almost never include actually killing enemies.

 This is what ruins the massive potential this game had - this game isn't about shooting enemies, it's about doing missions (which almost never require shooting enemies) and the enemies you shoot just to keep yourself alive while doing missions.

Helldivers is a great game, but the online war campaign system should be optional, or unlocked after completing the main campaign. Whenever I introduce this game to a new friend it is extremely frustrating to get wedged into whatever the current meta campaign situation is, and often the missions are too difficult or we have too few mission options.

IMHO this game *NEEDS* a campaign that you can enjoy with your friends, like the awesome ones in Magica or like the one in Castle Crashers. If Helldivers had this, it would move from "instant classic" to "multiplayer legend".

My only other major gripe is restricting the players to the same screen real-estate. It is a bizarre design choice, and counterproductive in the long run.

The fact that Helldivers is still such a great game is a testament to the many strengths and the polish put into the final product. I want to give the game a thumbs up, but the campaign issues and lack of fresh story DLC mean that I really can't recommend it to friends.
