Helldivers is an unashamedly tongue-in-cheek about spreading liberty and democracy across the galaxy by instituting its brand of liberation on other worlds. To do this, you and up to three other players must take on enemies from the Cyborg (arctic robo-bros), Illuminate (blue alien people), and Bugs (bugs) as you spread the reach of humanity across the galaxy. Players must take caution as to avoid firing on each other in the process, which occurs a lot more often than other games due to the mandatory shared screen (even in online co-op).

A big draw to the game is the use of "stratagems," which provide you with a variety of offensive, defensive, and support items or attacks that can help you turn the tide or better equip yourselves for the upcoming fight. These are activated by radeoing in an arrow-key combination. The game also makes it very explicit that you should be careful with these call-ins since they may inadvertently hit (or land on, if it's a resupply call-in) other players.

The most frustrating parts are arguably the slow progression and quickly repetitive gameplay elements. Players who are adept with games in this genre while find it laughably easy at the start but must play through easier levels before they can access more difficult content. Additionally, equipment unlocks require the player to conquer planets from different factions, which can be a time consuming process. Since the state of the galaxy is shared across all players, once a faction is knocked-out, it's also unavailable for all players until the start of the next war.

I find a lot of joy in experimenting with different loadouts or tactics to tackle the challenges presented by the different objectives that are further augmented by how each faction provides a unique combination of difficulties for the player to overcome. Others that require more direction from the player in terms of how to challenge themselves will quickly find it boring.

Regardless, Arrowhead Game Studios has returned with just a lil' more content every time we celebrate Liberty Day, a holiday that occurs on October 26th. The last update provided a new gamemode with a new weapon, which adds a few hours (or more, if you're feeling adventurous) for returning players. Their dedication to this indie game dating back to 2015 is absolutely well-appreciated by me.

EDIT: The last update to this was in 2019, which occurred on Liberty Day (a fictitious in-universe holiday), adding a new difficulty for only the most dedicated.

A fun twin stick shooter that can offer hundreds of hours of fun, coordination and communication are critical, the experience is enhanced with friends, a factor that makes the game hilarious and tense most of the time.

[h1]Story[/h1]

We are heroes that fight to sprerd managed democracy across the galaxy, Super Earth is our home where all desicions are made, and the target of the three main enemy factions that threaten our way of life. To fight back we count with a great arsenal of weapons, bombs, and technology that will help us during our liberation missions, the enemy will either accept our terms or they can die trying to fight democracy.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Helldivers is a simple game, we have two weapons, main one being hard hitting experimental weapons, rifles, shotguns, smg's, etc, a whole arsenal. secondary weapons are pretty much that, a weapon that will help you to get rid of smaller threats when carrying an objective or when you are down. Every time we start a mission we can choose four stratagems that will be practical and a key element according to the situtation, enemy and environment, most of these stratagems can be unlocked whenever we attack a high level threat planet, either that or we get XP, that will vary as well, the harder the mission, the better the reward, in the end we will have a huge arsenal of new gadgets, bombs, nukes, air strikes of different kinds, shields, armors, vehicles, etc. making the game more intense and extreme when trying to call for a stratagem, making them a danger as they can drop on you or your friends, being careful is important, one member down and a simple mission can go wrong.

On our way to spread managed democracy, three enemies will show up eventually as we advanced on every planet and sector, the map will reveal new areas to invade and/or defend if the enemy is cunning or if our numbers dwindle on an especific zone and fail to liberate a planet, this will give you the chance to choose what faction to attack, Cyborgs, Bugs or Illuminate.

Cyborgs: They are known to be socialists, change their body parts to mechanical ones (hence the name) hating super earth and carrying out terrorist attacks to demonstrate that hate.

Bugs: They are pretty much like the zergs, they act like a swarm, they are not intelligent but in great numbers they are extremelly dangerous and fun to fight as they are really unpredictable.

Illuminate: They remind me of the Protoss, they are the more technologically advanced race of all three factions, even humans, and rely heavily on shields for protection.

Each and every of these factions have weaknesses and strengths, choosing the right stratagem may change the whole scenario and the outcome of a single mission, being prepared and coordinated with your companions is also key as they can also turn into the main danger, drop pods and friendly fire are usually the main reason helldivers die during missions, which leads to funny moments, raging and frustration.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

HD is not a demanding game, detailed where it has to be, some effects look great and the engine seems to do the job, many planets have different environments, forest, desert, volcanic, snow are the main settings, they may change a bit during daytime, dusk and nighttime, there is not much to add, HD runs smoothly and it's almost bug free, well optimized.  

[h1]Sound[/h1]

Besides gameplay, this is where HD shines, the music, the sound effects, the screams and orders from your companions, all of them create this tense sensation of being on the edge, calling for stratagems, reviving your mates, calling for them when they die, surrounded by countless enemies, making a mistake while calling for help and stratagems and the music keeps on adding more and more action to it, once all that is gone, everything returns to normal for a while, rest a bit, think the new tactic, call for ammo, resupply and continue, the music and environmental sounds will be there for you, the screams of your enemies will drown in explosions and bullets. Top notch sound.

[h1]The bad[/h1]

HD is filled with DLC's for this and that, unfortunately they did screw up by adding boots for different terrain as a DLC, absolutely unfair for people that just bought the standard edition, as they are a critical add-on for snow planets, like the home planet for the cyborgs, a terrible decision that cripples the gaming experience of those who don't have them, snow planets are harder for a reason, they make the soldier walk slower and be a sandbag for the team and those who do have them. Besides this, thegame is ok on every other direction.

[h1]Final words[/h1] 

I have probably had the best laughs playing a game ever, play with a friend or friends and the fun is neverending, even more when new players join your public game and usually the laughs intensify as many of them die unnecesarily, screw up while calling for stratagems or any other eventuality during missions, avoid most level 50's (max level in game) as they tend to be really bossy and think they know it all, they complain a lot and can't cope with frustration. Playing solo is not recommended IMO, try joining others and have fun. Totally recommended.

I took a randomized load out into a hosted game with people that I didn't know.  They weren't very good and kept dying.  My randomized load out was sub par.  We made it to the extraction point, and things started to fall apart due to a bug tank appearing, since we were already at high alert with the enemy bug force. I tried to carefully aim the drop point on top of the tank while helping the other remaining squad member run circles around the bug to keep it somewhat stationary.  It moved just a bit at the last second, but the front tire of the motorcycle still landed squarely enough to take out the bug tank.  I wasn't even sure that it was going to work, but it was awesome and hilarious!  We called in a respawn for the two dead guys and were able to survive long enough to extract on the shuttle.

[h1]93 / 100[/h1]

[i][b]Arrowhead Game Studios[/b] are no strangers to the top down twin-stick shooter genre. Where I found Magicka's complex spell combos to be somewhat overwhelming & Gauntlet's authentic gameplay, although loads of fun, to become dullish over time, I found [b]Helldivers[/b] to hit that sweet spot between the two, while offering a much different sci-fi experience.[/i]

[b]Helldivers[/b] has a VERY strong Starship Trooper vibe, but it is used to good effect; while clearly taking its own unique creative queues. As a Helldiver, you are out to protect humanity from all manner of hideous alien species, in all the hostile planets around the galaxy. Each mission is randomly generated, offering different goals and layouts each playthrough. Along with this, there is also a number of different specific scenarios including some challenging boss fights in the late game plus a whopping 12 difficulty levels to choose from!
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=590753025
In conjunction with the design choices & combination of mechanics used, [b]Helldivers[/b] offers up some intense coop gameplay, that actually encourages team work. Design dictating behaviour; It is nice to see a commendation/reporting option built in to encourage the community to govern itself against troublesome players. The coop/team work/community focus is strong throughout.

Levels being objective based, have tasks like bomb disposal, arming a missile silo, blowing up an alien hive or recover an important item. Each almost always requires team work to complete the task &/or to provide defensive cover. You also need to share ammo and supplies to best survive harder incursions.

Many of the objectives also require you to input a series of directional presses in sequence and without mistakes to progress. These start off easy but get quite long in harder levels, increasing the pressure & punishing mistakes harshly. This combo mechanic is also used when calling down your personal [b]Stratagems[/b] [i](re-enforcement orbital drops)[/i]. It is fundamental to the gameplay experience, and used in perfect balance with the shooter/action aspects of the game. 

[b]Friendly fire is ON![/b] One of the other key mechanics vital to the experience is friendly fire. Normally, unless playing with friends this can lead to frustration in online gameplay, actually turned out to be an absolute BLAST [i]*pun intended*[/i], offering up some of the most hilarious, calamitous failures & occasional epic recoveries I've seen. Lot of laugh-out-loud moments, such as the inevitable time when your team mate drops a reinforcement [b]Stratagem[/b] to revive your dead Helldiver, only to have the capsule kill them on your decent!

Surviving your team mates can sometimes be harder than the aliens :)

Controls via controller are responsive, precise & there are some challenging achievements to acquire on the side.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=602360106
Another impressive element of [b]Helldivers[/b] is the great customisation over your loadouts, each offering something different, but well balanced in a way not to have a go-to loadout. This encourages experimentation, keeps things fresh & used as a reward/unlock mechanic as you level up. The DLCs offer a much wider range of weapons & outfits to choose from, not required by any means, or offering any distinct advantage, but would recommend picking up the [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/aussiedroid/recommended/396172/]Terrain Specialist Pack DLC[/url] with the 'Snow Shoes' as that is necessary in the Arctic scenarios. Working with your team mates' loadouts can greatly enhance your survivability & becomes crucial on harder difficulties.

The Mechs you can pilot are fantastic carnage inducing fun too!

Aside from the high quality, detailed animations & environments, there are three alien species change up your strategies, all performing very differently from each other. My favourites are the Bugs, perhaps it’s the throwback to Starship Troopers, but I do find them the most fun to play against. Cyborgs get on my nerves with some of the blocking mechanics used & swarms of Illuminate can be hard. 

These alien species are tied into a rather unique community feature where there is a War fought by all players in the Helldiver Community. Each mission success accumulatively counts points towards victories against the three different alien species, ultimately leading to a campaign to conquer their homeworlds. If players do not work together & push the aliens back, then they can overtake our homeworld. I really like the way this works, offering something to keep you loading the game back up on a regular basis, but it does unfortunately have one limitation in that it can prevent you from being able to play against some of the alien species at some points in the war. 

You may log in and find you can only fight Cyborgs for example, which can continue for many days!
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=598177503
With all the variety in the levels, objectives, weapons & aliens coupled with the solid team oriented mechanics there is a lot of replayability to be had for the money, but ultimately as you progress to the top levels, seen a few wars & have everything unlocked the experience can become repetitive. Levels generally play out with similar tactics outside of the core scenario changes.

With such solid foundation & super fun gameplay overall, I would love to see content expanded for veteran & new players alike. More map variety [i](towns/cities/underground/night)[/i], more level modes/sizes [i](A-B survival runs, stealth runs, vehicle only levels, multiphase missions, many more objective types)[/i], more aliens or some sort of a game-plus mode or campaigns. Perhaps in a Helldivers 2: Search for More Democracy?

Although at time of writing this the online community [i](over a year since release)[/i] is still active, I have also unfortunately experienced many an issue connecting to games over my time playing. Does work 90% of the time, but some will simply not connect & dump you back at your ship. When it does connect, the game performs well.

Best played with friends, [b]Helldivers[/b] is well worth a look for any fan of coop games or twin stick shooters.

For Humanity, & most important of all .. [b]For Democracy!![/b]

Presentation: 9/10  The Bitsquid Engine fits the top down perspective of HELLDIVERS extremely well.
Characters and assets have a fairly high resolution to them, but at display resolutions like UHD (3840 x 2160p) and 4K (4096 x 2160p) they can appear a bit blurry.
The sound design is amazing. 
Weapon sounds have a real punch to them and the soundtrack is mesmerizing and changes depending on the difficulty or the enemy faction you're fighting against.


Gameplay: 10/10  HELLDIVERS is a top down shooter, you can play either solo or with 3 friends/strangers (don't play solo you WILL die).
As a Helldiver from Super Earth you have access to stratagems, you can call down via airdrop.
These stratagems range from supplies and light machine guns to airstrikes and mini nuclear strikes.
You fight aginst 3 factions: Bugs, Cyborgs and the Illuminate.
Each faction has different enemy types and attack patterns e.g. Bugs use heavy armored units, Cyborgs use heavy armored tanks and Illuminate use low armored units with shields (all depending on difficulty).
HELLDIVERS has a difficulty system that goes from 1 - 15.
1 = so easy that it's getting boring real quick
5 = nice but still easy challenge
10 = a real pain in the A**
15 = suicide sounds tempting
Special mention: you can play this game with 4 people in local coop on one pc with any combination e.g. 4 controllers or 3 controllers and one player uses mouse and keyboard.


Story: 4/10  There is a bit lore and additional informations for those who want it, but story informations are completely optional.
The main focus of the game is gameplay.


Conclusion: 24/30  Enlist today and join the vast forces of Super Earth.

HELLDIVERS brings true DEMOCRACY to your very own fingertips as you spread some god damn Freedom and advertise liber-tea across the whole galaxy! 

The game is absolutely amazing to play, for such an "old" game, the game has a relatively active fan-base and for once in a co-op multiplayer game such as this, going into missions with randoms is actually a viable strategy as the community is actually extremely friendly and teamwork is butter smooth all 'round.

Older players often join newer players and help them out and newer players listen to older players when they try to help, it's a very wonderful sight and a very very welcome breath of pure air among all these toxic games nowadays.

The community in this game has just ascended to the heavens and become practically angels, and the gameplay of the game is equally as good, randomly generated objectives and plenty of choices in planets/environments/enemies makes you able to enjoy the game for hours on end without even taking a break!

The game has 3 main enemy races, "The Illuminate", "Cyborgs" and "Bugs". Or as I like to call them "Illuminati", "stormtroopers" and "holy fuck why is there so many tanks"
Each race has their own unique strenghts and weaknesses that the HELLDIVER arsenal has its own answers for, game progression is reliant on your own efforts and your own pace instead of a leveling system. Every level you get unlocks extra level specific weapons and items, along with letting you go into higher level planets (probably to prevent level 1 karens from going to difficulty 15 as their first mission and then blowing their ass off fuming to the manager how the mission didn't feel like the tutorial)

Every planet(mission) you accomplish either gives you a difficulty specific XP bonus toward your player level or unlocks a new armament directly reflecting the difficulty of what you just completed. Higher difficulty = Better gear unlocks.

Some of the DLCs for the game could be considered somewhat "pay to win" as you get some very OP gear right off the bat by simply buying all the DLC content, and even some(very few) of the non-DLC alternatives you unlock later on in the game aren't as good as the DLC variants which is a bit of a shame.

Overall the game performs outstandingly, with an amazingly lovable community, great gameplay, near endless replayability, very fun mechanics combined with great humor in dialogue makes for a very very good game well worth your money.
Deluxe edition is recommended as it gives you all DLC at the same time.

There is so much to like in this game, but there are three major negatives that FAR outweigh the positives, in my opinion. This is a real shame, because the game CAN be a lot of fun to play. Overall, the game is a fun, squad-based game, IF YOU PLAY WITH OTHERS.

[b]Problem number 1: There are no AI players provided to fill your roster, which seems awfully short-sighted and lazy on the part of the developers.[/b] Lots of people like to play on their own or at times their friends are not online. Most of the lower-difficulty missions can be accomplished solo, but once you get into the harder missions, there are a lot "defend this" and "escort that" missions that are a real challenge without another player or two to cover other angles. Working together with other players and accomplishing the goals is satisfying, but a game this expensive should have the option to fill your squad with AI.

[b]Problem number 2: you have no control over where in the galaxy you play, or which enemy race you go to war with or attack.[/b] You are stuck in a world(galaxy?)-wide war that you cannot adjust to your own tastes, or affect in any meaningful way without playing the hardest missions where you keep getting your controls spammed so you can't control your avatar (more on that later). I've played for nearly 30 hours at this point, and I've only faced one of the three races. There's not even different servers you can log into set at different difficulties or different stages of the war. There is one login and one war. If that race of aliens everyone else is fighting isn't to your taste, too bad.

[b]Problem number 3: I have found the game is impossible on higher levels, thanks to one of the most tired and difficult video game tropes out there, the "all your controls are backwards", which the game developers thought would be a lot of fun to spam players with relentlessly at higher difficulties.[/b] I would just like to know if anyone, anywhere actually thinks having your controls flipped on you in the middle of a video game is fun? Has anyone ever had this happen and thought, "Man, I love running the wrong direction while having my guy get shot by 10 tanks. It's really great that I can't dodge or aim or control my character at all, since my controls keep switching back-and-forth. It's even better that the enemies that change my controls are coming at me in waves of 10! Oh! And now 5 flying guys with cloaks and shields are coming that do the same thing! Hu-freaking-zzah!"

Seriously, the developers need to patch that ability completely out of the game. I bet none of the developers actually play-tested that feature and thought it was fun. It's challenging, for sure, but that is not the first and most important attribute of a game. Games are supposed to be fun first, then challenging in a fun way. There is nothing remotely fun about playing this game on the hard levels and getting blown-up while running around like a chicken with your head cut off, because your controls keep flipping on the X and Y axis.

Seriously, that last problem alone is enough reason to stay as far away from this game as you possibly can.

This game is good, really good, on all fronts except one: community driven progress. You can't simply go online with your friends and fight from where you left off last time. Instead, the game has three factions that are fought by the entire community. Naturally, some factions are preferred over others, resulting in the same faction often being left over.

It happened on multiple occasions that we went online and were locked out of 80% of the game, because it was the end of the war (the community-driven progression). This can easily happen 100% of your play time, if you're unlucky enough to log in at the end of the war. That's not what I consider fun, and it makes it a -really- poor game for people that cannot log in often enough to see all the variety the game has to offer.

It spoils this otherwise great game completely, and makes my friend and I choose other games over this one. Such a shame.

Should this ever be changed, this review will be changed into a recommended, but as is, I would say spend your money elsewhere.

Ehhh. It's okay, but it left me wanting a LOT more. Enough to not really enjoy playing. There are some things that are only surface level, like the lore and intel. 
As a whole, I don't really recommend this game unless you REALLY want it. I can't think of anything else out there quite like it, so I can see why some people SHOULD play this. It has some great parts and mechanics, but it feels like it could not only have been done much better and fleshed out, but could STILL be greatly improved today, with just a FEW things, yet they haven't been fixed in all the years since launch.
IF you do buy it, get it on sale.

As for the game itself:
It leaves me wanting more, in a bad way. It feels like the gameplay itself is slightly incomplete, the lore is very barebones (not inherently bad, but they way it is presented makes it feel like there is supposed to be a good bit more), and some design choices are just BAD. It lacks polish in SOME areas, but in others it feels incomplete on a fundamental level.
1. It feels a bit clunky to control. That might be intended and be part of the challenge, but something feels off about it.
Part of it doesn't even involve the movement. For example, using the minimap radar: it doesn't REALLY update when it looks like it should, based on how frequently the pings go out. Dead bodies stay on the radar for several seconds (and it's not because they haven't despawned yet. They stop appearing on radar long before they despawn), enemies' positions don't actually update when the ping goes out. I mean it would be fine if they told me "the radar can only give us a general sense of where the enemies are" or if the pings would only show up when it ACTUALLY updates, but instead it feels very out of sync, and shoddy.
2. Graphics leave me wanting more. I'm not a graphics snob, by any means. And I understand that it has to be limited so that the console version can play smoothly.
I don't want it to be higher res or better textures for the sake of it. But SOME things feel way too flat, and almost look bland. That might be more of an art direction issue I have, rather than graphics. The Helldiver's faction specifically. Which is a big problem since that's who you play as.
I still go have issues with the actual graphics though. It looks like things clip through each other some times, and some things looks very cheap and uninspired. Like the drop pods despawning is just them sinking into the ground. Fair enough. But it just looks cheap.
3. The upgrade system is not good. You can upgrade pieces of your equipment with research points. I won't get into getting those points, because I think it's fine. The upgrades themselves aren't JUST stat boosts, like increased magazine size, or damage. Sometimes it changes how the equipment behaves, like making it go from semi-automatic to burst fire, adding a machine gun to the sidecar on the motor-trike, making projectiles penetrate enemies, making projectiles briefly stun enemies, making projectiles armor piercing, etc. That is GREAT.
The problem is, that not all of the upgrades are exclusively beneficial, but you can't toggle upgrades on and off between missions, without resetting ALL of your progress. Penetrating through enemies is great to deal with hordes and increases ammo efficiency, but if you are going to do a mission in a small arena, it's not so great if you have to shoot something in between yourself and an ally. I don't have a problem with friendly fire, or having to be careful with aim and such. But for crying out loud, let me choose to remove some upgrades if I want to. This punishes experimentation in my opinion. For example, I will never get the tighter spread upgrade on my Punisher shotgun. It might be GREAT! But maybe I don't like it, and want to go back to a slightly wider spread. Well to bad, I'll never know which one I'll like, because I can't go back if I don't like the change, and right now, the gun is "good enough."
3. Some BS. Semi-graphics things that directly impact gameplay, like cyberdogs often being partially in the ground as they run, from just their paws, up to the tips of their ears. It seems like they run on a flat plane set at the lowest point of the ground elevation. They don't change elevation with the ground, but everything else does. It impacts gameplay because you can't always easily see the cyberdogs as they charge at you, even when they are directly in front of you. It also makes it slightly harder to shoot them if you DO see them in time.
It's so confusing why this happens, because everything else at least loosely follows the terrain elevation, and it sticks out as a really glaring bug that hasn't been addressed in the many years since this game released. Why?
4. It's online only. I regret purchasing this game even if for that alone. It doesn't try to hide it, I've just come to dislike that model a lot since I bought this, for unrelated reasons. As far as I am aware of, they have no end of life plans for this game.

It feels like if you got a BIG wrapped gift you've been told (for whatever reason) is a LEGO set, and you can tell there was a lot of effort put into making it look perfect when wrapped (Idk, like clean folds, symmetrical, lined up patterns, hand tied ribbon bow), but when you open it, there is only a single main line BIONICLE set inside.
BIONICLE is great! But why did you make it look so much bigger than it actually is? Why did you go through so much effort to do that?
I'd have been fine if it was wrapped in the size of the actual product, but you set expectations, and failed to meet them, and I'm still disappointed about that, no matter how good the actual product is.

Perhaps a better analogy would be that meme image of the pepperoni pizza box with the little window so you can see a small section of the pizza inside with the pepperoni, but when opened, the only pepperoni on the whole pizza is what was under that window. I mean... the pepperoni is there... and it IS a complete pizza... but they didn't follow through with the pepperoni like they set it up.

The biggest issue is the camera. Have you played a recent Mario game with multiple players playing at once, where you can get stuck against the screen edge and killed? I gather they wanted to force you to group with your squad, but I'd greatly prefer each player had separate cameras, and it was game mechanics encouraging being close.

Also problematic is that enemies just spawn around you on missions. Not spawning at a significant distance, but quite near the edge of vision or even visibly. This gives the game a cheesy feel, and means that the workable tactics are quite limited compared to what you might expect based on the theme.

I've never seen a game so totally derailed by a single weak mechanic.

The basic gameplay is very good - it's a great co-op action game with friendly fire that really makes the friendly fire, well, friendly. The trouble is that the game disables large mission categories if the total playerbase is too successful at those missions. Nearly every time I have played this game, 2/3 of the missions are disabled, and worse, it's the same 2/3, because the remaining 1/3 of missions are not nearly as fun as the other 2/3 so players just simply put the game down when it's down to those missions. This is frustrating for veteran players and is a hard-pass for newer players. The situation has, if anything, gotten worse over time, because the gap in player preference - and the speed at which the 2/3 get exhausted - has accelerated with the matured playerbase.

This whole thing could be trivially fixed by either not disabling those missions or having a local campaign mode, but the chances of this menu-level fix being implemented at this point in the game's history is basically null. The game is in virtually every other way more appealing to me than Magicka, but after nearly 100 hours this one anti-feature has sent the whole thing tumbling down.

I bought this game looking for a new co-op game to play with my friends and hoo boy, it did not disappoint. I honestly didn't expect to like this game as much as I do, but the humor, the emphasis on teamwork, and the replayability got me hooked.

I didn't expect it to be as tactical as it is. With friendly fire, limited ammo, the bountiful number of strategems, and sharing one screen you have to have good communication and teamwork to get through some the harder missions and choose your loadouts based on the enemies that you are fighting. Strategems are pretty much an air drop that is on a cool down that you can customize in your loadout and really bring a nice variety to the game.

The gun sounds are punchy and satisfying, the shadows look nice, and the gore is brutal and hilarious. You will end up dying a lot in a lot of ways, but almost every time it's easy to brush off, because of how over the top everything is.

Now as much as I like the game, one thing bothers me about it and that's the Galactic Campaign. As you will see on a lot of other reviews on here, the main campaign is a co-operative effort of all the players online and if one of the enemies is defeated, then they are not playable until the next war. Now I get what the devs were going for with this to give a greater sense of community, but it kinda sucks when you end up being able to only fight one race for a little while. Hopefully they'll maybe adjust the system in the future, but I totally get why that could turn someone off to continuing to play the game. The game is still alive with a lot of dedicated long time players and a lot of new players from a recent sale so you can almost find someone to play with. I don't really know how to end this review so I'm gonna hit you with a tldr in a second.


[u]TLDR[/u]

[i]Pros:[/i] Great game to play with friends and online strangers that will test your teamwork, great humor, active community, and nice gore/graphics.

[i]Cons:[/i] Campaign system is flawed to where sometimes you can only fight one race of enemies, very difficult to solo endgame difficulties, and the DLC is almost necessary if you don't want some things to be annoying.

+ Enemy diversity*.  Each faction requires different tactics to fight against and have enough variety that one loadout is ideal for everything, especially in higher difficulties
+ Cups of liber-tea!

Cons:
- Enemy diversity.  In both categories because after a faction is defeated, it can't be fought against again until the next war and not all factions are available to fight at the beginning of a war.  Haven't played the new random mode, so maybe this isn't a con anymore.
- Enemy spawn mechanics.  I'm not a fan of having all enemies up to and including tanks literally spawn on top of me(spawn itself won't kill you, but as soon as tank moves, you're squished)
- Very grindy after the first couple dozen character ranks.  Not a big deal as everything past 24 is cosmetic, anyway.
- Implying that democracies are best when constitutional republics are clearly superior.

All in all, highly recommend, especially on sale or if you have a couple friends to play with.  Remember, friends don't let friends dive drunk.

It's a simple game with simple mechanics, but the way they interact is where the meat of the game is. You can play the game with friends or jump into random matches either is fun. If you want to play the harder missions you're going to have to unlock the upgrades for stuff.

FOR NEW PLAYERS:

Collect samples. To make this easier, I would recommend picking up the Ranger Pack DLC. This will give you access to the 'Humblebee' UAV drone. Use the samples (those little shiny yellow things you will randomly find on the ground around the maps) to upgrade your UAV first (it's near the bottom of the "Stratagems" tab). This will make it infinitely quicker to find samples. It also allows you to run easier missions (Levels 1-4) by yourself and pick them up so you can upgrade your weapons.

If you're a numpty like me, you'll be wondering where all your weapons are. Well, as it turns out, on the loadout screen you can hover over the weapon and towards the edges of the box, arrows will appear. Depending on your unlocks and the DLCs you've purchased, you can cycle through the weapons you own. I didn't learn this until about 30 hours in, lol. I was basically running around with the MG-105 'Stalwart' from the Demolitionist Equipment Kit (another of the paid DLCs) for that time, and I loved every second of it. I only switched away for the last 20 hours (I have 50 hours played at the time of writing this) so I could try the different weapons and upgrade them.

Different weapons are better suited for different maps/environments and enemies, so do not be fooled into thinking you can run with one load out. To maximise you and your team's chances of winning, you'll need to pay attention to where you're going and who you're fighting. 

You will learn through experience, you will learn by failing, but even in the most frustrating moments, you will be having fun :).

Also, newbies, if you're playing with M&KB want to aim I would recommend the old aiming system where when you right click to bring up the cross hair, it appears next to your character and you 'draw a bead' out to your target. The 'always on' system is a bit of a misnomer as while the cross hair is 'technically' always on, it is blurred out until you right click to make it visible. This means you can lose track of it on your screen and can cost you vital seconds reorienting your self. Stick with the old system. It's far better. Trust me.

Certainly among the best and versatile coop/couch-coop games out there. After a few years, there still has to appear a title that would top overall package delivered by Helldivers. Best thing about it is certainly its appeal to both very casual and serious players. For the former, it offers low barrier of entry, intuitive gameplay and hot-drop-in couch (and remote)-coop functionality. For the latter, the increasingly challenging missions and unlocks provide for hours of group or solo fun.

There is one huge drawback to the game, though, and it has to do partially with steam limitations. Namely, when playing couch mode (on one machine), it's not possible to track progress on multiple accounts. This also means numerous annoyances as the game processes the same rewards four times for the same account. The per-mission stats are accurate, but overall, if you want to progress together, you need multiple machines.

Helldivers is, without a doubt, one of the most unusual and fun experiences that I've ever had in a video game. Although I wish there was more to it; some proper endgame, more complex progression, more stuff to customize your characters, etc., I still have to give credit where credit is due - even after all these years, the game still lives and the devs even bother to release new updates from time to time.
[list]
[*]Overview
Helldivers is a 1-4 coop top-down shooter, with a rather unique mechanic (inherent only to Arrowhead games) of using your "special abilities," which involves you typing in a specific series of inputs form your keyboard. The game itself is based in a semi-serious, semi-comical and grotesque universe, that can make the experience simultaneously immersive, engaging, badass AND funny as hell. It's definitely more enjoyable to play it with friends, since the game doesn't really give you any quarter for playing solo, but it also has more than enough difficulty levels for you to pick the challenge that suits you best.
[*]Story
Naturally, there's isn't much of a [i]story[/i] to speak of here, but rather - the setting itself. And it's essentially a combination of Starship Troopers, a bit of WH40k and a little bit of something unique. You are a Helldiver, an elite soldier that usually arrives on a battlefield in a drop-pod (who said SPEHSS MAHREENS?!), constantly wearing a badass cape and carrying some big gun. Your objective is to deliver democracy to any alien, mutant or [strike]heretic[/strike] communist, wherever they might hide. All of it is done for the glory and continued supremacy of Super Earth!
Your opponents consist of tyranid/zerg/starship trooper-like bugs, cyborgs and technologically advanced aliens - the illuminates. They get in constant wars with humanity and it is up to you to clear out entire sectors, planet after planet, while also completing some different objectives that are randomly spawned for each mission.
[*]Gameplay
Helldivers provides rather fast-paced, fun, and surprisingly strategic gameplay. While you do spend most of your time simply shooting hordes of enemies full of bullets, you also have access to a plethora of different stratagems that you can call in from orbit, which involve consumables, heavy weaponry, defensive structures, powerful fire support and even vehicles. Your loadout is pretty limited, and you should constantly adjust it accordingly, since missions can have different conditions/enemies/objectives that require a specific approach. You should also coordinate your loadouts with your teammates, distributing the vital roles (ammo supply, support items like jetpacks or shields, heavy fire support, etc.) between yourself. Suffice to say, the higher the game's difficulty gets, the more unforgiving this experience gets, making you approach the game more methodically, rather than just running forward, guns blazing. Oh, and keep in mind that there's friendly fire in this game before calling in a nuke on your teammates' unsuspecting heads.
The game's progression consists of unlocking new weapons and upgrades for them, as well as some new perks and cosmetics. Sadly, that's all there is, and you'll most likely unlock the most vital weapons and stratagems that you're going to use most rather quickly. And since there's no legit endgame to speak of, you will have to find your own entertainment much earlier than it should've been.
[*]Graphics
Since the game originally came from PlayStation and it can be considered old by now, naturally, the graphics are impressive. They do the trick just fine, though. The visual style is somewhat cartoonish and simplistic, and quite gory, actually. The visual effects are pretty dope - the weapons, stratagems both look visually appealing; the models of characters, vehicles and enemies also look pretty solid. And luckily, the optimization is pretty nice even with total carnage happening on screen.
[*]Sound
The sound design is good - voice acting is dope, all enemies have distinct sounds, all weapons and stratagems have solid sound effects. As for the soundtrack - I would say it's pretty badass, setting the mood perfectly.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Helldivers is a fun, challenging and straightforward coop experience. It provides and amazing and fast-paced action that one would expect from a top-down shooter, and adds a level of skill-demanding strategic approach to it, that rewards quick reflexes an ability to adapt on the run. The setting only helps by gratuitous levels of badassery and a nice hint of comedy, that makes the overall experience pretty well balanced and enjoyable. The only real drawback this game has is that it doesn't last long - the amount of content leaves a lot to be desired, and the lack of proper endgame makes the player bored way too quick.
7/10; worth trying, especially with friends.

Combining the level up system, multiple weapons with customisations, perks, upgradeable stratagems, vehicles, planets, and their different biomes, cooperative play, and the game's system in which everyone from around the world works together to take control of the galaxy one section at a time. Speaking of which many are locked behind DLC - yes you can play it without, but you're missing out on most of the unique (and powerful options like  healing drone) and direct upgrades to better guns in every way.  Unlocking perks and upgrading equipment is a lot of fun but it's also a bit of a grind, at the beginning it feels very unfair as you get fsking deleted and all your starting stuff is garbage.

It is intended to be a team game and is a lot of fun with friends  but friendly fire is a bit of a concern in random pub.  Plus your character is so slow at everything and the mandatory single screen per team means it gets chaotic and death is incredibly easy if everyone doesn't know what they're doing, where and when.  Comms are very limited and really need to use voice chat.

On bad points, the blimming invisible cursor really annoys me (the community voted for this!?) as you can't fire properly unless you aim, but you can't move well if you aim.  Oh, it also takes half a second to appear once you start aiming.  If you know where it is in the chaos.  All your weapons are ineffective if spammed, which you will need to do if on your own and surrounded.  Also you can get downed and headstomped while you bleed out.  Your own weapons can and will kill you, as well as anything the aliens or your comrades do to you.  Worst of all, INFINITE enemy spawns, and if you eff up killing watchers, more troops, more watcher will spawn which will spawn more enemies, which will spawn MORE enemies.  Did I mention you have limited ammo, looong stun on you being hit and reloads take forever?  Weapon swap is slow and call-ins are also very slow (120s) and/or limited (1 per mission).  It is intended to be a team game, with you backing up your team and them helping you with cover and support through combined arms and synergies.  It's almost impossible on your own as your loadout is a primary weapon, perk (can replace secondary pistol with DLC), and four call-ins such as heavy weapons, airstrikes, vehicles, defences and special equipment.  So you have to make compromises on your own - do you lose mobility, offence, defence or supplies?  In a team you would have multiple weapons in several roles (support, long range, point) and up to 16 special options (stratagems).

Tough as nails and vicious, I recommend playing with friends or open up your A-game for solo because you will have your ass handed to you.  Or join pub and enjoy the furious action, just be warned in good team you will dominate, but in a bad team failure is common.  You will also get kicked for being a noob or doing stupid things, read the guides.  Worthwhile on sale, make sure you get the DLC to get the cool toys.

HELLDIVERS


General:

Rating: T 
Price: $19.99
Genre: Twin-Stick Shooter, Action
Time played: (Playstation 4) 40 + hours, (PC) 59.6 hours


A top down twin stick shooter that encourages multiplayer. Plenty of fun running around slaughtering aliens to further the cause of SUPER EARTH.


Gameplay - 10

A twin stick shooter that allows you to ‘accidentally’ kill your friends.  You can use Stratagems which drop ‘hellpods’ with equipment, weapons whatever you need to complete your mission. And you will need them.  The enemies are endless, if you don’t clear them out fast enough, they will just keep coming and coming and coming. You can customize your HELLDIVER, yes you have to say it loudly each time, by changing their outfit or the cape. The cape seems..silly until you finish your first level 12 mission and earn your ‘species’ cape.  Then they’re like pokemon. 

On to the actual game though, you pick a mission and then have to land on a planet and finish the objectives. They range from finding survivors and escorting them to killing a certain number of enemies, to unpacking “truth” transmitters.  You cannot leave until the objectives are completed, or attempted and failed. Enemies will send out patrols, if you don’t kill them quick enough they will set off an alarm; which alerts others to show up and can make for a bad day. 

I mostly played solo, I learned early on that you can’t fight them all, i spent a lot of time running for my life and waiting on my Stratagems to go through their cooldown period so I can call in more ammo for my guns. If you move far enough away the enemies will stop pursuing you.  Thankfully.

 Once you finish them all you can call in the shuttle to take you off planet.   Of course it’s not gonna come down right away. You have to ‘defend’ the area for 1 minute and 30 seconds.  That’s pretty easy right?  Not always.  The enemy will start spawning in right away, and you can’t run away now. You have to stay and defend the landing area.  If you manage to make it onto the shuttle and get off planet, don’t get crushed by the shuttle as it lands, you’ll be rewarded based on your performance. Which of course gets loaded up to SUPER EARTH. When you finish an entire mission, you will get rewarded with new Stratagems, all helpful, but possibly deadly if you use them wrong. 

Story - 5 

There’s not much of a story here; Super Earth is ‘threatened’ by outside forces and it’s up to the HELLDIVERS to take the war to the enemy and win it all for Super Earth. You know to ‘protect our way of life’. The story could be better, but it’s really not needed; you’re just gonna kill everything/everyone you see. 

Graphics - 10 
Great graphics, no real complaints.  When you kill a big Bug with a rocket launcher, if you’re not running for your life, take a moment and appreciate the way it collapses and blood runs off its corpse. 

Controls - 10  (Controller) 

 I started off playing on a controller, not sure how good/bad the keyboard/mouse style would be, try it yourself. 
You gotta have quick fingers, you use every single button.  You better be quick calling in your Stratagems.  They literally can mean the difference between life and death. 

Repeatability - N/A

So this game you’ll do different missions but there are only 3 different types of worlds.  However the map combinations are pretty much endless. There is a lot of doing the same thing over and over again. Once you hit level 20 or so, you’ve unlocked most of the items/weapons and are just going around looking for the ‘samples’ to upgrade weapons. 

I’ll play for a few days, take a break and come back and play some more. It does get repetitive after a while. 
 

Music - 9 

You’re running across the desert to your next objective, the music is calm and serene nothing much is happening, you see a patrol of bad guys pop up. You kill 2 or 3 of them, but one sets off the alarm.  Suddenly enemies are dropping in all around you, or from the ground if you’re going against the bugs, the music becomes inspirational “Hero” music. You going to be fighting and possibly running, but the music lets you know you’re still alive. 

Seriously I really enjoyed the music. 

Difficulty - 10 

You have 3 different types of enemies, Cyborgs, Bugs and  Illuminates; each with their own style and weapons and hazards. From each of those 3 you can pick planets to invade ranging in difficulty of 1- Walk in the Park to 12 - HellDive.  And then there’s the bosses you can fight as well. 

I played solo games mostly, I was able to do missions 1 through 9 by myself.  Not always completing all objectives, sometimes taking an hour or more for 1 mission.  As the difficulty goes up so do the amount of enemies and the different types.  What you thought was hard on Level 4, just a scrub on Level 9. 

Adding in other players, even random people can either make it super easy or super difficult/frustrating. Everyone has their own playstyle based on what works for them, it can conflict with what you have planned or screw you up royally.  For instance if some idiot drops a minefield where you’re running as he gets eviscerated by a giant bug.  The bug then charges you and since you can’t move b/c of the mines, you wasted a good  hour having to start the freaking mission over again.

Thanks asshole. 

Multiplayer - 8   

Multiplayer was.. Interesting for me.  As mentioned before I was mostly a solo player, but I wanted to earn the Level 12 capes, the cyborg one is my favorite. You need other players or an insane amount of luck to finish a Helldive. 
Let’s not forget that all players contribute to the total war, everything you do gets reported back and affects the state of the war.  Didn’t fight off the invasion from the bugs?  We lost a territory, now they might get to SUPER EARTH and destroy us. 

The small problem with the multiplayer, and it’s a big one. Is that you can kill other players just as easily as the enemies. In fact, it’s going to happen quite a bit. You can try not to, but even the best of us will have it happen.  All you can do is call the reinforcement Stratagem and hope they aren’t too pissed. If they are, you might soon be having a little firefight that helps no one. 

The map can be a problem, it’s a top down shooter where everyone shares the same map.  Someone looking off to the right can cause some problems for the others who are now at the edge of the screen, not a huge problem but can be frustrating at times. 

In all seriousness though, the community is great for the most part, there are some jerks who will drop into your game and kill everyone and leave, they are the exception, not the rule.  

If you're the one running the game you can easily boot them and continue on your mission. 

If you enjoyed t his review then check out my curator page here: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28849369/

I had to force myself to stop at 1000 hours or my games backlog will never be cleared. That should be the end of my review.

However, I do wish to clarify on the matter of DLCs where some people are not satisfied with (too many on release, should be free, etc)

Helldivers comes with 3 (5 as of 26/10/2019) free expansions which provides more variety for planets, missions, and enemies plus bosses.

The DLCs which are cosmetics + additional gear/vehicles/perk are slowly added over the months based on player feedback when Helldivers was still a Playstation exclusive. By the time Helldivers is available on Steam several months later, all the DLCs are already completed so it's not on disc or day 1 DLC or whatever you want to call it.

Regarding the DLC equipment, I consider most of them are side-grades instead of upgrades. While it does add some variety to how you can complete missions, they are not necessary and you can most certainly get the job done with base equipment. In the hundreds of hours I played, I was using base gear most of the time.

The only DLC I would consider mandatory is the terrain specialist pack for the boots which removes movement penalty on snow or swamp planets. Ultimately, you skill is what determines the mission success, gear is secondary.

So yea, this turned into quite a rant but I hope this clarifies things for potential buyers who may be put off by the amount of DLCs Helldivers has. If you want, just wait for a sale and get the DD edition for half price. It's worth it, but not necessary.

I keep coming back to this game, because it's got this spark. The type of spark that comes with being unique, in that it does something traditional like twinstick co-op shooting, but does it in a way that feels very different. 

It manages to make you feel like an elite Orbital Drop Trooper while also making you feel very vulnerable and mortal. I think this is mostly down to two things. 
Firstly, every weapon you fire feels like it has impact and weight. Every calldown you bring from orbit brings either death to large swathes of the battlefield or is a weapon that will bring death to anything fool enough to get near it.
Secondly, everything is friendly fire. Run in front of a buddy's gun: You die. Stand under an ammo crate being dropped from orbit -> SQUISH. Run headlong into airstrike: You'll be turned into swiss cheese with nice pasty red tomatosauce. Forget that there is a friendly machinegunturrent behind you while there's an enemy in front of you: welp, you just became a gory mess of once human parts.

Because death is so present both where it concerns you meting it out and being subject to it, it feels like you're constantly just hanging in there. That you and your team can only barely make the impossible happen because you are such fucking badasses. And that makes for a fun game to play with friends.

At the same time some of the most frustrating elements about the game can be the players seeing as how the screen is shared amongst the entire team all it takes sometimes is one person running off and locking everyone down. Learning to play around bad teammates was probably one of the most enjoyable parts of the game for me personally, simply another difficulty factor.
I would argue that, some of the DLC is very useful bordering on too good. Such as the terrain expert perk letting you ignore the mechanic which is meant to make snow maps difficult.
Besides that one DLC the rest is very much just more variety for your loadout and/or appearance should you desire.
Another drawback for the people starting to play the game is that the galactic campaign system doesn't do itself any favours as unlocking abilities require you to play particular planets from each enemy and in some instances those can be unaccessible for extended periods of time depending on the current War.
The game isn't without its problems but overall I think it is a very enjoyable experience.
Controller recommended.

This game isn't for anyone, I'll get that out of the way first off. It's one of the tightest co-op experiences out there, with moments of 'down but not out' as you throw a reinforcement strategem while downed, ressurecting your team, as well as yourself as you get killed. It is not an easy game, for instance, when you get downed in most games, enemies ignore you, in this one, the'll execute you. Friendly fire damage is not reduced in anyway, and anything that damages enemies damages allies, and vice-versa. There is no enemy/ally damage, simply damage. A careless shot could kill off one of your teammates, or your whole team with an air strike. Essentially, if you're good at coordinating with a team, and using communication, this game's for you! If not, well, it's also for you! But probably much harder, as there is singleplayer, but the main expirience is co-op.

FYI, it's a top-down shooter with FPS style movement, moving, sprinting, aiming, and the like.

This is a fantastic game that is held back by one major problem. The progress is based on a "community campaign" where the levels and your to unlocks is tied to community progress. In spirit this seems like a good idea, you feel like you are part of a larger  war that advances as players complete objectives.

In reality, every time you boot up the game you have to be hopeful that some fun levels/unlocks/areas are open for you and your friends to play. If the community is not moving the campaign along, or it gets stuck (as it frequently does) on the final push to enemy homeworld, you have a scant few levels to pick from or some boss/survival levels that are at best boring, at worst frustratingly difficult.

Everything else about this game is fantastic, the negative review is tied solely to this mechanic, which has the effect of taking away your ability to play/enjoy the game you paid for on the basis of whether or not the community has collectively filled a bar that decides which levels you have access to. I can't tell you how many times either myself or a friend has been excited to unlock some interesting new toys to play with, only to log in and be stuck grinding XP, sometimes for several days in a row while we wait for the campaign to reset.

Helldivers is a top down twin stick shooter that despite being competently made is just too boring to recommend.

The biggest issue is the art direction and story. Models are bland and there is no narrative to speak of. There are 3 enemy races and you select from a list of missions ranked from easiest to hardest. Harder missions offer more rewards. But there is a huge disconnect between the missions you select and what's happening in the game itself. Objectives in the game are meaningless as far as a greater narrative goes. Why am I clearing this minefield? Why am I hacking this computer? Much of the fault here lies in the Global War system. Essentially you are fighting with the rest of the multiplayer community to fight off the aliens and you can only fight specific missions where the war front is currently at. It's confusing and doesn't make the player feel like he's contributing much himself.

The actually gameplay is fine. You have a number of different guns, special abilities you can call down, and there's a lot of customization available. Each of the races is fairly unique though maps are not especially varied. There's a big emphasis on the multiplayer. I played most local coop which worked reasonably ok but difficult on a single screen. Online multiplayer got me team-killed immediately upon playing a match.

Helldivers might be fun with a couple friends dedicated to completing the toughest challenges. As a single player experience it's too weak to recommend.

Mindless fun with a hilarious premise, Helldivers portrays you as an interstellar soldier fighting to bring "freedom" to the galaxy. You'll mow down endless alien hordes whilst endlessly shouting slogans of liberty and democracy, battling on behalf of what is, in fact, very obviously a military fascism bent on galactic xenocide. 

The campaign is entirely multiplayer, and functions cyclically: at the end of each galactic conquest, the map will be reset. Star systems are captured by the player and his many thousands of peers on a planet-by-planet basis. 

My only knock against this title is that it can become repetitive. Nonetheless, I strongly recommend it to fans of the genre. It's tons of fun, and can be had at an affordable price. It is, as with most multiplayer titles, at its most fun when played with friends.

The DLC adds some fun options, but isn't a must-buy.

LOVED: 
I loved that this game really makes you [b] work as a team [/b] with your teammates whether randoms online or with your friends. This game [b] doesn't pull punches [/b], but lets you decide what difficulty level you want to play at. I doubt many players will be able to ever play the most difficult levels - particularly casual players. There's no shame in that - every victory is celebrated. While your progression might be slower if you don't challenge yourself, you still contribute to the [b] total players combined effort [/b]. All players worldwide work to win the campaign together, there is no competition between players unless you want their to be.

Helldiver's sense of humor is excellent, it's worldbuilding is great, and I'd love to see more like it. While the Helldivers universe doesn't really every come into gameplay, it is good on its own and I wish there was more lore to discover.

This game lets players that have been brutally murdered by friend or foe [b] get right back into the fray [/b] with the help of friends without breaking the experience or even the plot.

One of the most unique mechanics in this game is STRATAGEMS - which are essentially airdropped supplies, weapons, explosives, bullets, napalm, or the like that all players have access to during missions. Lots of enemies can't be dealt with easily with small arms - but calling in a small nuclear warhead should do the job just fine... [i] as long as you clear out in time [i]. Or maybe use a smaller more humble DiveBombing Run, or the strategic HellBomb. Players can only bring in 4 stratagems per player, and some can only be used once per mission. 



DISLIKE: 
Related to stratagems, it is important that players can think as a team on what aid they want. Not every player needs to bring a supply stratagem nor jumpack, but if you are joining random players you cannot see what items they already have, so it is likely you are going to be redundant at best or lacking at worst.

The DLCs are totally optional and allow players to bring more gadgets, weapons, and perks into the fray. Seeing as all players are on a team, this doesn't give an unfair advantage over other players - but instead lets people who have bought the DLCs have cooler, flashier, and often downright more effective stratagems than other players. Because players are not competing against each other, this little pay-to-win problem isn't really a problem. For information, I own none of the optional DLC.

Helldivers feels like a rejected 40K title. I do not mean this as an insult, Starcraft was another 40K reject and it's amazing. Helldivers features intense PURGING of all alien species, with SKULLS as the banner for humanity. Just replace the empire with a cynical view of a futuristic humanity dominated by american stereotypes and you have Helldivers. 

So, if you have never played it, you probably wonder what is so special about it.

[h1]The good[/h1]
Helldivers has an EXTREME amount of customization and "Building" as in, you will have to work with your squaddies to build the best setup you can. Do we take vehicles, who is taking a short range stuff and wont be able to help with patrols, do we have an anti tank weapon that can be quickly used. This game will push you into a role to fight each of the three factions and you have an immense amount of FREEDOM to make your helldiver as badass as you want.

The game features 3 enemies that are diverse in how you have to deal with them. The bugs are melee only and rely on overwhelming squads and using their large units to break up your formations. The Cyborgs are armored to the teeth and require more firepower to kill than the other factions, working in squads and using tanks themselves. The illuminate are masters of death by division, even their base units create beams that force you to move out of the way, and they even have a flying "Orb" that can put down a wall and cut your battlefield in half. One strategy will not work for all factions.  

The game is satisfying as hell to play, because the difficulty really makes you feel like you have achieved something every time you play it. As in, this game is REALLY HARD on the upper difficulties. Difficulty seekers need not look further. 

In addition to just being hard, the game forces you to forget tired and incorrect videogame tropes in order to keep yourself, and your mates, alive. All weapons can friendly fire and will kill allies FAST. Reloading doesn't put your mag in a magic vest that reallocates the bullets to other mags like a typical FPS, if you reload at half mag, say bye to those rounds, they are gone. You will have to rewire yourself and be extremely careful to not harm your allies or yourself. If you call in an ammo drop near a vehicle, it may land on the vehicle and destroy it, good job, you just threw away your teams tank. 

As a result of the above info, the CO-OP is incredibly fun and intense. Some weapons require a "Loader" to help supply it with ammo, resulting in even more emphasis on teamwork. Tanks need gunners to man the turret, in fact most non-walkers need people to man guns, so teamwork is always necessary. Solo play is not impossible, and you get compensation one "Auto Revive" per completed objective so it's not completely impossible.

[h1]The bad[/h1]
Helldivers is a fantastic concept, but even the Mona Lisa has flaws.

The games balance can be a bit bass ackwards, some weapons really are "Always takes" and some are "Never consider" some of the DLC weapons completely replace ingame weapons in terms of use. 

As far as DLC goes, it is a pain to have to buy content, especially in a game where at base you feel like you NEED some DLC to be effective. That being said, 3 bucks is a very low price and you can pick and choose which ones you want instead of buying a massive DLC for 1 item. This isn't a big deal in my opinion. 

The real sin here is how the "Perk" system works. You can have 1 perk, these perks range from useless to holy-crap-take it. The problem is some of these perks do stuff like replace pistols or grenades, but this robs you of your perk. Would you take a smoke nade over being able to survive a lethal hit once every 20 seconds? No? Weird, I wouldn't either. Would you take a plasma pistol replacer over Heavy armor? No? Weird. 

Nades and pistols need their own bloody slots, it is silly that the perks account for ALL of these. Especially being some perks are basically necessary to survive certain levels. This has always been a problem and will probably remain unchanged.

The game features this "Worldwide cross platform link" gamestyle where every person contributes to galactic campaigns. Each campaign ends in an assault on the enemies homeworld or a defense of super-earth. This sounds like a fun gimmick, but it makes certain gameplay options unobtainable based on players progress. Say you just bought the game, get on, and see the cyborgs and illuminate campaigns are the only ones up, and the game is at their homeworld now. You cant get stratagem unlocks from homeworlds, so you are now locked into waiting for that to end before you can even really play the game. Gameplay is locked off based on things out of your control and that is not enjoyable at all. 

The community on this game really can vary. Many are helpful, all over reddit revealing strategies and how to use guns you may not yet understand the purpose of, but on the flipside many are ego-monsters who kick you for not using the right perk, or if they get themselves killed running into your gunfire. It really can vary, but when it's bad, it's nasty. Play with friends if you can help it to alleviate this and search online for the helpful helldiver player-tutorials, they are bountiful and quite helpful. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Helldivers has endured as a Co-op icon for years now, and even as it's playercount falls, I still love coming back to it with friends and trying my luck at it's difficult missions. The freedom of customization is intoxicating, and we need more of it. The flaws on the other hand are an ever-present sore on an otherwise great game, and one can only hope a sequel someday shows that has all of the beauty this game offered, plus important fixes and modifications. Even more freedom and variety would be great too. If you have friends willing to play it with you, this game is a no brainer. 

Buy it.

I don't want to call it false advertising or something, but this game's presentation and representation are spectacularly misleading.
Between jokes of inflicting freedom and causing democracy, this game builds strong outside image of a horde shooter similar to Crimsonland or Nation Red.

Which couldn't be further from the truth. If anything, this feels and plays like some sort of a Syndicate game with one unit controlled by an individual player. It's highly tactical, and you're supposed to evade encounters with enemies as much as possible, as opposed to actively seeking them out and massacring them for some loot or exp or whatever. The less you actually fight the better.

Even something as simple as moving and shooting requires constant concentration. And there is this whole stratagem input business. That somehow spreads onto panels activation and what not.

This game is enveloped in this cheery EDF-like atmosphere of fun and happy-go-lucky massacre, that is mostly associated with and brainless horde twin stick shooters, where all the work is done by your spinal cord, while your brain takes a good nap.
Instead this is very mental and demanding game, especially when soloing, and probably even more so at the maximum difficulties with coordinated squad.

I highly recommend this game if you want difficult, tactical  and smart co-op twin stick shooter, but be aware that if you're looking for game similar to Crimsonland, Nation Red or Alien Shooter, this is quite the opposite.

So many rather good game[i]play[/i] design decisions, and so many terribly awful non-gameplay game design decisions.
Before I say anything, I should probably read you the Arrowhead Game Studios motto
[b][i]"A game for everyone is a game for no one."[/i][/b]
I should probably say this review isn't for everyone.
Now that all parties are entirely excused from blame because of some words, we can go forward.

I'm not mad that the three top difficulty levels are just artificial difficulty increase through random chance, because I know how it must feel to have to tack on something just to keep the maniacs busy.  I'm very mad inside but will pretend that I'm not mad that 
bad guys will drop directly onto you, making you look like an idiot in a situation of no possible correct moves because it's only made so in certain circumstances.  I'm constantly endlessly seething with rage, and will not show it for you, that missions start and end with incredibly long unskippable screens that makes restarting take up to 45 seconds of doing nothing but pressing E.

What I will tell you I'm mad about is

[b]1. Retaliatory Strikes[/b], the [i]other[/i] gamemode in the game that makes half of all planets (groups of 2 or 3 or 4 missions) untouchable.  Packed into a small space with the aim to survive x amount of enemies almost makes sense, except when the bad guys don't come from a certain direction/directions.  They always arrive in random spots coming from up off screen with less than a second of forewarning before they start punching you.  That includes the overwhelmingly significantly more difficult team-effort enemies (tanks and stuff).  'Playing Retaliatory Strike' is the exact string of words that equates to gambling in Google translate English -> English.  It requires more than prayer to God, Allah, Buddha, and your own personal Spirit Animal to survive.  It is quite possibly the least fair chunk of game design, and it's not changing or going anywhere.

2. [b]DLC objective advantages[/b], where not having the DLC puts you at a significant disadvantage.  One example is [url=https://helldivers.gamepedia.com/LAS-16_Sickle]the LAS-16[/url] (go to the bottom, Detailed Analysis), a DLC weapon that is 1.7 times as effective as the [url=https://helldivers.gamepedia.com/LAS-5_Scythe]LAS-5[/url], a base-game laser gun that compares (the metric is DPS/HPS to account for the LAS-16's higher heat, where it's still better rather than DPS alone, where it completely eclipses almost everything in the game).  Another example is the [url=https://helldivers.gamepedia.com/All_Terrain_Boots]All-Terrain Boots[/url], which make half of all planets the same as the other half in that you don't need to plan ahead, because you bought the DLC.  (These boots also make doing boss fights on snow planets even feasible, where otherwise you would be disadvantaging yourself somewhere between 2 and 20 times as much). The crazy thing is not all the DLC even provides an objectively useful item.  It's just that some of them are so insanely powerful compared to the rest that if you try to pick 'em for style and pick wrong you're toast. 

3. [b]The War System[/b], which completely blocks you out from playing big chunks of the game because the community already did it before you.  Yes, the insects, the most fair enemy type, the community's favorite to play against?  They're gone first because there is a limited amount of effort you can put in against any of the three enemy types before they die off until you finish off the others.  When I first got the game during the last [strike]Christmas[/strike] Holiday sale, me and my pals couldn't play against the bugs until far after the New Year dropped.  Another [i]highly[/i] intelligent design decision of the war system is making the best possible gameplay (city defense) a punishment, and making the most boring possible gameplay (enemy capitol) a reward.  I would really like to show you, but I would like more to never have to play the game again.

With over 10,000 steam reviews, you'd expect HELLDIVERS to be a bit of a household name. However, I have had a genuinely hard time finding other people who have even touched this game. When brought up in conversation, I often hear that people have never heard of this game. Upon viewing the steam page, I often hear the response, "Eh, it doesn't look like my kind of game."

This pretty much tears my heart in two every time I hear it, because HELLDIVERS is an incredible game that you should NOT overlook.

HELLDIVERS (yes, I'm going to capitalize it every time) is a twin-stick sci-fi shooter set in an offbrand Starship Troopers universe. Levels are procedurally generated, and the campaign is a massive galactic conquest that is contributed by the entire community, similar to games like Planetside 2. There are 3 main factions that all have their own specialties and require delicate changes in playstyle at high levels. This game is seriously difficult on higher difficulties 9 and up, so be aware of that.

HELLDIVERS' customization features can be absolutely glorious. Please note that I said "can be." There is a wide variety of armors to choose from in the game, but with the added caveat that a lot of the (imo) best cosmetics are locked behind DLC. This is true heartbreak right here. On top of that, these DLC's add a ton of cool weapons that are locked behind a paywall.

This I believe is the biggest issue with the game. It is the only one that comes to mind with well over 75 hours played. The game isn't perfect, but this glaring issue is just unforgivable. Someone in corporate demanded that HELLDIVERS has loads of DLC. If you are interested in picking this game up, please just buy the Digital Deluxe Edition. The game goes on sale for cheap sometimes, and if you do bite the bullet it will make your life way easier.

That being said, this is a positive review; I have a lot of good things to say about this game with the DLC in my pocket. First I'd like to discuss the gameplay.

On a basic level, the combat is just good fun. HELLDIVERS can be equally enjoyed with a KB+M and a gamepad. Animations are smooth, informative, and don't get in the way of the game's tight controls. Gunplay is very strong, with good sound, visual, and haptic feedback (on controllers). Controls are tight, with lots of inputs to master. Calling in drops (you will be doing that a lot) has a high skill ceiling since it involves complex inputs. There are absolutely LOADS of things you can call in. Vehicles, mechs, nukes, close-air support, and you can even respawn your friends using a drop.

Maps are procedurally generated, with a wide variety of objective types to make the game fresh. Within these maps there are 3 factions to fight, each with their own quirks, special objectives, and respective bosses.

This game is no slouch, so expect to die a lot. Friendly fire is ON, and to hilarious effect. Expect to get team killed a lot if you can find a lobby. Expect to get crushed, nuked, shot, stabbed, burned, and bludgeoned. Maybe you'll be wrecked by a giant tank, or maybe by your fellow teammates.

That's the next thing: Multiplayer. Multiplayer is both local co-op and online, and both can be used simultaneously. HELLDIVERS uses drop-in co-op, similar to how the LEGO games do it. Playing with friends would be an absolute riot if I had any that owned this game. In my 76 hours of HELLDIVERS, I can safely say the best way to play this game is with other players.

From loadout variety to map and difficulty variety, it really feels like there's a lot of content here. Each match feels fresh, and the trickle of rewards you get from playing the game are worthwhile. There's a good reason why people in this review section are really excited about this game; suffice to say, it is very enjoyable. I can safely say that this is the best twin stick shooter I have ever played, and I have a hard time going back to play others after playing so much HELLDIVERS.

So please, purchase this game, sit down in your epic gamer chair, and have a nice tall cup of liber-tea as you mow down hordes of aliens in your mech, or motorcycle, or APC, or tank, or your even bigger mech. I heartily recommend this game.
