Things I like:
-You can win any difficullty on any mission solo (you just need enough skill and the right equipment).
-You get rewarded if you search around on the whole map. You can collect probes which give you research points and with them you can unlock either better equipment (more-fueled jetpacks, extra ammo for a mech, etc) or new stuff for your weapons (focking laser sights, bigger magazines, etc) ---> Higher difficullty = more probes on a map. Beware that those probes will only save if you (or someone else) escape(s)!
-You get new stuff after getting a level-up. New weapons, new armors (skins) and new unlockable calldowns.
-You progress on the galaxy-map with other players. 3 alien-races to fight against at the same time? Hell yea!

Mixed feelings:
-The camera "forces" you to stick to each other. The enemies still spot you sometimes from a place you can't see because of the camera. At the same time it "forces" to play as an actual team and not everyone by himself.
Don't get me wrong, I like to play as a team! But sometimes I could just shoot at an ally for running alone towards a point or leaving someone slowly behind, instead of shooting the enemy. It affects you, but not as much as the enemy spooting one of you outside of your screen.

What I don't like:
-Even thou you and your team got good internet connection, the servers have their limits. I once shot someone in the back and there was blood coming out, but he didn't took any damage. Same goes with "walking someone over with a mech".
-The DLC's all togheter are like 50% of your arsenal.
There is some equipment you will never or only rarely ever use, dlc-stuff included.
Some stuff is even unbalanced, in a bad way. But I won't tell anyone what not to use.
-Many players use the laser-shotgun (for a reason). It counts as the "best" weapon out of all for many players out there. Personally, I prefer the Laser-Rifle or Plasma Cannon.


Personal opinion:
-You either play this game non-stop or just a few rounds each day/week. Sometimes you find trolls, but there is a report and like system.
"Report" = You don't actually "report" them, but you give this player a "dislike" which means this player will more likely be put with other people that got disliked when looking for a game in the multiplayer-list or waiting for player support after calling a beacon inside of a mission. And... "Like" does ...well, it does the opposite, duh.

"If you spontaneously think of a game that you really liked, where you liked the graphics, the setting, the gameplay, the controls, really EVERYTHING... except for ONE SINGLE BUT CRUCIAL detail, that's unfortunately so damn annoying, that it breaks your whole gaming experience and you're tired of playing it?"
... my answer would be: "Helldivers".

The detail that is at stake has already been hotly debated in various forums. There is a strong stock of supporters, as well as many strong voices against this feature.

It's about the camera setting.

When I bought Helldivers, I had made the mistake of not reading in the description exactly enough that it is a "twin-stick shooter".
For all the unfortunate souls who, like me, had no idea what that meant at the time, here's a short explanation.

If there is only 1 player on the map, this player can move freely with a fixed camera angle from above. The camera even shifts a little bit in the direction you are aiming for, and you have a bit more of a view in that direction, which could be great for spying on the terrain ... IT COULD BE.
Cause now comes the above-mentioned feature of the "Twin Stick Shooter" into play.

If 2 players, worse, 3 or 4 players are on the map, they are forced to share one and the same camera view.
Imagine it as if the players were connected with invisible, elastic rubber bands. And above the imaginary node in the middle between all the figures, the camera hangs rigid and fix. ALWAYS. No matter what you do.

The developers justify this feature with the fact that it is supposed to enforce the teamplay and that this game was made as a couch-coop-game. In fact, in my opinion, it makes the game unplayable.

Some examples:
You are on the battlefield with a suqad of 4 members. Suddenly a patrol appears on the right edge of the screen. Now all of the players have to aim in this direction. If not the angle of view shifts only partially there or stays stuck in the middle. The patrol calls for reinforcement. The reinforcement spawns unfortunately right in the centre of the screen, inbetween the players. In order not to die, they have to split up a bit, get away from each other. That means, one runs to the right, maybe two to the top of the screen, one diagonally down to the left ... And the view still remains in the middle ...
The problem is, if more enemy units are approaching from any direction, you can not see them! Simply because the camera can not be moved. The enemies are actually there, but you literally do not have them on the screen! So it may be that in such a situation you are disassembled by several heavy adversaries that are only five or ten yards away and that you might have been able to fend off, but since you could not see them, you're just dying.

The fact that there are sniper rifles in Helldivers at all seems completely meaningless. A weapon designed for the longest distances, but you can not see an opponent who practically stands beside you and pats you on the back because he's hidden under the edge of the screen.
And then he will of course hit you in the face.

Other situation:
You're on the road with a full team. It comes to a tough fight, a team member dies. Everyone has to withdraw a bit, let the fight fade away. The fallen teammate could not be resurrected on the spot because there were too many enemies, so he gets resurrected by drop pod. If this player had the misfortune to have worn particularly good equipment at his death, which he would really like to bring back, everyone must go there with him. Theoretically, you could say, "You keep going, I'll get my stuff and then I'll join you." Nope. It does not work. All MUST stay together.

There are some mission goals that would be much easier to win if the players were allowed to spread across the terrain even just a little without having to accept the penalty that they no longer have a view in any direction, but only see the center between them. While one team member does the work, the others keep the enemies off his back. But that only works if you see them coming ... again, I find the sniper rifles completely useless in this context. It would make much more sense if, as a user of such a weapon, you had the privilege of being able to move your sight not just a bit but very far in the direction you are aiming for. After all, you swap the fast rate of fire of an assault rifle against further view. Or not?

And that's how I experienced Helldivers playing online.
When I died, my team members did not let me get my equipment. I had to go with them, whether I wanted to or not. The camera would have followed the team, not me. If I had gone on my own initiative in one direction, I would not have seen my figure anymore and would simply have died once more. In some cases they just didn't resurrect me, even if I did nothing wrong.
Several times I died because I could not see opponents beyond the edge of the screen. I was shot by enemies with ranged weapons, who actually have a miserable range and damage, but since I could only roughly target them and almost had to shoot good luck into Nirvana, I did not hit them.
And that's exactly what happened to me again and again and again and again and again... until I finally asked myself, why for all heavens names I really do this to myself.

The answer is, as I mentioned in my introductory words, that I really wanted to like Helldivers! I wanted it! But this camera view just ruins everything.

If you had at least the freedom to choose, to decide for yourself, whether each participant in the group can run with an individual camera or if you play in a group with a fixed camera angle, I would write a big hymn of praise here! Helldivers is actually a great game and it would certainly still be in my personal top 5 of my favorite games.
No kidding: I would PAY for it if the developers would offer a free camera perspective as a DLC! I would buy Helldivers for the full price one more time, including all DLCs, if every player could have his own camera!

(The only reason I did not request a refund was that I spent at least some nice hours at Helldivers. But only in single player...)

Welcome to the HELLDIVERS elite infantry unit, recruit. We are the personification of humanities greatest accomplishements. Listen closely and maybe you will survive your very first mission!


-We are the good guys! - A wonderful sense of humor in the fashion of Paul Verhoeven (Starship Troopers).

-Grow and learn! - A progression system that gives you new character skins, weapons, perks, stratagems (airstrikes, heavy weapons, vehicles, tools like attack- and repairdrones etc..) and upgrade points to enhance your favorite play toys.

-Adapt! - No classes, just pick your loadout before every mission. Look at your comrades equipment and take the stuff your team lacks. Or just play your favorite and most effective build which suits your personal playstyle most.

-Be proud! - Individualize your HELLDIVERS elite soldier with tons of helmets, armor and capes.

-Know your enemy! - Fight 3 different factions: Cyborgs, Bugs and Illuminates. Each with their very own units, different strategies, advantages and such.

-Be percise! - The game controls just awesome no matter if you use M+K or a controller (The game detects every controller just fine and lets you rebind keys).

-You are equipped for every environment! - Procedural created levels with several bioms and a big variety of different objectives (finding buried mines with a metal detector and disarm them, reload a giant mortar cannon, repair and fire it, steal alien technology, or escort survivors to the safety of a bunker and many more).

-Watch your step, watch your aim! - Friendly fire is always on - Everything is able to kill you. Everything!

-You are the veterans of tomorrow! - 12 different difficulties for a challange. The higher the difficulties, the more teamplay you need to be successful. The game is pretty well balanced. Almost every mechanic is a risk/reward one of some sorts.

-Work together to save humanity! - Up to 4 ppl local + online coop (at the same time if you want). Join a running mission on the fly by grabbing the mouse/controller. Or invite/join ppl via steam. It's pretty quick and easy.

-Do your duty, soldier! - Take part in an actual war. Every single player has the responsibility to change the tides. Take back the galaxy bit by bit as a whole community.

-Nobody will be left behind! - A really decent and friendly community. During all my time playing this game i've just met 1 toxic troll and very few ppl who play bad on purpose. Most veterans are very helpful to newbies and often help them doing missions for fun.

Helldivers has a distinctive charm that is difficult to pin down.

It has a campy aesthetic straight out of Starship Troopers, where the governing body for which you serve is much more of a totalitarian state than a "Democracy," but this isn't its charm, it's just a bonus to get a few giggles out of before you enter the meat of the game.

The AI is nothing to shake a stick at, but then, it doesn't need to be when the swarm, the graphics are clean but not overly beautiful, allowing lower-end machines to run the game. Personally, I feel the game really shines through its co-op mechanics. Things normally limited, like respawns, power weapons and air support, are given a cooldown or delegated to teammates, and the screen position is locked on all players' positions, not just yours, making coordination a must.

Sure, some of the DLCs are lacking, and others are outright vital to progress at the level that most others are, but you can look past this, because the raw experience of dancing on the knife's edge with trusted teammates at Level 12 "Hell Dive" difficulty isn't something you can get from other games in as mass of quantities. 

+ for soundtrack, + for gameplay mechanics, + for community (I've made lots of friends on here), - for predatory DLC (Deluxe Edition really helps)

Sensation: HELLDIVERS is a nonstop coop action experience with sudden death always around the corner and reinforcements available in five seconds notice. The tension is broken up with moments of calm as you scour the map for your objectives, exploring the procedurally generated alien maps and fighting off scouts before they detect you. 

Fantasy/Narrative: The story is cheesy and spoofy, adding some comedy as your men shout "FREEDOM!" and dispense fresh democracy to the aliens. Each mission is its own narrative, and the overarching story is limited to periodic "wars" which you don't really feel like you have an impact on (it's not very visible) yet seem to be won and lost based on player count. One main issue with these wars is that it sometimes restricts map and enemy choice if one enemy faction is wiped out and the other takes longer to get rid of so the war can restart, restricting mission choice significantly and causing the game to feel stagnant, though this is usually fixed within a day or two.

Challenge/Fellowship: The game is easy to learn and very accessible, and the later difficulty levels leave a lot of room for skill expression and strategizing builds and squad loadouts with your friends. Teamwork is reinforced through several mechanics, including entering several button commands to call in reinforce beacons, using support weapons, or using team weapons or vehicles. However, it's sometimes hard to find other players due to low player count, and often people don't know their mics are on. There is crossplay on console, which alleviates this a bit, but otherwise it's sometimes hard to coordinate with other players.

Discovery: There aren't very many map types to explore, and once you've played long enough even procedural generation fails to present you with many new maps or enemies to keep you surprised. The fun in discovery comes from finding out how each weapon, stratagem, or vehicle can be used to conquer the enemies of Super Earth. 

Expression: Each weapon and item offers a unique experience, and you can bring a very mixed loadout to each mission. Some may feel restrictive, especially snow maps basically requiring snow boots, but otherwise there's so many loadouts you can try and so many methods to find and invent to defeat the enemy.

Submission: Once you've figured out the importance of anti-tank weapons in difficulty 6 and above, and once you get kitted out with some devastating machine guns, dropping back down to difficulty 4 and stomping the low-tier enemies is good mindless fun to kill time or save some newbies (especially during free weekends). You will be trying your hardest on the higher difficulty missions, but the easier missions are still always accessible and sometimes popular in multiplayer lobbies.

Microtransactions: Not pay-to-win, but there are a few that make some parts of the game much easier. In particular is the Terrain Specialist Pack, which gives you snow boots (making missions on snow planets so much easier) and the Ranger Pack, which gives you an objective and sample (research points to unlock weapons) radar that helps with progression and playing hide-and-seek with mission objectives. Other than that, they add cool weapons and airstrikes that aren't necessary to play the game but add that little bit of extra expression, discovery, and pretty explosions if you like the game. Just some more options really.

Overall: HELLDIVERS is my favorite video game because of the many clutch moments, epic moments with teaming up and fortifying the evac site or leveling a small army with artillery. The player count is somewhat lacking, especially on off-days and times, and it's not nearly as fun in single player, but if you can get over these issues, this might be one of your favorite games too simply due to the constant action that also requires a bit of forward thinking, strategy, and tactics. 

Other: Playing twin-stick is nice, but it is SO much easier with a mouse! Also, be mindful of friendly fire, both giving and receiving it. It's part of what makes the game so tense!

This game has a lot going for it, but there are two main problems (really just one that is comprised of two parts) for me.

Let's start with positives.

The game is a mission-based, top-down shooter. The mechanics utilized feel fluid and cohesive, and the art-direction is good.
The game runs smoothly on an i5-7500, geforce1060. I haven't had any issues with performance so far. 

The first big problem is solo-play. Unlike games (such as Warframe), where you can feel confident in Solo'ing the majority of missions, this game can (and will) throw certain enemies at you that will inevitably stun-lock you and kill you. Other games share this feature, though not en-masse like what I have encountered in my short time of playing. While these enemies are weak, I've noted several times where my character could just not turn fast enough to hit the next charging enemy before being hit. This leads to a death that feels somewhat cheap, and leads to the next problem: respawning. Respawning in solo play is quick (which is good), but spawns you practically near the horde of enemies that just killed you, which isn't. This means you are likely to get stun-locked again, and lose the mission. If Solo play is not Intended, then just do matchmaking, and not allow solo at all. If Solo play is intended, then please adjust these issues. I recommend a brief invuln time to allow a person in solo a fighting chance (alternatively, have solo players be accompanied by a weaker variant of the Guard Dog Stratagem, similar to BOSCO from Deeprock).

I should note, all games mentioned are predominantly multiplayer focused, but this area is a spot where this game could do better. Take it with a grain of salt, as I haven't played for 100+ hours.

Multiplayer is hit-or-miss. In some cases, you can get paired up with a group who just do not like you, and TK you and then proceed to kick you out. Alternatively, you can have great moments where you and the group just shit around like idiots and have fun. I don't think this aspect should change, but it is worth noting that you are going to get a mixed bag of who you play with (also, not noticing a lot of US players, but that could just be poor luck on my part).

The cursor (despite being set to always visible), is hardly visible aside when aiming down sights, which causes your character to turn. This can lead to your character turning the wrong way (leading to stun-lock, in certain cases). If you have an option to set the cursor to be visible, please make it actually do what the title says. A hazy blob that blends in with the backdrop-landscape (which is beautiful), makes this game much more artificially difficult than it needs to be. Half of the difficulty shouldn't be having to memorize where I last left my mouse. Again, not advocating to completely remove the feature (as some players may like it), but please offer us plebeians a means of actually seeing the reticle.

These are very minor nit-picks, but I feel that the game could be polished a bit further to be more new-comer friendly, especially in terms of Solo play. I don't expect hand-holding, but I do expect challenge from the game itself, and not from the UI.

I recommend this game, with a 7/10. It has a wonderful art-style, and easy to pick-up and play controls. It falls flat on the AI mechanics in Solo that can feel over-whelming, and poor respawning implementation in Solo. Multiplayer is a mixed bag again, and I strongly recommend that if you play this game, play it with a friend who you can feel comfortable with dicking around.

Helldivers (HD in short), developed by Arrowhead Game Studios and published by PlayStation Mobile Inc. The PC version was released on: Dec 7, 2015. HD is also available on the PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4, PlayStation Vita. As of this writing, according to Metacritic (https://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/helldivers) it has:
[list]
[*]An average user score of 7.0
[*]#34 Best PC Game of 2015
[*]#78 Most Shared PC Game of 2015
[/list] 

What happens when the makers of Magicka decides to go to space and battle aliens? Can the recipe that made Magicka a success - be reintroduce into this product? *cough**cough*


What is it about?
Helldivers is a 4 person co-op, sci-fi, top-down shooter. The goal is to win this intergalactic war against 3 races so that mankind can prosper in space. To win this war, you'd be unlocking a variety of weapons, skills & equipment to get the job done. But the [b]ultimate[/b] question will be: Do you want to solo the battle? or play with other helldivers?


Controls, Visuals, Audio
Visually, It's really nice. Every bit of animation and detail can be seen on the character to the objects and environment. Explosions, lasers, nukes - the effect looks realistically.

Aside from that, +1 to the graphic team; each race, weapon, equipment's is designed distinctly. Every special units and boss fights were thought properly and provides different battle experience. Next, the programmers deserves +1 as well as all mechanics are in working condition. No crash/bugs ever happened. Everything is smooth. Kudos.


Audio, its good. Most of the time, the sound provides the "feedback" feel. You wont be hearing beautiful ambient rather screams of your teammates/aliens and explosions. 

Controls uses the standard WASD keyboard and mouse however, there are certain objects; jumpjets/certain weapon which can feel funny/when you completely forget.


Mechanics
You will battle from planet to planet, completing each objective in the mission will net you exp and successfully conquering a planet will reward you with either; exp, equipment's, skills. There are [u]various[/u] objective@activity to perform in a battle; escort mission, fetch, defend, assassinate a unit/terminate x enemy, scan mines and more. Every planet will have samples - you use samples to upgrade your weapons/skills/equipment's. Higher level planet spawn more samples however more mobs/horde will occur with some "special" units that are harder to kill. Aside from the standard planet invasion/defend battles, There will be boss fights. *ahem* bragging rights. lol.

The routine: Dive to a planet -> collect samples -> perform objective -> Escape 
Sounds easy enough ya?


My personal thoughts/My Summary:
I really dislike playing public games because they never fail to offer me the worst gaming experience with trolls/toxic people insulting others. I went into the game with the mindset of: I will only solo - unless I play with my steam friends. No public. Unfortunately as you advance to higher level planets, going solo gets you killed. Waste of time and effort. Ultimately I had to play co-op and behold my gaming experience:

I've been stomped by mechs/crushed by tanks/blown to bits by team mates/fall off from the cliff, burnt to death by lava, ammo drop on my skull, nuked by my teammates, Blown to oblivion with team mate RPG, turrets, grenades, mines, electrocuted, sprayed with acid, laser sniped by my very own team mates, my @$$ blown to bits by shot guns and the list goes on *sigh* cries silently in the corner.  Super earth produces super crappy warriors!

That my friends is the imported recipe from Magicka. Unless you are light hearted/sporting enough, you will probably enjoy the mess that your team mates are cooking - while being surrounded/chased by god-zillions of aliens. Else, well, the urge to rage-quit is 101% very tempting. 

Public games still get on my nerves unless I meet really good/sensible people. When I do meet them, I will commend them. For unruly players, I will report them. enough said. But then, this system can be or is being misused/abused.

The end game? once you've conquered all the planets, your focus would be on collecting as much samples as possible to upgrade every single weapon/skills/equipment's. The grind kicks in and this can feel really tiring.

At the end of the day, while I might complain about the missions and all that crap. At some point, I do appreciate the mess and action provided. For me, playing with friends is the ultimate "fun" experience. I once took my friend on his bike and went in circles smashing through aliens and avoided the escape zone. Or when my buddy keys in the wrong arrow key while scanning for land mine - boom - the entire crew guarding him died. Silly stuffs like that with friends are [b]priceless. [/b]

One of the leading Freedom Simulators on Steam; this game is well-worth a recommendation.

Liberating space from three visibly and functionally distinct factions of foes, this game plays like a cross between Magicka and Alien Swarm. Especially to the former insofar as it's very, very easy to pulp your buddies, and only slightly more difficult to bring them back following an accident. And there will be accidents.

Although this game is playable solo, I do much more strongly recommend it if you have a group of friends to play it with. Friends that won't mind being crushed by a drop pod, or a tank, or a dropship. Or minced by a strafing run, or blown up by some artillery fire. Or just plain shot in the back of the head.
To say nothing of the [b]actual enemies themselves![/b]

HELLDIVERS offers a wide variety of weapons and support abilities with which to carnage [strike]your teammates[/strike] freedom-hating scum, ranging from grenade launchers, to mechs, to micronukes, to squad-loaded rocket launchers, to a bolt-action rifle. Although the meta might only call for a few specific things, you're really better off just having fun with it. You'll find that some weapons and calldowns tend to work better on one faction than another, which allows for some experimentation and freedom in your builds.

The game looks pretty nice, and controls very well on a gamepad, although I know some people have taken issue with the PC controls. The difficulty display takes the form of a number, and ranges from cozy slow recon to absolutely horrifyingly tense and non-stop danger. Each of the 3 factions has a different focus on their power curve, as well as giant bosses that can be optionally fought.

The general gameplay loop is objective-oriented, and actually fighting things is usually secondary, if you can avoid getting caught by dealing with the patrols quickly. Which isn't always as easy as it sounds when you have the objectives to worry about, especially by yourself. Casualties in co-op can be quickly replaced by any surviving member of the squad by calling reinforcements, or by an automated lives system in solo play. This keeps the gameplay moving along pretty smoothly.

If I were to level any real cricitism of the game, it would be that the story and plot are nearly non-existent, if you actually care about that kind of thing. Some people complain about certain DLC being "mandatory" for high level play, but I honestly think you're fine with the free stuff. Do some investigation on your own, if it concerns you.

Definitely worth playing with friends. I wouldn't necessarily recommend it if you only plan on playing solo/with pubs, though.

A tremendously fun twin-stick shooter, wrapped in a very pretty package with a thin veil of political satire.
The closest comparison that comes to most minds is on a Starship Troopers level, but anyone who ever cheered for the bravado and overly-heavy weaponry of any shade of space marines: this game fills that niche perfectly.
A solid experience to play on your own, redoubled in value when played online, and even moreso when doing so with friends by your side.

Outstanding game, particularly with friends. You'll find additional depth at higher difficulties where your team composition and load-out choices are critical. The higher difficulties truly pose more challenges that require thought and strategy to overcome. As a result, this game is thankfully devoid of brainless speed runs and shallow point-and-kill efforts currently saturating the market. Over time you'll find the right weapon and perk upgrades that fit your style. This in and of itself is an element that may fall short to the casual player that expects every unlock to be unequivocally better. Be patient, experiment with load-outs, find good coop partners, and enjoy another cup of liberty.

HELLDIVERS is a great top-down shooter that may seem all "Guns blazing", but actually also has some soft stealth elements that also take on a role in the game. Without DLC, this game has a bunch of items and ways to slaughter all those cyborgs, bugs, and aliens. There are APCs, Mechs, Rocket Launchers, Laser Guns, Turrets, Airstrikes, and even a friggin Nuke. There is a bunch of weaponry in the base game, but even a ton of more toys with the DLC, however items range from Too useful to complete garbage in it. The game still even adds more content from time to time, and with how the game still has people playing, you'll never have a dull moment playing this game, especially with the events that occur when the opponents repel your forces or you finally reach the capital city of their homeworld. The whole game is designed to be a community effort, so you feel like you are contributing to something bigger with how after every mission, you are awarded points which go to a community pool. Enough points and you progress, until you get to that homeworld and trash their city, which means they are eliminated for the rest of the campaign. They can also push back however, requiring the community to do missions or they get a leg up on you. The game still feels alive for what may seem like low player counts to some, but it really is a good one!
Still great and fun, though a little dependent on having the DLC if you want certain loadouts. Can still manage fine without it though.

It's as simple as the trailers. Virtually the better "Magicka" concept in execution. There was a lot of talk about... I really tried to make it short.

[h1]Now, if you've never played Magicka...[/h1]
HELLDIVERS is a top down shooty bangbang game with emphasis on multiplayer cooperation, like Alien Swarm. But unlike Alien Swarm, it has much more depth and variation completely dependent on player preference, kinda like Magicka. What? My comparisons are awful? [i]Fiiine.[/i]

In HELLDIVERS, you are a soldier fighting a grand war against three oppositions. In every mission, you and up to three others will be dropped in the middle of enemy territory. You are to complete as many objectives as you can or die trying. Upon completion and/or failure of every objectives, evacuation will be made available. After every three regular missions, you will have completed a planet, receive a greater reward, and also contributing to the overall war effort. zzz...

[h1]That sounds dull, even to me. At least it's out of the way, though.[/h1]
On the field, fire discipline is out the window. The difference between life and death is as small as a sidestep away. Friendly fire is on full; Whatever happens to the enemy can and will happen to you at some point. The reason? Because the camera is so darn focused on the center of every player. No, I don't mean individual players, I meant the center of EVERY PLAYER. You all share one screen. Be aware of your allies, manage your camera as a team, because their handling of destructive weaponry and stratagem could also be your head lopped. Although, it's not like you can't save yourself if someone else made a bad decision. I hope you didn't skip tap dancing lessons because you're going to want fancy feetsies.

As much as we try to avoid it, inevitably, "accidents" happen. A lot. It may be a norm to die, but it doesn't mean you should do it without care... even if everyone is quite expendable... I'll get to that in a bit.

Gunplay is quite simple. You aim, you shoot, reload, repeat. Most weapons are quite straight forward in this pattern. What makes this juicy are the strategic call-ins, aka stratagems. These vary from offensive (such as airstrikes or artillery), to defensive (sentries and traps), and special equipment (support weapons, tanks, mechs and ammo). Calling in these require manual directional input for every unique stratagems. In a sense, it takes a bit of player skill. It becomes muscle memory to frequent players, and those few seconds they cut really count. And you know what's a really important stratagem in this friendly fire volatile environment? Reinforce. I'm sure you'll get used to that input, too.

[h1]How many colors should you expect?[/h1]
Before every mission, you can choose between 15 perks, 22 primary weapons, and 50 stratagems, and 4 more which are standard issued (numbers include dlcs). Oh, I also should mention you have to unlock some through leveling. Every weapon and stratagem can be upgraded (with a couple exceptions). I recommend upgrading Reinforce first, as it significantly lowers its cooldown so that you may recover from an ally's mistake who recently died to your bullets. Mhm, not your fault. Don't worry about it.

Customization? Not really. Upgrades are rather straight forward. There's no revolutionary tech trees or anything. More points just means improving certain stats and adding characteristics to it. There's different armors and hats I suppose. Oh but ultimately the glorious cape! What kind of soldier are you without a cape? It's still all aesthetics.

There are three factions/races you'll battle in the game, as I mentioned. Equipments have varying levels of effectiveness depending on your foes. Each enemy units are unique, with different characteristics and behaviors. But as for how? Unfortunately I'm writing a review, not a guide. Stick your face in it and find out. Good luck, greenies! I wouldn't mind seeing a few more panicked faces.

[h1]It's bashin' time[/h1]
My signature move: complain. Because I believe people should be aware of the flaws rather than being fed by sugarcoat reviews.

[b]Repetition.[/b]
Very, very big thing here. If you don't enjoy the gameplay, you will likely not enjoy the game as a whole. Missions are randomly generated and while that sounds great, you'll still be doing the same few objectives over and over. The same enemies, the same-ish maps. But it can't be that bad if there's many of us maxed level siting on hundreds and thousands of hours still playing this right? That's up to you to decide. Psst! This is why I pirate games before buying! It's revenue~!

[b]Community[/b]
I only play on the highest difficulties so there should be a bit of consideration on player saturation. You may have a few other problems, but those aren't mine~ haha! ...Sorry.

You'll run into the same players veeeeery often. That doesn't mean the game is dead. It is still very much active and there are plenty of lobbies. Getting into a game is pretty easy. Hosting one doesn't take much as well. Someone will always join.

For a team-based game, this is bound to happen. Not everyone is going to get along. Through my experience, there aren't very much toxic people. Generally, most are quite nice. Grab your bayonet and give your teammates the good ol' poke to start a tickle party. Everyone will want to have a pillow fight with grenades eventually! (Actually no, don't.)

Bad players? Of course. There will be new players joining tough missions because there's nothing stopping them. Some people can't seem to stand it. Beware of getting kicked on the spot. I know I sometimes can't. But I normally don't kick people unless I have to. If there's earnest effort to improve and play for the team as a whole, I can usually tell. It's quite admirable. However if a player has no trigger discipline and is always unaware of the team's intentions, that's quite problematic.

[b]Balancing[/b]
Yes and no. People are going to yell at me for this one to defend their favorite guns.
Game's not that balanced. It's balanced "ENOUGH." Not to call any weapons weak or overpowered but to put out there that some weapons are just too effective, and are overused. I quite dislike these weapons. When you hit the skill ceiling, in the right hands, these weapons have little limitations, extremely versatile, and are generally the top dog of the game. Arguing otherwise is rather silly. Which is why the Constitution is the best g- [i]*muffled screaming*[/i]

[b]Difficulty[/b]
When everyone catches on and use the "best" equipment? The game is trivial, even on the highest difficulty. Heck, even a regular team of four that knows what they're doing is cake. That's why you'll often see a lot of high levels run around with foreign loadouts you probably wouldn't dream of using. "Once you grow older, you'll understand why."

To us, we just want to have fun. We've already had our learning experience through a few hundred thousand missions. It's the "let's do the craziest things to challenge ourselves" point. Thus the game is balanced "enough." Weak weapons are fine as they are because it's fun. Not showing off, mum. Just don't want a routine.

Although, don't take what I said at face value. The game can be incredibly tough, especially without experience. Even for those with hundreds and thousands of hours, ...things happen... almost always.

[h1]Yay or nay?[/h1]
Like I said, if you don't like the gameplay, it will be not worth your time. It can be extremely repetitive if you can't find your own fun in it, but otherwise it is replayable. Personally, the biggest pull in for me is the community. I've added a lot of people over the few months I've been playing. It's very easy to organize games with familiar people to trust and fool around with. It's nice to slack off when the galaxy is in danger.

If you do want to purchase, do get the dlcs. Not only are they a huge addition, they also improve early game loadouts. So that you won't bore yourself out.

[h1]Very good example of a true 4 players co-op game done right.[/h1]

First and foremost: don't take the game too seriously as irony is everywhere and you will find yourself smiling most of the time, either to movie references or the ridiculous situations and outcomes of the various wars.
About wars: Helldivers is always played online and every player contributes actively to the progress of the current war against 3 alien races with unique perks and troops. The goal is to spread democracy (literally) by claiming sectors until you get to each of alien homeworlds and wipe them all out of existence. When you conquer a homeworld, the related alien race will no longer be available until the war is over and everything starts from the beginning in a neverending cycle.

The point of view is shared across the whole team, a welcome feature that alone forces players to actually coordinate as a squad, rather than allowing for the usual, egoistic solo-in-a-team approach typical of other similar titles.
The top-down shooter mechanics are perfectly integrated with the objective-based gameplay, so don't let screenshots fool you: the attention to details is outstanding (animations, weapons mechanics and so on) and shooting all sorts of enemies is extremely fun, but it's better to be sneaky and avoid open conflict for as much as possible (enemy spawns do not have a limit, so you can't actually "clear the map" from hostiles). On top of that, kills do not award experience, nor research points to upgrade your gear (exploration and objectives do).

Difficulty goes from Level 1 to 15 (a heaven/hell difference in terms of gameplay) so you can pretty much find the sweet spot for your capabilities and have fun, while learning the ropes or refining your skills and unlocking new stuff, avoiding excessive frustration (even when going solo if you don't feel like joining public teams).

You can extensively customize your Helldiver both aesthetically (gender and armor parts) and gameplay-wise (main weapon, stratagems and perks). There's a large selection of weapons (from SMGs to Sniper Rifles, including everything in-between with energy and plasma weapons too) and stratagems (air/artillery support of various types, turrets, decoys, tools, exosuits, vehicles and whatnot). Perks, on their end, give powerful passive bonuses and if that's not enough, all weapons and stratagems can be further improved in various ways via research points.

All in all, if you'll play it for a bit you'll slowly realize much thought went into this little gem of a game. 

Here, just to add some, alongside some tips:
- When you're bleeding out, team mates can actually shoot above you while you crawl to safety, same applies when you get to cover.
- Enemies have different armor values, some of them can't be damaged at all if not with anti-tank weaponry. Same goes for vehicles (the rule "front armor strong/rear and side armor weak" applies here as well)
- Heavy specialized weapons like rocket launchers come with a pack of dedicated ammo and benefit from a second squad member assisting with reloading said weapon ("assisted reload").
- Aiming at specific parts of larger enemies results in different outcomes depending on the weapon: ignoring the obvious "weak spots" on some of them, generally speaking if you shoot straight at an enemy's torso/head you will deal way more damage than normal. Also, mind the angle of impact of bullets when shooting to maximize your damage output.
- Maps' features are not to underestimate: snow and water can and will slow you down, bottomless pits are lethal (there are no invisible walls to prevent you from falling).
- Enemy scouts will ping your location to nearby troops and call reinforcements continuously if there's none in the general area. If you kill the scouts before they spot you or before they update your location to the rest of the enemies and get some distance, you can go back to sneaking around.
- When calling support gear and stratagems, the laser pointer shooting toward the sky will attract enemy patrols.
- Falling pods (support gear/reinforcements) will kill anything directly below them. The shuttle for extraction is no exception, be sure to clear the landing area or you'll be crushed right at the end of the mission.

[b]Introduction[/b]
Helldivers is a top down objective based shooter, with an emphasis on team-based strategy.

[b]Game-play[/b][list]
[*] Helldivers is a highly lethal game, that encourages players to crank the difficulty as high as they can handle. The game strongly emphasizes multiplayer play, and the game runs a campaign that combines all the points that players earn throughout the community to fight a living war against 3 seperate factions.
[*] Helldivers relies on skill based gameplay, using the correct type of equipment during a situation is more important than leveling up which gives you more selection of equipment (but no skills)
[*] With three types of foes, boss battles, vehicle piloting and a plethora of weapons, playing has opportunity to become varied
[*] Stealth is somewhat of an important aspect of hell divers, each faction has scout units that will set off an alert a few seconds after they draw a line of sight to you, as well as roving patrols of enemies. Thus the name of the game becomes fast and hard. Move objective to objective as quickly as possible and kill any enemy that hinders you doing so.
[/list]

[b]Sound[/b][list]
[*]  The game’s strategic nature causes sound to be mostly used for finding patrols. Therefore in someways it is a little lackluster. The soundtrack consists of military marches and a little ambiance mostly. But you have the option of in game voice commands and there is a little voice acting.
[*] I would say the soundtrack is the weakest point of this game, as the gameplay and visuals are both extremely solid.
[/list]

[b] Visual [/b][list]
[*] The game’s visuals are enjoyable and convey the effects appropriately from electrical Tesla towers to laser rifles, explosions and toxin throwers. Can’t complain.
[/list]

[b]Conclusion (TL;DR)[/b]
I find there isn’t a lot to say about Helldivers. At its core its driven by game-play, graphics and sound take a slight back-seat to the gameplay. I highly recommend this game to anybody. The only time I would suggest someone not get this is if online multiplayer doesn’t appeal to them.

NOTE: I chose to do this review now, because just recently it received an update! I find it extremely satisfying when a developer releases even small content updates to show they haven’t forgotten people who supported their release.

ALSO NOTE: I made sure to play a bit of the game since the new update. I still find lots of games and the player base is still going strong.

Helldivers is a skill based twin-stick shooter where you go up against 3 radically different alien factions with up to 4 players with any mix of online or local co-op featuring realistic military themed weapons, tactical strategic options, and friendly fire.

It is set in a dystopian future where players fight to protect [b]Super Earth[/b] where the Helldivers are the last line of defense to help in the Spread of Managed Democracy. The game doesn't feature a typical campaign story as it follows an endless design where it gives a brief intro and then lets the player play at their pace, picking from 1 of 12 (now 15) difficulties in up to 3 different war fronts.

It is only by completing proceduraly generated missions and conquering planets that players collectively push back against the enemy factions away from [b]Super Earth[/b] and towards their respective home worlds. If the players can reach and defeat any of the enemy factions, those enemy factions are out of the game until only [b]Super Earth[/b] remains. Conversely if players are unable to keep any enemy faction away, they can initiate an attack on [b]Super Earth[/b] and blow it up. In either scenario, after a brief cinematic and some global war statistics, immediately as one war ends, another begins and the cycle continues.

The progression system used by the game uses both XP earned as well as accomplishment based unlocks and on-mission sample gathering to help upgrade various options in their arsenal. Leveling up by XP is based on completing objectives within missions which lead the player through a series of military ranks starting from Recruit all the way up to [b]Admiral of Super Earth[/b]. A player doesn't get stronger (so this is not an action-RPG), just gets different ranks keeping with the military theme and has access to some weapons and options that a starting player may not.

Along the way earning new Ranks, the player will unlock additional Primary Weapon options, Perk options, and cosmetic Outfits.

The accomplishment based unlocks have to do with completing planets across the full spectrum of difficulty the game offers. Combined together each Helldiver quickly accumulates a massive collection of loadout options.

The additional options aren't necessarily better as much as just different since there is a strong attempt by the developers to give everything pros and cons in an attempt to keep things generally well balanced. What this does is allow new players to play with more veteran players and the more significant difference between the players will always remain about skill, not progression.

In addition to all the base game content and continued developer support to grant players additional free DLC content, they also released a couple of free major expansions to the game adding in new Bosses (called Masters), a Horde variant mission type (called Retaliatory Strikes), and additional enemy units and objectives that can show up on missions. All these free additions have been complimented with a wide assortment of paid DLC options that provide players even more options for their loadouts. Indeed, many favored items seen in frequent use by players are from one of these paid DLC packs.

For myself, I have found all the paid DLC options to be worthwhile additions. Some more than others, but no regrets on any of those DLC pack purchases. It may seem like a lot if you are just now looking at the game, but I have been playing the game since it first released in March, 2015 on PlayStation and it may help you to know that the wide selection has grown over time as the developers continue to support while players continue to play and enjoy.

I decided to get the game again on Steam from scratch once it became available here and I continue to play on both platforms because I have made different friends I like to continue playing more with on both platforms. Steam and Playstation players cannot play with each other (no cross-play), but the Galactic Campaign of players vs the enemy factions in a global co-op campaign is shared between the two platforms.

Helldivers is an excellent arcade strategic shoot-em-up, which sounds like a mouthful, easy to pick up and set down at any time of the year. It offers both surface-level fun, easy to complete a few missions in under half an hour, and high skill scenarios that can up to an hour and a half to complete, depending how methodical you are. Additionally, the game is loved by its developers, and has seen numerous DLC's and updates since its release, often going on sale throughout the year. In addition, every "Liberty Day" is celebrated in one way or another.

Pros:
Easy to jump into at a moments notice
Having trouble? Call in backup by asking other players to dive into your game, and offer their own equipment for the cause after you've already started.
In-depth progression, with an absolutely massive set of weapons and tech that you can take.
Several vehicles and turrets, that fel extremely rewarding to master.
Practically every stratagem can be upgraded in some sense, and the process to both obtain and use the upgrade currency is extremely easy.
Little penalty for failing part of the mission, allowing you to still escape at the end with the loot and rewards, to a lessened degree.

Cons:
The difficulty scales very rapidly, going from a mission that is easy to solo while eating some random junk food lying around, to having your eyes glued on the screen a mere two difficulty levels higher.
Enemy detection range makes it incredibly difficult to do any kind of stealth operations, typically forcing you to always have to build your character heavy.
Slow turning rates make it so aiming can be a bit of a slog while trying to pinpoint an enemy from accross the screen, but this also makes it very rewarding when getting these long-distance shots. It's bothersome for me personally, but I cannot say it will affect everyone like it does me.
No way to link directly to someone's steam profile, so finding a friend in game becomes a tedious process of trading usernames and describing your profile picture.

Helldivers has always been one of my favorite games to, well, just dive into at a moments notice. Easy to jump into, easy to drag my friends into, and because its on sale so much, easy to find tons of new people to play it with via the S.O.S. beacon. I 100% recommend this to skilled, and unskilled players alike. I, myself, am excited to try the new difficulty settings and weapon!

A must-have coop game if you liked any of developer's other games (like Magicka and Gauntlet). I would say it's their best game yet, or at least the most refined. If you're looking for a solid coop game with depth, many difficulty levels, lots of enemies, vehicles (three different MECHS!), equipment and weapons,  that you can pretty much always play online, then I can't recommend Helldivers enough. The theme (?) of the game, that's reminiscent of Starship Troopers is just icing on the cake, but oh is it tasty. The over-the-top cheeky taunts the characters make and the various story/flavour texts are pretty entertaining to hear/read.

You don't need friends (;_;) to enjoy playing this, playing it with random players is perfectly fine. There are always a couple games up, even in crazy hours and  the game is still healthy online thanks to the constant wars. The playerbase is overall good (especially on lower levels where people are still learning), of course there are toxic players (like in every multiplayer game), but since it's a coop game, I find that people tend to work together rather than against each other. Finding someone toxic is rare and there's always the option to host a game for yourself and remove whoever you don't like or just simply report them.
The upgrade/leveling system is fun, always gives you something to unlock/reach, until you unlocked all the upgrades you could, leaving only your rank. You get more rewards for finishing more difficult missions. There are 3 races to wage war against and deliver them the glorious invention of mankind, freedom and liberty. Other than the normal missions there are even bosses that you can fight for each race. This game is meant to be played around one TV set, with controllers and perhaps some beverage. 

Most of the entertainment value of this game lies within its ability to "generate chaotic moments". 

Every bit of Helldivers wants you to go ransacking some enemy planet and then suddenly all hell breaks loose: there's an alert and enemies start swarming you without end. You throw grenades at your friends, you yell your comrades to duck as your auto-minigun opens fire over them, you catch fire, someone drives off the cliff, you die with reinforcement stratagem in your hand: suddenly everyone is back. This is a social game.

I suggest wishlisting and waiting for a sale so you get the "everything" pack, as grinding the stuff isn't what the game is about. It's about you and your friends using all kinds of experimental weaponry to fail missions.

Did I mention friends?

Others, with a lot more hours clocked in, have already written elaborate reviews on why you should (or shouldn't) buy this game, so there is little left for me to add.

Verdict: Highly recommended with all DLCs (e.g. Deluxe Edition) on sale.

EDIT: For those interested in the multiplayer aspects: The average player-base seems to be on a dwindling trend (e.g. currently between 40 and 180 depending on the time of day). You can check steamdb.info to find the times when there are the most people. Player counts seem to spike around the October sale. I hope the developers will add more enemies/DLCs to re-kindle interest in the game.

Pros:
- The controls are simple.
- The combat is great.
- The graphics are pleasing.
- The goal of the game is inspiring and unifying, to the point that you actually want to fight every day and try to drive away the alien scum from the galaxy.
- It gets absolutely hilarious as squadmates can accidentally and randomly kill each other by shooting, bombing and crushing each other through drop-pods.
- The weapon and perk/ability choices are satisfying and keep changing how you experience gameplay.

Cons:
- It gets repetitive as there are only a few kinds of missions to complete. Different planets have different missions to each other, but if you play the same planet you'll definitely do the same missions you just did. Changing the difficulty ups the action, thrill and hilarity, but also increases the desperation of needing squadmates - making it alsmot impossible to play at times if you don't have suqadmates.
- You cannot play if you can't get online - which is generally understandable, but there should be an option to have a custom offline game against a species of  your choice etc - like a skirmish mode in RTS games.
- There are no bots/Ai/computer controlled squadmates that you could take into missions with you, so you end up needing other people online to join your game.
- The accidental and random killing of squadmates can make strategic plays into absolute chaos, turn victories into defeats or cause people to rage quit or become rude.
- The part of the screen you are viewing is shared with the 3 other people playing with you so your vision can be greatly reduced or altered if someone goes to an edge and you're not with them. This is one thing I would definitely want to see changed, so each player has the whole screen to themselves.

I would still recommend the game as it is to everyone. It's a fun, unique, well designed and thrilling gaming experience.

P.S. I definitely recommend buying the Ranger Pack DLC along with the game, to get the ‘Humblebee’ UAV as a perk/ability - It's an Unmanned Aerial Vehicle, capable of revealing enemies and hidden objectives at greater distances, and really helps find samples quickly and easily.

Helldivers, in short, is basically Magicka with guns and tanks. You may think that makes the game sound lazy or bad, but that would be far from the truth: it's excellent. The gameplay is well done and the humor still hasn't lost all of its charm, and the thrill of running and blasting everything with a bunch of friends and randoms online to ruin the alien hive is still awesome.

Helldivers, like its progenators, is a twin-stick shooter that allows you to combine inputs to use special "spells", or in this case, air supply drops in things like LMGs, tanks, or nukes. The gameplay is well done, and you will often go on missions online, joining in with up to three other commandos. While it's been a long time since I've played, servers were doing well when I did, and the game really comes into its own awesome, team-killing joy with a full team.

The music is great and as cheesy as it has to be, the heroic/hammy shouts of the characters are as the music, and the game itself looks pretty good. There's no story, except "you are space America, go liberate the dirty aliens", which is good enough for a few laughs and to go punch aliens.

If the game has any flaws, it's that the voices can get stale after long enough, and that it suffers from a significant portion of content behind DLC or grinding for equipment... but the game is still great without those anyways. Any game that gives me caped protagonists with cool helmet visors in space with guns is good in my book. Helldivers is an excellent experience whether or not you've also tried Magicka, and it's at its best when played with plenty of chaotic friends, rammed in a corner frantically shooting incoming xeno bugs. 8.5/10.
Kill lots of teammates and you become.... real HELLDIVER. ;) wink

Helldivers is a stange game.

It's advertised as a twinstick shooter, but instead of having the fast twitchy action the genre is known for, it seems to focus on  large stretches of semi-stealth with small arena sections a few times within the level.

The stealth mechanic fo this game is that levels spawn with only groups of low health "patrol" enemies. If these are allowed to see you, they can spawn the medium and heavy level enemies, as well as drasically speeding up additional patrol enemies. 

It is possible to "full stealth" and not even fight the patrols, but most players seem to like semi-stealth - it's possible to burst down the patrols at long range, allowing players to achieve constant motion from objective to objective. This would make the game too easy, but it compensates a little bit with it's "shared screen scrolling" mechanic. Although this can be a disaster in games like Gauntlent (where a slower player can get pinned and everyone else has to go behind the wall to get him unstuck) the screen scrolling in this game seems to avoid this pitfall, and does a good job with its intended purpose of keeping some of the patrols alive to summon the actual enemies. 

The game has 3 alien factions to fight, each of which feel fairly different to fight against, especially because the patrols are some of the most drastically different enemies for each of the races. It has mostly seamless drop-in and drop-out co-op, and can even migrate hosts (usually). I bought it with the intent only to play with a small friend group, but public games turned out to be about 3/4 of my playtime. 

One of the game's stranger mechanics is the implementation of "armored" enemies - Medium enemies tend to have damage reduction except from certain angles. Certain designiated tank enemies are semi-immune to anything put the largest weapons. Generally, tanks are dangerous because anti-tank weapons can not be used as primaries, requiring some of the group tp put one in their special weapon slot (and even then multiple tanks can spawn at a time and long reload) Tanks do a good job of preventing overuse of easy to aim and wide arc weapons such as miniguns and shotguns. However, they also mean that their is a hard limit to playing the game as a "loud" group. It can be survived for a good amount of time, up to about 1:30 - 2 minutes, but continually fighting and spawning more enemies will eventually force players into a "runaway or die" scenario. 

The trailers heavily focus on multiplayer shenangians, and in-game, teamates are usually much more danagerous than enemies. Friendly fire is an inevitability, but the game is pretty gentle with it's regenerating health and respawn mechanic, so it's possible to shrug off a small amount of the friendly fire, while the times you are one hit killed by badly aimed rocket launchers or supply drops are also manage. 

Besides the standard missions, there are also retalitaory stirkes, and boss battles.  The former is a fight in a small arena about 1.5 screens wide, with enemies spawning at a high rate. Boss battles take place in arenas about 3 screens wide. Despite how small these two are, they can easily last equally long to normal maps, as Retalitoary strikes have high kill requirements, and bosses can get out of hand when first playing against them. Retalitory strikes are decent fun as arena missions, but the arena setup invites more direct comparision to normal twinstick shooters, and helldivers cannot compete against in the context of doing the same thing as them. 2 of the bosses (cyborg and bug) are easily avoided health tanks where the real threat is spawned minions. The third boss (illuminate) Is extremely annoying and seems like it was designed for a game with different movement physics. A bullet pattern boss is great in smash tv or binding of issac, but not really suited toward this game. 

The game's weakness is repetiveness. Their are only 3 meaningful missions types (normal, retaltiory, boss) and of those, only normal missions are particualrlly engaging. The semi-stealth is far too easy to optimize if playing solo, and although it can be tempting to do so to speed up the proggresion system, it is generally unfufilling. Multiplayer carries the game extremely hard, but can run into the same problem --- A well-oiled group can run into the same problem, particualrly if multiple people bring things like tesla towers or Napalm --- In some cases, even a single player bringing a distraction beacon can keep a lvl 1-15 (out of 50) group out of real combat for an entire mission on the highest difficulty. 

When a patrol does go off, it's severity again depends on the group - if somebody instantly airstrikes it, a single alarm going off hardly matters - it's only when they start chaining off of each other that they are really fun. However, when first learning the game, the patrols can appear too powerful - because every alarm spawns more patrols in addition to fighting units , you can get caught by large numbers if you remain in one area, with each spawning between 3-4 units.  So, the game kind of scares new players into playing too much stealth early on. However, the amount of fun to be had with the game depends on staying away from stealth as long as possible. 

Personality wise - the game tries some pretty decent satire of an overly trigger happy first world democracy with fascist overtones. It's pretty funny, but is almost entirely contained in the opening cutscenes and the crazy in-level dialuge. Player charathers can shout "Have a Taste of Democracy!" while firing their guns. and so on. Although what we get is good, I kind of wish it did a little bit more... it lacks the satiric edge something like Chester Williams:Super Cop has, and the setting does feel like it could go a little further... I thin there's an implication that the WMD's that the aliens are holding are a pretense and that the humans are the real aggresors, but the game doesn't have a further comment. The game's setup also keeps the aliens races weirdly zoned off from each other at all times. No word if they're united against humanity, or also fight each other. 

I like the idea of the game, but after 20-30 hours, you should be able to survive both the single player and multiplayer versions of the hardest difficulty for each of the three alien factions, and will have probbably done all the bosses as well. I think further multiplayer could give you a bit more, but it would  require a group commiting to using the bad/joke weapons or intentionally setting off alarms to make the game more exciting. However, for me, I don't really have much drive to keep playing the game. I'm going to try for one more big MP session with the friends I originally purchased the game to play with, and then I'll be more than ready to uninstall.

Really fun game to play with friends, since it emphasises teamwork to achieve mission success. Playable solo as well, though you will be restricted to certain loadouts and it will likely be tougher than playing with a team (unless your team sucks as well, then too bad). 
There's a very large selection of weapons and strategems to suit your playstyle, and you can get surprised as to how well certain weapons work on certain situations.
You get to fight against 3 different enemy races: Cyborgs, Bugs, and Illuminates. Each race has their own unique set of enemy types, and will require different strategies to tackle.
There's also multiple maps to fight on: Desert, Volcano, Forest, and Snow. Each map comes with its own environmental hazards, which will keep you on your toes (as if you don't already have to around your fellow Helldivers and enemies).

As with any game, there are some issues as well. Enemy position/spawn and AI bugs are common when playing online, and sometimes the game can lag so bad that you see players and enemies teleporting all over the place, or you get hit by stuff that you seemingly avoided.
You can get randomly disconnected as well, especially at the results stage, even after you've been in the same room for tens of minutes, which means you lose all progress unless the game kindly saved said progress for you.
Since the game uses a Peer to Peer network configuration, it's too bad that you can't restrict your matchmaking region when hosting to mitigate said issues, and even if you join a game that's in your region, you can still unfortunately face those problems.

Even with those problems, I would still recommend this game to anyone nonetheless. It's a very well-made top-down twin-stick shooter with almost endless replayability till you get bored of it, in which case just taking a break will most likely wear it off.

Brutally challenging fun... you share a certain bond with your teammates after attempting a challenging mission for the 50th time, each time evoking the same grim determination it often takes to succeed in this game. The gameplay rewards tight teamplay above all else, and you are punished for every little mistake you make (like bumping into a moving vehicle, trying to get out of a vehicle while its moving in your direction etc.) but it never feels cheap, which is key to these types of games. The stratagems offer a cool layer to the gameplay, forcing you to tap out sometimes long and confusing key combos in order to call in supplies, weaponry, airstrikes etc. which are necessary for the harder difficulties. 
The fact that everything is wrapped up in a constantly shifting persistent war for galactic dominance (and survival) against several other factions just makes it even better. Sometimes, events will also take place which will require the entire community's efforts to overcome and they add a further sense of tension.  Overall the game is fun and rewarding along with some of the nicest players I've met in an online game.

This is the modern take on the classic twin-stick. Twin-sticks have always been about mayhem, and bullet hell-like swarms of enemies. This game embraces that, says, 'what if we added friendly fire and quick respawns' then threw in three varied races to combat. Sure, there's a learning curve, since you have to keep from wasting precious magazines by way of constantly calling in more or just avoiding dropping it all, but that's part of what makes the tension of the game so good. And not to mention getting blown apart by the random player that happened to answer your distress beacon and promptly called down an airstrike on your location. No, seriously, that's just part of the game. But you get used to it, have a laugh, then wait for him to drop a beacon for you to get summoned back in on top of the giant bug that his airstrike was supposed to hit, taking it out in the process of putting you back in the game. It's awesome. 12/10 must play with strangers again.

[b]Promising Mechanics Squandered[/b]

I want to be able to recommend Helldivers. I love the co-op squad setup, and the variety of useful gear. I even like the little DDR-style minigame for activating abilities which is harder for stronger abilities. The three enemy factions are cosmetically and mechanically interesting. As a basic concept, I loved it.

Unfortunately, the game suffers from a few absolutely crippling problems.

First, there is virtually no content beyond what's required to make the game work. If you've seen a mid-level planet from a faction, you've basically seen everything that faction has to throw at you other than a few "endgame" few holdouts. You can experience all the content in the game in at most three sessions.

Second, the game never progresses other than weapon unlocks.  I used quotes around "endgame" advisedly. Helldivers doesn't have a plot (or story of any kind), characters, or even a setting other than space and fight stages. Since there's no story, the game cannot progress or evolve, and no matter how much you play the game, the universe stays the same. You can go through the same three stages over and over at various difficulties with very slightly altered objectives, but that's it.

Third, the entire online mechanic is awful. It seems like it's the result of a marketing idea gone wrong. In this basically unchanging world, everybody who beats a level contributes to this online overall war against the enemies of Earth. Of course, nothing really changes other than a graphic depiction of the galaxy divided into territories under various faction control. Everybody who plays the game shares the map. If you buy the game today, you'll enter the game at whatever point it has currently progressed to in the community. At certain critical thresholds, the progress map resets for everyone in the world simultaneously, and you start back at the starting planets. Of course, you can scarcely tell the starting planet levels from the others, so this is a meaningless event.

Unfortunately, [i]Helldivers[/i] revolves around a static world where the only "progress" is a map controlled by the world at large. There's no real sense of progress, and weapon unlocks don't count. So maybe one day someone will make it into a real game, but it feels half-baked to me.

Helldivers is an ineteresting game. For one, It has been around for quite some time, and I have only joined fairly recently, so I would say it has held up to the test of time very well. However, it would seem that the game is finished being updated other than to stamp out bugs, so what you see is what you get.

You start out with a small arsenal to choose from. Your loadout consists of a perk, a primary weapon, and 4 strategems. Your perk can affect anything from the speed you move to the sidearm you hold, so it is very versatile, and very important. Your primary weapon is what you are holding when you spawn in. There are essentially two types of primaries, projectile and energy. I don't know the exact values, but it seems as though projectiles have more firepower, but require more ammo. The opposite is true for energy weapons, as they technically have infinite ammo. As long as you don't continually fire the energy weapons for too long, you can keep using the same "heat dumps" in your energy weapons. Too much continual firing and the weapons overheat, their heat dumps automatically eject. For a long time I preferred energy weapons, but recently I converted to projectile as I started playing with randoms online, so it changes from person to person. Strategems are the most important part of the game. Strategems include vehicles/mechs, ordinance, Support drones, artillery support, etc. The catch is you have to find a lull in the endless combat in order to type in the code to call in each specific strategem. This can be challenging, but to me is what makes the game great.

The galactic campaign has grown on me since I began playing, but I still don't necessarily "love" it. Essentially, you have 3 enemy factions to deal with at the start of every war. The community of Helldivers works together to push the enemies back to their home worlds. In each system, there are 12(?) different planets of increasing difficulty. Different difficulties offer different rewards, and different factions offer different rewards as well. The problem I have with this is that sometimes a war is finished with a faction before I am ever able to join in, and so I miss out on the rewards until next season. Most of the time this isn't a huge issue, but last season we defeated 2/3 of the factions and lingered on the last one for weeks. I played a bit to level up but had no way to obtain any new strategems for a couple weeks.

Overall this game is a lot of fun. Bring a buddy, or don't. I've had mostly good experiences with the community. Often times I will recieve help from players who have reached the maximum level, they are all really nice and respect the difficulty curve for newer players. For me, Helldivers is a good 7/10.
Unforgiving, but oh so fun.
