[h1]Democracy in Action[/h1]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1276508000
Super-Earth, our home. You’re going to get extremely tired of hearing that every single time you load up Helldivers, but I can tell you that you’ll never get tired of relentlessly massacring foes in the name of democracy. Helldivers is a game that flew well beneath my radar for a criminally long period of time, but now that I finally picked this gem up I’ve had some of the most co-op fun since the release of Magicka. I bring Magicka up because there’s a plethora of similarities between the two games, and Helldivers often makes me feel like I’m playing a Warhammer 40K version of Magicka. What impresses me though is that it draws upon elements from Magicka, it does so in a way that doesn’t actually feel like it’s doing so, instead taking the idea and making it into its own. I like that they’ve expanded on this genre of sorta-but-also-not-co-op, with mechanics like team killing that spice up the co-op experience with a bit of humor and organicality. That’s the most important aspect to a game like this, it needs to have mechanics in place that allow organic situations to foster, otherwise you’ll just run out of content to play through and face burnout. Thankfully, Helldivers does this wonderfully and allows for each run to be ever so slightly different than the last so as to keep you playing for the experience and not just to run through the content. This isn’t to imply that there’s some sort of content drought in Helldivers and there isn’t enough for you to play but, as with any game, regardless of how much there is, you’re going to eventually run out of content. Helldivers doesn’t face that problem because it doesn’t rely so heavily on using the content itself as anything more than a backdrop to your experience, like other games may. It’s a simple game with simple mechanics more than anything, and from those simple mechanics the devs have managed to create an extremely tactical yet, at times, extremely friendship destroying game.

[h1]Randomness and Replayability[/h1]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1276506448
 As I said the game itself is relatively simple, with each mission consisting of a number of objectives, increasing along with the difficulty, and ending in your extraction. This is just about the only part of the missions that’ll remain the same, experiences tending to differ wildly based on a multitude of factors like enemies faced, equipment brought along, or who you choose to play with. When it comes to equipment you can bring, there’s a king’s ransom from which to make a selection, from laser shotguns to anti-material rifles, even to beacons for calling in a thermobaric rocket strike, you’re never going to be short of ways to bring justice to the undemocratic. The weapons are all extremely enjoyable both in their names and their functions and feature a full upgrade tree with at least two significant advancements for each weapon. Some of these enhancements can literally turn weapons from useless to critical, all just with a few research points, hard-earned from sample-gathering. Gathering samples is your main way of acquiring upgrade points, though you do get one per level-up, but not only do those become increasingly sparse as the game progresses, one research point simply isn’t that much. Really you get samples by finding them scattered throughout each mission, finding up to 15 or 16 on some of the harder missions. I like how hard they are to find, it makes them satisfying and rewarding as well as providing nice little side “objectives” as it were for you to look for in between the main ones. The main objectives are all unique, and they differ based on which race you’re fighting at the time, sometimes you’ll be neutralizing a minefield and other times you’ll be setting up and performing environmental scans. I like the variety, each mission has randomized objectives so you’ll rarely ever get the exact same ones as last time, and each objective requires a fair bit of teamwork, but can be soloed in some cases as well. Not only do I appreciate the variety, but I also appreciate that these missions require a division of labor amongst your team. You can’t have everyone doing the objective, at least one some of them, you need to have some people on constant guard for patrols and some actually performing whatever the objective may be. This teamplay coupled with the random drop-in system makes for an incredible social experience as well, since you’ll be not only meeting new people, but engaging in almost team-building exercises as well. That sounds a bit odd, but that’s kinda what I can liken the gameplay to: a big team-building exercise where you and your friends get together and attempt to solve various objectives without getting pissed and murdering each other. 

[h1]Home-Grown Gameplay[/h1]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1276505519
I’ve talked a lot about the missions and the social aspects present in Helldivers, but now I’d like to get into more of the mechanics and content. Helldivers has a real focus on diversity in your equipment, giving you dozens of different weapons and almost a hundred different stratagems to use with the most prejudice possible. I’m in love with all the different stratagems there are and how absurdly fun they can be to wield, ranging from small tactical barbed wire and ammunition drops all the way to massive mechanized war machines and tactical missiles. There’s so many of them and they’re all so fun to use that I often find myself going through a crisis in the loading screen, not knowing which of the fantastic abilities I’d like to take along for the ride. The same goes for the weapons; they’re all satisfying and extremely reactive to use, and oddly I sometimes found myself opening fire even when nothing was there, just to feel the recoil and hear the impact. What’s impressive to me is that the stratagems and weapons seem to all have a place, and I’m often rotating them out to fit whatever the current situation is, which seems to be an organic way to get players to experience all the content your game has to offer. That’s a perfect way to describe Helldivers: it’s organic. Everything, from the situations you encounter in-mission to the weapons that you equip and even the outfit you choose to wear, it’s all organically determined. You might be fighting armored enemies and adapt to the situation with offensive stratagems like a tank-buster turret, or you may be in a winter environment so you switch to an arctic cloak. No matter how small, every little thing is determined by the situations in which you find yourself, meaning that you’ll be playing Helldivers for hours on end, annihilating both boredom and the enemies of democracy with extreme prejudice. 

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
You can spread democracy a million different ways, but Helldivers by far has the best one. Hilarity and badassery go hand in hand, making for a fantastic team-based experience like no other.

In a dystopian future, mankind wages a never ending war against 3 alien races to defend the glory that is Super Earth. You are a Helldiver, using an arsenal of weapons and air strikes with ungodly power to spread Democracy and Freedom accross the galaxy. The first time you and 3 other Helldivers unleash a bullet storm of Justice into the face of a seemingly insurmountable wave of enemies, and help Liberate them from their bodies, you can't help but crack a smile.

Simply put, it's one of the greatest co-op (online and local) games ever made.  There are so many options as to how you can approach each mission, the game never gets old.  The game can be as hard or as easy as you want to make it.  Play solo and farm samples, or team up and tackle harder planets.  A team of 4 grizzled vets can make a level 12 Helldive look easy, then get destroyed on a level 6 planet due to a misplaced stratagem call down and some not so friendly fire.  All 3 races are fun to play against, and you have to adjust your playstyle accordingly.  

This is also one of the few games that does DLC right.  None of it is needed to reach the end game, but it is fun to use and can breathe some new life into the game once you become the epitome of Super Earth.  Yes, the boots DLC is great, but it wastes your Perk slot and it does nothing that a jet pack or vehicle can't do.

Greetings Everyone!  Today I will be reviewing Helldivers a twin-stick shooter that has been on my radar for a bit now thanks to my desire for quick games and co-op.  As you may be able to tell I’ve only played the game for about two hours and did request a refund.  But, is this a game you should put your time into?

Become a Legend:  As stated above this game is a twin-stick shooter where you aim with one ‘stick’ and move with another.  These were very popular is old arcades and in co-op circles of the early generations of online consoles.  There is controller support (which I find essential for a game like this) and the replay ability of the game comes from leveling and trying out different combos.  The story is far from forgettable but don’t let that fool you into some epic narrative.  The story is based around humanity basically sending ‘democracy’ to the galaxy at the end of a gun…or a few million of them.  The enemy factions are all characterized as pacifist alien species that are somehow violent.  If you can’t tell it is a very tongue in cheek with a slap of ‘Team America’ and Starship Troopers thrown in.

So lonely:  In my opinion this game lives and dies based off the online community; thankfully this game still has one.  All the players I played with were friendly and at least communicated to some degree; increasing the fun of the game.  But sadly, after a few levels I saw really what the game was:  An arcade twin-stick shooter where the enjoyment was solely dependent on the community but otherwise honestly being rather shallow.  You play one mission you’ve played them all as there are limited objectives and the enemies are not super varied inside each faction and there just doesn’t seem to be much variety in playing styles to choose from as I felt some guns were just objectively better than others and the people I played with seemed to agree by their choices as well.

PC Mastery:  My understanding is this game originally came out on consoles and later on PC, which makes sense as this game feels more at home with a controller than a keyboard and mouse.  With that said they really should have done more to make the controls more refined for the PC as they are a bit of nightmare.  This is almost immediately resolved by simply plugging a controller in but feels this should be stated none the less.  The game didn’t seem to have any bugs that I noticed but I found myself annoyed by the lack of any real innovation, it seems like they just ported a stick shooter for an arcade machine with better graphics.  Finally, a decent amount of the game’s options are locked behind DLCs that admittedly aren’t that expensive but still annoyed me as I felt the game really isn’t up to snuff without them.

So, twin-stick shooters are a lot of fun with people.  If you have a few friends wanting to get this I think it would be a great addition.  However, alone is a no go unless you love meeting new people 10 minutes at a time.  I will say I did have a good time with mine and glad the game at least carried the parties from mission to mission.  Overall, it is really up to you, I requested a refund because none of my friends seem interested and didn’t see myself spending a lot of time on this game verse my other hobbies.  Regardless of what you decided, enjoy as always.

Game has a loadout system with different guns, stratagem and perks. Loadouts are effective especially when tailored for specific enemy type/worlds and mission difficulty. 

Guns are plenty but most are trash and players will often find themselves sticking to a specific for each of the weapon types. Standard fare of action shooter weapons with lasers and conventional shotguns and auto rifles. 

Stratagems are called in via CTRL key and WASD key. Call in fire support from artillery to orbital lasers and personal equipment like shields, anti tank rockets or jump packs.

Perks affect your character's survivability, stratagem cooldown or deployment and equipment like stun grenades. 

Friendly fire is deadly and often laughably absurd. Drop pods are a serious threat to both friend and foe.

Very easy to level up and attain mission/planet specific rewards in equipment and stratagems. Thankfully it's only late game cosmetics that are hidden behind the grind wall. 

Enemies come in three types. Cyborgs, Illuminates and Bugs. Has both strenth and weaknesses to weapon types and stratagems so adjust loadouts accordingly. 

Game has a campaign event targeting one of the specific enemies every few days or depending on how fast the overall multiplayer progress goes. The campaign and game in general reminds the players of introducing "Freedom" to these enemy regions.

Good gunplay and the impact of having the right stratagem, perks and aiming feels satisfying. 

Overall, a fun game to be hold your attention for a couple of weeks or so.  Good blend of overly militaristic humors with responsive gameplay.

My previous review reflected my experience with the game. Unable to play, no answers from support. 
Since then, the bug or problem that was ruining matchmaking has been fixed, so it's now easy to find matches again. 
So, bugs apart and old problems solved, the game itself is a good offering, specially if you enjoy playing games with friends. You control your soldier and have to do missions "fighting for Democracy" in space. You can do them alone or with friends in squads of 4, matchmaking itself is good and fast to find you a game to join. Each mission drop offers a sequence of different field objectives that you then need to endure and fullfill, fighting hordes of enemies trying to stop you. There are 3 different enemy factions, with different units and abilities. Each of those races has a home planet. Progress is linear, you progress through missions untill you get to that home planet and defeat them. While you can individually choose your next missions for you or your squad, the meta goal comes in the form of a war event with community goals. It will be the overall gathered results of all missions played by individual players to dictate if the community won, or lost the war for democracy.  
 As soon as a war cycle ends, a new one begins. Each time you can either win in spreadintg democracy to all the alien worlds, of get defeated and extinguished, as aliens conquer our home planet. 
Individually, as a player, you control your character in a top-down view, you can choose your loadout before each missions, and gained XP allows you to unlock better weapons, armor and equipment for your soldier. The game is light, fun and easy to understand, requires some skill and good timing analysis to decide when to use what from your inventory. 
All in all, I'll finish as I started. If you have friends to play with, it can be quite fun. If not, you can still have fun while matchmaking with randoms, since there is a rating system for players, and generally people are friendly and do try to play the game the right way. See a few videos to check if you like the type of gameplay.

My pod touched down with a thud barely audible to me through the reinforced and shielded hull.  The red light on my command console blinked at me. It was ever so subtly speeding up, telling me that in a few seconds the doors above me would open and I would be amongst my Helldiver squad... spreading Democracy at 200 rounds per minute.  I readied my MG-105 Stalwart squad automatic weapon, giving it one last check to make sure it would dispense freedom reliably.  It would be my first line of offence and my last line of defense against the bugs we were here to squish.
  
The red light was faster now... and slowly turning green.  I knew when the green light lit and the alarm went off, I would be in combat.  My auditory amplifier was coming live and I could hear the muffled sounds of gunfire above me.  Yes, there was Democracy to spread this day.  My heart was pounding at the chance to convert Super Earth's enemies yet again.  At once, the light turned green and the doors flew open.  I pushed up hard with my legs and my rocket assist boots kicked in, propelling me up and away from my pod.
  
The sound of gunfire was at once deafening and exhilarating.  The world seemed to explode around me.  The dopamine injectors kicked into full forward and my eyes lit up with a lust for blood and violence the likes of which have not been seen since Travis found that box of gerbils back in middle school.  I brought my Stalwart up and trained my sights on a wall of bugs moving towards my position.
  
As I squeezed the trigger and began to feel the climactic rush of Democracy about to leave the barrel, I noticed a 6-sided shadow around me, growing larger.  I looked up in time to see the bottom of the next Helldiver's pod racing towards me at 1000 meters per second.  I was about to take a full load of freedom right in my face... and it was magical.  I had time only to hit the "max" button on my dopamine regulator and feel the explosion in my veins as the pod crashed through me and into the ground, letting the next Democracy dispenser begin his mayhem.

10/10 – Would get crushed by my friends in the name of freedom and Democracy again.

Helldivers is a tongue in cheek mixture of Judge Dread, Starship Troopers, and some Orwellian nightmare made real.  You play a raw recruit that will die, over and over again to fight in the war against the bugs, the borgs, and the squids.  In the 2 hours I have on record so far, the game has made me laugh out loud, sit on the edge of my seat, smile like an idiot, and just about rage quit.  

This is not a game for sissy mary's, you are going to die, a lot. especially if you play solo where it always seems like you have to reload at the WORST possible time, where calling in a defensive turret or some other strategem is always going to be an edge of your seat skin of your teeth affair. 

This is an unapolagetically twisted and violent twin stick shooter, which works pretty darn well with mouse and keys (I like the controller, but you lose a LOT of accuracy with your weapon).  The action is frenetic and satisfying, and the carnage is everywhere.

In a very real sense, this game plays like a moving tower defense game, at least in the sense that as much as you need to move around and explore to complete objectives, a LOT of the key objectives revolve around defening an object for XYZ time while enemies flock to your location.  This is good, but predictable, and is both part of what is fun, and annoying, because if you are playing solo, or even with a team you will need to use your "strategems" to survive (at the moment the defense turret is my oh S#@t button.   Strategems are these special abilities that range from ammo drops, respawns, air support bomb runs, and defensive turrets etc. 

However, you don't simply select what you want and it drops for you... Oh no, the game uses a brilliant mechanic where you need to input an up up down down konami style code to use these special items, and in the heat of battle this can be both infuriating, and brilliantly exhilarating.  

Of course what modern game would be complete without loads of unlocks and things to improve your power... Every mission has slews of items you can collect to give you research points you can dump into weapons that you want to improve, and strategems you want to buy. 

All of your efforts go toward a global campaign that everyone who plays contributes toward.  The forces of Super earth are at war on three fronts, and as the humans win, or lose, the galactic map changes, offering new worlds to fight on, new environments, and more.  Eventually through community effort, the humans either gain victory points, or the aliens do, and if enough victory points are accumulated by the human players, the humans will advance till they reach the alien homeworld.  Take that, and that part of the war is over. 

The war ends when the humans conquer all 3 aliens, or when one of them reaches Super earth. 

So there is always incentive to keep fighting. To add just a few more points to the war effort.  

In addition the multiplayer has a report/commendation system where good players can get commendations and this ranks them as a good player worth playing with, the matchmaker does it's best to match you with suitably good players, while people who get reported at lot (usually for being a griefer etc), get limited to only being able to join people with a similar bad rep.  This bad rep takes time to go away, and good comendations can repair your standings reasonably quick.  I don't know how well this works to limit griefing, but judging by the community opinion of the game, it must work well enough!

Sadly, I haven't tried the game with a group yet, I want to play it with RL friends more than strangers, and didn't want to be an embarrassment to a team of oher players who might know what they are doing.  So for my first 2 hours I avoided it.  Now I'm about ready to try, and from all accounts, multiplayer (with friends or strangers) is where this game shines. 

I already like it a lot, and I expect when I get going with multiplayer I will be hooked.

I tried this game on the free weekend it had in October, and then bought it on sale after just a few hours of gameplay.

PROS:
-Rules are simple, and gameplay is straightforward.
-Missions are relatively quick, and other players can join mid mission.  Which can be VERY nice, because there are times you are getting wrecked and need the backup.
-Unlockable and upgradeable weapons, stratagems, and gear.  As you defeat other planets, you unlock more and more gear.  Each mission you can find these little items laying on the ground, and once you collect enough you earn an upgrade point.  Those can be spent to improve all of your equipment/weapons.  It isn't at a grueling pace to get them either, so you will usually be able to improve equipment often enough.
-Teamwork.  This game really leans heavy on playing the harder difficulties with others.  Because otherwise you would be overwhelmed and die.  Some folks may list this in the CON section, but I feel like the company did a good job at making this aspect work really well.

CONS:
-There are 3 enemy races.  You are pushing into their territory and killing them off, etc.  Once a "sector" of planets is conquered, it is locked off.  The game is "real time," meaning all players share that status of the sector locked off, so if you never played that region then you have to wait for the war to "Reset."  And that could be regions to unlock more gear you do not have yet.  Kind of a bummer.  That is pretty much the only real drawback of this game.

OTHER:
-Friendly Fire!  Oh man...this can be upsetting moments, or funny moments.  You can easily shoot a teammate.  Might do only moderate damage, so no big deal.  Or you were firing a rocket launcher and you aim was piss poor.  Results may vary.  You can also call in a piece of equipment that is a mech, and accidentally walk on teammates and crush them.  OOPS!
-The story/environment of the game is VERY entertaining!  While in the hub area of your ship, there is scrolling news stories at the bottom of the screen.  They are purely for fun/flavor, and can be quite hilarious!  It has a very...Starship Troopers type of feel to it.  You are Helldivers going out to "spread democracy" with your guns!  Your characters even say similarly motivating (brain washed) things while running around during missions.

If you have 3 friends and dont mind blowing them up then this twin stick shooter is for you!

Do you like Starship Troopers? The movie not the book. Well okay you can like the book too but really what matters here is the movie. If you like the movie then you will love this game. The game play itself is phenomenal, I thought I would hate the shared top down view that prevents you from getting to far from you team and forces you to work together. My favorite mechanic is definately that you have a radio that you can use to call down extra equipment, fire missions for artillery or aircraft, and even respawns for dead team mates. It adds an extra layer to the game without being obtrusive and is implemented in a way which is extremely well thought out.

HELLDIVERS is a great game that promotes teamwork over skill. though you might be able to clear some of the higher difficulty missions alone a team is pretty much requierd if you wish to grab those sweet rewards available at the hardest difficulties. The friendly-fire mechanic in the game requires you to focus alot on team coordination and not just shoting at the first enemy you see, aswell as causing some rather hilarious situations. 
Also no worries about running out of missions sense each mission will have a new set of randomly chosen objectives forcing you to come up with a new plan for every mission.

However the game doesen't come without it's downsides, one of them being the way the in-game campaign works. Sure it's fun working together with the community to gather enough points to conquer a piece of the enemies territory. However the problem lies in the fact that once you defeat and conquer an enemies home planet you will not be able to play against them for the rest of the galactic war (usually lasting for around 2-3 weeks). This leads to for example the "bugs" being defeated within week making it imposible to play against them for another 1-2 weeks which can be quite discouraging at times. 
Next is the reasearch point system which honestly is one of my favourite parts of the game. during your missions you have a chance of coming across samples on the ground, gather ten of those and you get a science point. These points are used to uppgrade/unlock weapons and stratagems but they are far to easy to aquire and the uppgrades are way to cheap. This causes higher level players to walk around with tremendous amounts of science points they have no use for. I dont like the fact that the hole idea of running around the map searching for samples is just rendered meaningless once you get far enough into the game.

Still though, no game comes without it's flaws and i think this is an amazing game if you want to team up with some friends and just have a good time.

This is a fun top-down shooter with a heavy emphasis on co-operative gameplay. 

You can play by yourself but the harder missions will be much easier with friends. Up to four people can play together and teamwork is encouraged. For example, one player can carry a heavy anti-tank gun while another can carry the gun's ammunition, allowing for much faster reloads. You can play with random strangers but I strongly recommend playing with friends and using voice chat to get the best experience.

Also, this game has full friendly fire so you need to be careful. At first I was annoyed by the friendly fire, but after some hilarious experiences I can safely say I've had more fun getting accidentally teamkilled in this game than any other. 

The levels are all procedurally generated so no mission map or objectives will ever be the same. There's a large variety of weapons and special abilities that you can earn, and three different alien races to fight. A weapon or tactic that's useful against one race may not be useful against another - this encourages experimentation and use of tactics. Many times I've failed a mission only to say to myself or my team, "That plan (or loadout) didn't work. Let's try this plan (or loadout) instead." Seeing your plans pay off this way is really neat.

The firefights can be incredibly intense. If you've called for evac, and there's a horde of aliens bearing down on you, and you're down to your last few bullets, it can lead to some adrenaline-pumping close calls or last stands!

The graphics are adequate. The music is suitably epic during large battles, with alien ambience for the quieter moments. I particularly liked the "Bugs Hard" soundtrack.

The story is sort of a spoof of the movie "Starship Troopers." On the surface the plot is about how the soldiers of Super Earth fight to make the galaxy safe for managed democracy. But there are subtle doses of humor that I liked a lot.

If you like cooperative top-down shooters then check out Helldivers!

All I expect from a co-op game is a bunch of reasons to say "I'm sorry" and "Thank you". And this one granted me a lot of them. Helldivers might seem like a generic run&gun type of game at first sight. A plain excuse to shoot stuff and avoid to get shot at. But you actually have to worry about so much more ! You will probably do things like :

- Shooting your teammates in the chaos and kill them
- Landing on your teammates and kill them
- Making your tank land on their mechs and kill them
- Being mad because someone took your gear and kill them
- Calling a Tesla turret in a closed space and kill everyone

But eventually you'll get better, eventually you will join a game right in the most desperate situation, right when their last teammate died. Then you get to revive the whole team half a second before a swarm of mobs guts you, come back from the dead, kill a bunch of monsters and turn things around.
There's more than one way to play and a ton of possibilities for your loadout. The game gives you a lot of opportunities to make you feel terrible or proud about your skills and the decisions you made, which in my opinion says everything about it's quality. Plus there are no filthy microtransactions.

Helldivers is what you get when you take the unyielding friendly-fire mechanics behind Magicka, put guns in your character hands and launch them down on planets inhabited by critters, cyborgs, aliens and a lack of democracy.

It's a fun, tongue-in-cheek experience where you can always return to play with friends, that is easy to learn but relatively challenging to master, that makes deaths seem like a minor inconvenience (and most of the time, thoroughly funny.

It plays well both with keyboard/mouse or controller (originally being a console game) and even after so long, it is still populated with enough players to have a good time.

It's the kind of game you can drop an hour in here and there or spend an evening on. Both sweet and spicy but always delightfully right.

Here are my pros and cons for the game
:PROS:
+Fun solo but to about 8 leveled missions, I managed to push 9.
+Insanly fun with friends always a good laugh.
+Indepth teamwork mechanic
+Heavy Friendly Fire based game (can be a con)
+Report/Commendation system (So you can get an idea of who joined you)
+Diverse tools ingame

:CONS: 
-Diverse tools ends up falling off endgame.
-Hefty on the grind side(Doesn't bother me though)
-Can get repetitive quickly
-You can't always use what you want, There has to be some compremises in your team(Doesn't Bother me)
-Most DLC isn't worth it and poor DLC practice, All Terrian boots the player HAS to buy them to do ice planets, And most of the items in the DLC packs offer very little for any real pay off, Fun here and there, But at level 11-12 end game missions, you'll barely use any of them if even a single one at all except drone boots and maybe a few others.

All in all the game is going threw time rather well, I still love the game after the several years it has been out but i hate the DLC practice in games that developers choose to take.

This game is plain dumb and fun and I love it. Game's only got 4 notable problems IMO.
It's a good game aside from the below problems. Looks like a mindless twinstick shooter, but actually has loads of coordination! Heck, you can even coordinate with other players as you construct your builds before actually starting the missions. Pretty awesome.

I'm not going to be writing this review to try to sell you the game though, I'm just writing it so you'll be aware of certain things I don't like about the game if you plan on buying it. [b]Read other reviews, watch videos of gameplay, and do further research and don't base your opinions entirely on solely my review.[/b]

[h1]The 4 aforementioned problems are:[/h1]
[u]1) Illuminates are really not fun to fight[/u]
There are 3 races in the game: Cyborgs, Bugs, and Illuminates. Throughout all the planets you fight on in this game, you will fight against one of these races at a time. The Cyborgs and Bugs are actually very fun to fight, while the Illuminates are not.

On lower difficulties, only the weakest Illuminate enemies spawn, making them the easiest to fight. On high difficulties, Illuminates spawn in large quantities, often on top of you, or if you're trying to reinforce dead teammates, ontop of their pods when they drop in. If the Illuminates enemies aren't close by, it's often because they are Obelisks or enemies with laser-sniping abilities.

Now, let's say you're playing a higher difficulty where all types of Illuminates spawn in. All of the special types that start spawning have [i][b]extremely annoying[/b][/i] attacks that feel plain unfair.

Illusionists fire projectiles that invert your controls, which are difficult to avoid because such projectiles explode (and any players caught in the explosion will be affected).

Council Members fire projectiles similar to those of Illusionists, except they [i][b]instantly kill you if they hit you[/b][/i], and they also home in. They also fire out a wave that inverts your controls if you're close enough, and it doesn't matter how big the wave seems at the time, anybody in the maximum radius of the wave is affected, instantly. The Council Members can also attack even if you stagger them. Very annoying.

The scouts sound the alarm so quickly you need a gun that one-shots them to deal with them effectively.

The laser snipers (don't know their actual name, and don't care) always are offscreen and annoyingly snipe your objectives.

The Tripods always spawn in large numbers and stay ontop of you or your pods when you try to reinforce people.

The Obelisks fire walls that instantly kill you, some utility strategems (mechs, tanks, etc.), and some objects, and make it so jetpacks are required since the walls block players.

[b]TL;DR:[/b] Illuminates are annoying and are not fun to fight.

[u]2) Content gets locked off as the community plays[/u]
I mentioned Illuminates being annoying. Now, think about how I said Cyborgs and Bugs are fun to play. Now, imagine only being able to play on Illuminate missions. This happens sometimes because people hate playing Illuminate missions and love playing Cyborg/Bug missions.

Every mission you complete in a sector of planets grants that sector influence points. When enough of these are attained, the sector is locked off and you continue to the next. When all sectors for a particular race are cleared, that race is out of the war and you need to wait for the war to end and for all sectors to reset to be able to play missions with that race again.

It wouldn't be so bad if all the races were fun to play with, and it especially wouldn't be so bad if often you weren't restricted to Homeworld Assaults (which are the last things done for each race). During Homeworld Assaults, you can't unlock items at all (unless they are level-locked items). Thankfully, only non-DLC items need to be unlocked, but this is still super annoying since you really do need many of the non-DLC items to play effectively.

[u]3) Music is super repetitive[/u]
I like the music in this game, good work to whoever made it! Only problem is, the music that plays during a mission depends solely on the race and difficulty you're playing on. If you keep doing Cyborg missions of difficulty 9 or higher, you will always hear the same theme. Minorly annoying, but hey, the music for the high difficulty Cyborg missions is awesome. I just don't like hearing it 50 billion times.

[u]4) Difficulty curve is dumb[/u]
Think of an exponential curve. It starts out super shallow, not increasing rapidly, and then over time the speed at which it increases skyrockets. That's this game's difficulty curve. Difficulties 1-8 are pretty easy once you get used to the game, and difficulty 9 is the "I need to start paying attention" difficulty. Difficulties beyond that (10-12) can actually be pretty challenging.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Most of what I have to say is negative, but that's only because I wanted to point out the flaws with this game. It's pretty good, but it's not perfect. The flaws aren't so bad that I wouldn't recommend the game. It's a solid game with fun gameplay for the most part.

TLDR: A very fun game for a short time which afterwards to boils down to a pointless grind. Some of the DLC seems like it should be a feature in-game, with some way to unlock. The playerbase is great, but small, which prevents you from trying some of the more challenging gamemodes (unless you have 3 other friends who play the game as well.) Difficulty is binary.

Majority of the things that should be features, example: All Terrain Boots aka AT Boots, are locked behind a DLC paywall. There are few much less effective alternatives to this, but unlocking any of them is a pain. AT Boots is the only true remover of the Snow planet debuff which slows your character and prevents them from sprinting (in a game thats all about moving fast and killing faster).

The playerbase, while helpful and non-toxic, just doesn't seem to be big enough, as more challenging missions require more players for pure firepower in different direction, and there is very few playing above or at the 6 - Very Challenging Difficulty (it goes up to 12). Much could be improved with matchmaking (although the problem may stem from the seemingly low playerbase.

Diffculty in this game is also binary: Either you have the firepower and equipment to take out the hordes of enemies, or you are simply numbered. If you are outnumbed, this results in an 8 minute circle of 3 out of the 4 squad members dieing, one reviving them all, and all but 1 dieing again. Otherwise, in singleplayers, it is just dying twice and failing or aborting the mission.

This game is fun for a few hours, but it loses it's appeal once you've played all the mission types.  The game universe resets every 20-30 days so that you can once again win the war for Super Earth, which is nice so that you can continue playing the game but also very annoying since you have to watch the War Victory cut scene every few weeks.

You can play missions in three sectors of the galaxy.  Each sector is controlled by a different alien race.  The races have slightly different strengths and weaknesses, but are overall pretty similar.  The planets have slightly varied environments, but you do end up seeing the same level design over and over again.  The selection of mission objectives are not very diverse and include bomb sweeping, pick up and deliver, defend a location, destroy a location, or activate some equipment.

Repeatedly playing the game will earn you experience, and each level has a number of collectibles you can pick up to unlock research points.  Experience and research points grant you new gear or upgrade existing gear.  I found that the gear unlocked by level 5 or so was pretty much the best gear to use for my play style, so all future experience and research points just went unspent.  The vast majority of weapons and special abilities are garbage, so there's simply no appeal to keep playing and try to unlock better equipment.

Missions have varying difficulty levels which are adjusted not by the objectives you have to perform but rather by the enemies you have to face.  There are more enemies, and they are more difficult enemies, in the higher difficulty levels.  Since it doesn't take special gear to defeat those enemies, a low level player can be just as successful in those harder levels as a player with hundreds of hours.  This ultimately means you'll be able to experience everything the game has to offer in only a few hours of playtime without actually having to build up to anything.

Ultimately this game is a highly repetitive grind simply for the sake of grinding.  It grows boring quickly regardless of if you play solo, with friends, or with random people online.  I found myself wishing for an end-game of some type at the 10-hour point, but Helldivers simply doesn't have one to offer.

A fun, simple, co-op twin stick shooter with a nice amount of mechanical "crunch" that doesn't require some meta-knowledge and rewards experience via faster muscle memory of strategems. The "liberate planets = get strategems/rewards" mechanic encourages play and allows you to decide what strategem to pursue next. Using them is fun, upgrading them is rewarding, and it is simple to activate. Just make sure the landing zone is clear...

As for plot, it's fairly bare-bones. You are a Helldiver, an ODST/Space Marine by another name, sent to pre-emptively liberate the galaxy from the terrorists at Cyberstan, the robots of the Illuminate, or the bugs of... the Bugs. Each enemy has their own ideosyncracies for fighting (cyberstani terrorists remind me a lot of the Orkz from 40k, the Illuminate are effectively "control" fighters who either summon big metal monsters or use forcefields to control the board, bugs are extra tough but have weaker points). Your goal is to defend Super Earth and our VERY WAY OF LIFE... before the enemies decide to one day attack Super Earth itself. By spreading managed democracy, you can ensure that Super Earth will be safe today, be safe tomorrow, and be safe forever.

The hyper-militarized fascist backdrop serves perfectly for the violent extravaganza of drop-pod deaths, friendly-fire turrets, and brutal sniping enemies. It may sound like a lot at first, but the mechanics are simple and the difficulty curve is nicely paced out from "walk in the park" to "oh God why are there so many bugs and why can't I get 10 feet without dying". It's truly optimized for a party of 4, and the drop-in system works wonderfully; I rarely have to wait long to have someone join my game, or I can hop into someone elses. The fact that it takes 2-3 missions to capture a planet goes a long way to ensure players stick together between missions, which helps keep party size up while also helping to ensure a degree of coordination and teamwork. When teamwork fails, the game lets you get back into the fight quickly provided your team mates actually call for reinforcements. I rarely wait more than 10-15 seconds to get back into the frenzy.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes cooperative shooters, "last stands" of any kind, and people who like to call in CAS every 10 seconds like an A-10 pilot owes you his daughter's life. If you want a fun "pickup and play" game for the fall season, this is a very casual game that can't really be matched for $10.

The shading and the lighting are all great and very sharp with only a few times where the shadows look like cubes on high settings. But the detail in this game is also beautiful! Depending on what kind of biome you are on you will leave footprints or if you use laserguns and overheat them small canisters eject from the gun leaving a trail of smoke. It may not sound very great but its fun to watch that happen. Even better are all the bullets that lie on the ground after a big confrontation with hostiles. Such a joy to watch what happens on the screen if something goes wrong.

The sound is great with enemies haveing unique sounds that really set them from others appart. But the soundtrack is rather boring. It follows the simple dramatic horn and violin format most of the time. The tracks sound all pretty much the same at least most of the time. Also I wish there would be some more lines for the Helldivers. At first it may be fun to hear the things characters say when they kill but at some point its quite annoying. Also having to hear a RELOAD voieline everytime you hit reload is especially annoying with shotguns or weapons that have generally small mags.

The gameplay in this game is increadibly fun and addicting! Beeing a twinstick shooter you obciously to the usual things like running arround and shooting everything but the unique thing about this game are it stratagems. They are supplies or airstrikes that can be called down to you on the surface of a planet if you enter their activation code correctly. This is done by using WASD as arrowkeys. Putting them in a specific order will give you a beacon to call down whatever you want! This is something that may be challanging at first but gets more fun to do over time and once you can enter the Reinforcement code under a second you ll feel like a pro player. What keeps me playing this game is the need to be able to play the highest difficulty mission with no problems. This game has a neat learning curve. Depending on how good you are with games you ll be able to get good at the game quickly and have a lot of fun with it.
But untill that happens you shall die from your own supplies. this game has friendly fire enabled at all times and cannot be disabled. Its a part of games which makes you have to play carefull at all time. Dont shoot your friends on ´accident´ or stand beneath the rescue shuttle when it arrives and get crushed.

The progression is something that is nice and also not nice. There are 50 levels in totall and they ll take you more time to get as you go on ... obviously. But at some point you ll be able to notice the grind in this game. Ranking up after 25 can already take quite some time especially if you are not a good player yet. Weapons and stratagems are also upgraded by so called Research Points that can be acuired by collecting a certain amount of samples or ranking up. Getting these is simple and not difficult to do but you ll notice that you will have to grind for them if you want to upgrade more and more as you go on. Both the xp rewards and the research points will make this game feel like a grind that can or cannot be enjoyable because mission always are kind of same with diffrent maps and random objectivs. The only times it get somewhat diffrent is with bossbattles and capital defence missions.

Unfortunately this game has dozens of DLC of which some are undeniably good for the game. Which is why the Digital Deluxe Edition should be bought instead of the standart version of the game.

Generally is this game worth it? Yes I would say so but beware of the grind. Its a game where you have no story whatsoever and you ll be doing things over and over again.

I also do not recommend to buy the standart edition of this game. !! Buy the Helldivers Digital Deluxe Edition!! It will give you all the DLC that have been released so far. It will give you a much larger arsenal of weapons airstrikes etc. Should the Deluxe Edition be on sale its most definately a good idea to buy that instead of the standart edition

I love top-down games... been playing them since Alien Breed on the Amiga.

After 8 hours of Helldivers, my opinion is as follows:

1) the blurred cursor in a mission is *RETARDED*. It makes the game harder for no reason - PC and console players can't play together anyway, so crippling the game for the PC gamer feels like a stab in the ribs.

2) *BUG* that prevents your game from saving! If your player name is something like "PLAYER #0" then you're not going to save progress or unlock achievements. However, Steam still manages to track for how long you've played! After 2 years of the game being in release, I don't expect a ridiculous bug like this.

3) Friendly fire... imagine this: tiny screen bounds, everyone clustered together with high-powered weapons. Friendly fire will happen - a lot !

I've seen a lot of comments about the game being repetitive and a grindfest; to be honest, if there is a grind, it's not at MMO levels.

 The game itself is fun in multiplayer, it's even exciting when you join a party (or someone else joins you) due all the chaos on the battlefield. The main problems I see, that would make it less attractive to anyone are the facts that it has friendly fire (which also applies to the enemy), and that almost anything can kill you amidst the chaos.

 Also, the game has basically 4 map types (snow, desert, volcanic and jungle), this sounds terrible in paper, but they are just a template to generate your mission. Basically, you can have a snow map where you have to rescue survivors, activate a communication tower and capture a zone or two, and after that it could be a mission about nuking  a nest or facility, retrieving a pack and disabling some mines.

 In the end, the point of the game is not to run and gun, if you stay and fight the enemies won't stop spawning until you either lose them or manage to avoid triggering any alarms while dealing with the current army. Basically, the game is more of a stealth game than a shooter, and what makes it shine is the teamplay and chaos.

[h1]My recent experience:[/h1]
Oh hey a new update is out and I get a free stuff just for starting up the game!
I download it, start it up and click play on the main menu. It shows me a map and some text about how sectors are being liberated. Skip past all of it. An unskippable cutscene shows up of me walking up to some dude giving me a medal and saying I'll be remembered as a hero and he's extracting oil from bugs or something. [b]CREDITS ROLL[/b]. Sends me back to the main menu.
I click play [b]AGAIN[/b]. Some more sectors being liberated, blah, blah blah. Finnaly lets me do stuff. I open the armory to look at the new uniform I got for the anniversary. The helmet is a reskin of the default and the armor's nothing special.
I proceed to delete the game.

[h1]Updates[/h1]
This was the 2nd anniversary update. It added a granade launcher turret, a smoke cloud and another boring airstrike.
The update before that added an m1 garand and a cape.
The update before that was the 1 year anniversary update which added a pretty cool laser shotgun and super useful armor admittedly.
So the game's [i]kinda[/i] still alive. At least as long as the servers stay up.

[h1]First time playing it[/h1]
I had a lot of fun with it when I got it. The gameplay was good and the unlocks, which I feel are the core of the game, were satisfying. Even played it with some friends. We had a tactic where one guy would get armor and a machine gun to tank bullets, one would get a rocket launcher to kill tanks and the third guy brought all the OP DLC vehicles that nobody else wanted to spend money on. When they got bored I spent some more time farming for upgrades and doing bosses, but I didn't really get too far solo.

[h1]The camera[/h1]
An important thing to mention is that in multiplayer, everyone sees the game from the same perspective. The camera focuses on the average position of all the players in the squad and you can't leave the field of view which makes running long distances while fighting off enemies a hasle.

[h1]The metagame[/h1]
The game has a server wide metagame where the missions you do contribute to the ongoing war by helping capture territory. This means that you get a new selection of random missions to do every time a territory is captured, but it also locks you out of fighting a faction if the war against them has been won. This can lead to only missions for one faction being available for as much as a couple real time days if they're the last one standing.

Although I never got to play very much, it was a great game. It felt like Magica with Guns (more guns, for those of you that played the vietnam content lol). It was action packed, full of humor, wtf moments, diverse weapons and gadgets. Its okay solo, pretty fun in matchmaking and even better with good friends. 

I genuinely hope this game gets a sequel.

Hundreds of hours on the console, nearly maximum of the prestige rank. Game is still just as fun now to play.

Essentially it does everything right. 



The controls are tight and feel very fleshed out. Accommodating for every type of action a player can perform without being complicated. The game even having a system for pressing buttons in a code entering fashion to activate objectives and call in support, which feels very nice to use yet it doesn't feel obtuse or confusing at all.

The combat is relatively simple twin stick shooting, with a variety of enemy types and enemy abilities however once again remaining basic enough that it's easy to remember what each enemy can do without them losing their individuality. There's three different enemy factions, which also helps a lot for variety.

The gameplay itself is the games strongest point. The maps are totally randomized and are composed of very nondescript geography to the point where even after hundreds of hours it is rare to actually notice two maps that have the same features. The objectives are each unique, randomly generated and placed around the map, and are very understandable to complete. It just doesn't get boring, although the escort objective is obnoxious.

There is a variety of outfits, weapons, passive perks and equipment that players can choose from and gradually unlock. Which is the low point of the game is that there are certain things that are distinctly underpowered and have never been buffed, and thus they might as well not exist which makes the customization smaller then it could be.



The game does have a lot of purchasable content, and for twenty dollars for the base game it does feel like a lot of that content should have been in the game to begin with to flesh it out more. Especially with all the underpowered things in the vanilla game that aren't ever used. It still doesn't feel however like the game has less content then it should, and the main emphasis of play is just on shooting things anyways. The game has also recieved multiple free expansions and pieces of content so it's not like the developers were ransoming content away. The purchasable content has a few powerful weapons in it, but it isn't required to have them to be able to play effectively so players aren't majorly at a disadvantage if they don't buy it.


Although the game does have a low playerbase by now, it's still no problem to find multiplayer so long as you turn off the region filter in the search filters; and there's really no problem with lag at all. The game is very social in its matchmaking system and so it really doesn't require many players to be ingame for there to be options for drop in cooperation.


Other then the imbalance of certain items, the biggest problem with the game is that the progression of the games world wide online system is very bad. Certain online events lock players out of going on any other kinds of missions for that faction of enemies, which means less diversity and no access to earning certain rewards; for the duration of that event. When an enemy faction is defeated, it can't be fought for the duration of that online cycle which means it literally isn't playable content anymore until the world wide playerbase has completed that war. Beyond that, the Retaliatory Strike and Boss mission types are ridiculously overpowered.



The game is totally worth playing even if twin stick shooters, or even shooters, aren't your main thing. It's just that well designed, fun and replayable. Helldivers combines intense action gameplay with the meta of a galactic conquest. A twinstick with plenty of flavor and content for hours on end. Seamless multiplayer makes every mission feel like a part of something bigger, and the ease of finding company is admirable.

Each mission pits the players against against one of three distinct races, each with their own ways of fighting. Selecting a mission, preparing and deploying all flow together with ease. Weapon variety is deceptive, as they all fill the same role: killing weak enemies. The actual variety of loadouts comes from a set of special abilities, or "Stratagems". They range from simple artillery strikes and special weapons to deployable cars with seats for the whole team. 

The actual gameplay consists mainly of complering a variety of objectives(enought to keep the game fresh) and defending against endless hordes of enemies. Completing missions has "rewarding" written all over it, as every mission brings the players closer to unlocking a new toy, as well as progressing the entire playerbase towards their common goal.

While not as abundant as in their previous game, Arrowhead has incorporated plenty of references that a sci-fi fan is sure to get a chuckle out of.

Be wary of the DLC, as it varies in usefullness and quality.

It was a desert planet, I think. I don’t recall being slowed down by untouched snow drifts, nor being routinely boiled alive by the gushing magma that volcano worlds like to troll you with, but the actual planet-type itself escapes me. We were there to capture it, and while we certainly weren't attempting that feat on the hardest of the twelve mission difficulty settings available, it was up there in challenge. There were three of us; I’m certain of that much. There were just the two of us at the start of the first mission, but a third jumped in mid-way through and, while we were nothing special, we were competent. We dragged each other through that first invasion with just a few hairy moments and a narrow escape when we finally completed all our objectives, suffering the most when forced to hold ground until a dropship arrived to evacuate us. But we dug in, weathered the last of the storm and then unashamedly ran like frightened girls toward the ship when it finally arrived. Two of us actually made it.

Mission one of three down, we ploughed on. Completing a full set of missions isn’t obligatory, but you soldier on for the prize at the end, be it a fancy new weapon or a fat experience boost. This time, our war was waged against the bug army. There are three distinct enemy races in HellDivers, but the bugs are by far the best. There’s nothing wrong with the robot or cyborg forces, both of which wield superior tech the giant insects don’t possess. Robots teleport in and cyborgs drop from the sky, but bugs come at you from under the ground, burrowing in from anywhere. Should one of their scouts spot you, you’re flooded with snapping claws, acid spit and near-unbreakable carapaces. One second you’re alone with nothing but the swirling sands for company. The next you’re, well... not. It doesn’t take very long at all for a screen to fill with homicidal bugs.

But we were making good pace, confident enough to leave the beaten track to try to hunt down hidden specimens that are used to slowly upgrade you Diver’s arsenal of weapons. We reactivated SAM sites and held off the herd that appeared to destroy it; we nuked insect nests and liberated strategically important sites. Our resource use was slim and slow, saving the big weapons for the eventual end when we called down that shuttle and the entire planet would turn up to try and stop us. But we were all good. Then the fourth character fell from orbit, and everything went to hell.

The new arrival was ten or so levels behind the current team’s average, but that’s usually okay; a decent team can often carry a rookie through harder planets that their default, unleveled equipment shouldn’t allow them to endure. The three of us were battle hardened; our chosen pulse beam rifles, sub machine guns and shotguns all fully researched to their most powerful apex. Even if our new member did minimal damage, it’s better than none at all, right? At worst, it would be a boon to have a new person ordering equipment from the ships in orbit above us. Even if they chipped in now and then with the odd ammo refill or a revive when one us fell, it would make for a better team. 

In theory, anyway. Dear, sweet, elusive theory...

Full Review // http://www.honestgamers.com/13523/pc/helldivers/review.html

To my delight and surprise, this is probably my favorite purchase of the summer sale thus far.  Some important highlights:

1) This is such a great spinoff on the themes of Starship Troopers I’d say it might outshine the series itself, if that wasn’t heresy. The jokes are clever, & the game nails the absurd political/military dynamics. If the gimmicky lines get old, you can simply turn down the voice volume setting.

2) At launch they took a lot of flak for being “DLC: The Game” which was completely fair. Now, however, I can buy the game, and all DLCs, for $20 – a steal, for all that it’s worth. I’m again pleasantly surprised to see the community hasn’t died even after 2+ years. Even outside peaks in the userbase (sales, etc) there are more than enough pubbies to grab a pug game with. Feel free to look up the stats.

3) The progression is rewarding enough without being intrusive. Besides the cosmetic items common to every gorram game these days, there are upgrades for your existing weapons/abilities as well as more to unlock. The DLCs make this a great deal easier – which, again, they deserved a lot of criticism for after launch. Get it on sale, however, and you won’t worry about p2w locked items.

4) The campaign map analog is, personally, highly satisfying. It boosts immersion, & gives you a sense of purpose in slogging towards one of three enemies’ planets. The progress is shared across the entire userbase, whether you’re playing solo, co-op, or matchmaking. I can see how it would feel like a grind, but to be honest, if you’re playing the game to grind/looking for a game to grind in, this probably isn’t it. Helldivers is clearly meant to be taken lightheartedly, & the progression is mostly here as a supporting feature. The DLCs go a long way to reducing your dependency on unlocks/making the game generally more enjoyable. So, again, be sure to pick this up only as a bundle on sale.

5) Servers are stable and co-op is seamlessly integrated – with pugs & among friends. No issues personally, nor have I read of much. The game itself is thoroughly stable, & the graphics are accessible even to low-end PCs.

6) While it is playable solo, most of it is a steep climb if you’re not in a group. This varies depending on mission difficulty and player skill, of course.

7) As a small, personal aside: I immensely appreciate that you’re meant to aim for center-of-mass (headshots aren’t remotely as frequent in reality), and that reloading your magazine doesn’t magically keep any unused rounds from the previous one. This is another unexpected (and at least for me, pleasant) surprise – an immersive detail I haven’t seen in most other shooters I can think of.

So who is this for? I’d say if you liked Magicka (or disliked it for certain stylistic reasons); are a fan of Starship Troopers; enjoy top-down squad-based shooters; cackle gleefully while dismembering enemies of Democracy, Liberty, and Super Earth; are looking for a casual to medium-core co-op game with friends; or some combination thereof.

Well, that’s about all I can think of for now… I hope this recommendation helps. Bottom line: when it’s on sale, I’d give this game a 9/10 must-buy if even any of the features entice you. Go kill things for Super Earth! It’s great for Liberty, Democracy, and  FREEDOM! ...probably.

 If you are looking for a great cooperative experience with tons of opportunities for you and your friends to step on eachother's toes this is it. A satisfying shooter with a massive amount of potential viable loadouts and many different kinds of weapons. Great variety of enemies and how to combat them in the three factions. The game takes place over a large meta-war where you fight a three-front war against Cyborgs, Bugs, and the Illuminates (high-tech aliens). The war is divided into three branches for each faction, and you fight within a sector in order to gain enough community points to take over the sector and advance your war. At times the aliens will fight back and may gain territory back depending on if the community fights back hard enough. A small issue appears when two factions are defeated in a meta-war causing the remaining players to be forced to fight the remaining faction without an options to fight the others for variety. Not too big an issue since I believe all three factions are uniquely fun to fight, but can get annoying when you're burnt out on a faction. 

You will enjoy firing projectile guns, explosive guns, lasers of many varieties, pilot vehicles, mechs, stationary turrets, call down artillery, bombing runs, FLAMING NAPALM WALLS, you will kill your friends by accidentally landing a drop on them, you will kill yourself by accidentally landing a drop on yourself, you will kill GIGANTIC ALIEN INSECTS BY PURPOSEFULLY LANDING A DROP ON THEM (git gud). You'll unlock pieces of equipment for purely visual customization of your male or female Helldiver (helmet, armor, and cape). Pub games are pretty fun, too! text and voice chat, and a friendly community (tends to happen with cooperatively focused games!). If you enjoy cooperative games with a hard focus on friendly fire, a jovial attitude, and some good ol' democracy, you'll love the hell out of Helldivers.

In HELLDIVERS, you are essentially the human race settling in a new home planet for what is called Super Earth. However, there are 3 factions that call for war and you are required to fight them in order to liberate their sectors to gain peace amongst human and other species. 

+ Large variety of equipment and "stratagems" (Call-ins that can provide support or bring in a piece of gear). There are a lot of weapons that you can choose for certain types of missions or if you're wanting to change your style. As for stratagems, there is also a large quantity of those that you can chose and a type for each different scenario, also has substitutes if you have yet to unlock the one you want. 

+ 3 different factions/species you can fight against. (Unless that faction has been defeated)
[list]
[*][u]Bugs:[/u] Oversized cockroaches that will tear you apart if you get swarmed. Or are willing to spit acid on you.
[*][u]Cyborgs:[/u] Some weird cult believing in mechanized humans. A combination of human flesh and metal.
[*][u]Illuminates:[/u] Aliens. Highly advanced and rather annoying with all of their gadgets.
[/list]

+ Enemy patrols can and will call for back up if you are spotted and haven't wiped out the patrol. Wiping out the patrol before they can send a signal will prevent their back up and you can continue on your merry way of completing the mission. However, allowing the patrol to signal for reinforcements will cause you pain and misery in the higher difficulties.

+ Very basic controls, stratagem call-ins require you to do some button smashing, but it's fairly simple. Until you screw up, that is.

+ A long ongoing war that will continue regardless if you lose or win. Losing requires for the WHOLE community to not play or to be so horrible that they manage to lose the entire sector, which allows the enemy faction to invade your home planet. On the other hand, winning will be a long, hard journey of triumphing multiple missions in order to claim important cities and sectors alike.

-+ Large amount of DLC. Can be see as a con as some DLC are not worth getting or if you're a not into paid DLC. However, you can get all of the DLC if you want to support the devs or get the Digital Deluxe Edition whenever it goes on sale.

-+ Small Stealth aspect, it's possible to avoid any conflict, but you better be looking on your map every 5 seconds and lie on the ground whenever you spot a patrol passing by. Be aware that suppressed weapons won't hide you. Learnt that the hard way.

-+ This can be seen as a con or a pro. The camera is based on the entirety of the squad, forcing you to stay with the team. Also causes issues when the team is horrible at placement, causing you or someone to have a VERY limited view.

This game is downright brutal when you get to the really difficult (and important) missions.

The easy missions allow you to get a feel for the game. As you move up to more difficult missions, it'll become very clear that you need your fellow Helldivers to accomplish the objectives.

FRIENDLY-FIRE is also a very important concern. Always be mindful of your aim and the whereabouts of your team.

The game is pretty simple. Drop in. Accomplish Missions. Extract. That's it. There are many weapons and stratagems (The Helldiver's bread and butter) to upgrade and learn how to use. Once you've upgraded everything, you may choose to wipe your slate clean and start over.

All in all, the game is fun and satisfying when you finish missions and see how hard you've suffered to finish it but without multiplayer, it becomes almost impossible. So going solo is not a very productive option.

HELLDIVERS is a top down shooter. It has been meant for the PS4 but then came on PC. 
Set in a future where earth is a big alliance, under control of a managed democracy, this game already promises well. So let's see the

PROS

+Great backstory. I won't spoil it to you.
+Intuitive controls, and original support call system: You can call for resupplies and fire support using a peculiar key combination system, like cheats in GTA.
+Well-made weapons: There are quite a few weapons, and they all have their pros and cons, sometimes you are forced to change weapons because your current weapon isn't suited for the mission.
+Teamwork. A lot of it. The game offers quite a few ways to put your team to good use. From choosing complementary equipment, tanks, and assist-reloading heavy weapons, teammates are invaluable. Best played with 3 friends. 
+Unforgiving friendly fire: Yep. There's friendly fire. And a lot of it. Your teammates are squishy, and so are you. See that giant heavy caliber rifle in your hands? It oneshots enemies. And so does to teammates. 
+Good unlock and progression system.
+Democracy is life

But, not everything is good in HELLDIVERS. There are a few

CONS

-Too many DLCs. I get that the devs need money, but there are way too many, and adding stuff that is REQUIRED in some cases. Plus, the DLC equipment is all available from start and is not to be unlocked.
-A few bugs. There are few of them, but this few can easily be gamebreaking. Although rare, a bug could end your mission.
-Stealth could've been better: Having a suppressed weapon won't change anything, you can't go stealth.

--Verdict--
HELLDIVERS is a nice game, and strangely doesn't suffer from the port from console to PC. It will deliver a lot of fun with friends, and it will make you swear a lot. The pricetag is quite high and difficult to justify, because of the so many DLCs and the age of the game. If you want to buy, i suggest you get the digital deluxe to fully enjoy it, and buy it from external sites at a lessened price.

Very fun multiplayer top-down shooter. This game requires you to work as a team against the aggressive enemies that are tying to prevent you from achieving your various goals, which change from mission to mission (they are varied enough to keep things interesting through many hours of gameplay). Level up to earn improved weapons and "strategems" - adiitional weapons, gear, static defense, air strikes, or vehicles - that you can call down from the skies via a varying-complexity button-press series. The tone of the game callls to mind the movie Starship Troopers, with the same satirical way of depicting a society based on waging war against other intergalactic races. Highly recommended for those who want to have fun working together to mow down enemies and keep the galaxy safe for democracy.

Progression is slow, rewards are uninteresting (although this is subjective), levels are repetitive and empty and the missions are always the same. The controls are also clunky (You can't quickly turn around, you can't shoot while prone and you can't snap aim which is often the cause of friendly fire because you'll start shooting the enemy who is attacking your friend while your helldiver is still leisurely sweeping over said friend) in addition to forcing every player to see the same screen meaning that if you go down and your teammates run away you can't see yourself. 

When asked the developers say these design choices are made to make it more difficult. If this game becomes fun and engaging at some point then I didn't make it there, but I can't sleep at night because I keep wondering how this game got such high grades.

It's not the worst game ever though. The humor is good, shooting up the enemies feels satisfying, I've had no connectivity issues at all and the airdrop system is genuinly fun.

I wouldn't recommend it but if you're going to buy it, buy it while it's on sale. Honestly though, you should play alien swarm: reactive drop instead.

This game is basically a better version of Alien Swarm, and Alien Colonial Marines we never had. You're a special operative designed to make a bright future for your Democracy Motherland, Super Earth, which is under attack by vicious Cyborgs, Zerg-like Bugs, and Protoss-like aliens.

The tips constantly claim this game is difficult when playing alone, however, I must debunk it. It's actually easier if you play everything alone. If you're spotted, just run for your life. When running, try to mow down those sentries on your way before they can sound the alarm to call in more reinforcement.

Also, playing alone is another good thing, since most of time players don't want to spend time looking for samples that can give you research points every 10 sample collected. It doesn't matter what kind of samples you collected, just pick them all up everytime you see them.

Research points is like the backbone of entire game. Don't spend it on just weapons, sometimes, it's fairly important to upgrade your strategams. From calling down ammo supply, to air strikes, they can be a game-chaging potential if you do it right. I suggest you save up all the research points, and don't spend any before lv 10. If you are in need of research points, then just go ahead and collect samples, but that'll be time-consuming and boring.

Now, if you wish to play Co-Op, be careful where you're aiming, since this game is fairly hardcore, that is, you can actually kill your allies even if you really want to help them take out the blasted aliens that are licking their faces. Don't ever do it. Keep in mind, this can happen to you as well, if aliens are very close to you? Just run and reload, so your allies can eliminate the threats.

However, I must say... this game is kind of just "That's it". Really, just that's all the game it can offer you. You're there to do the same things over and over, just RNG give you different objectives. But it's basically like this, Host looks for a proper landing zone, then finish the objectives, then survive about 1 and half minutes for extraction, then hop on aircraft to end the match. That's pretty much it all about. 

If you ever want to feel the excitement of being overrun, gun and run, then this game is for you. Double the excitement, or even triple it or maybe quadriple it, if you got friends to play with.

And yes, this games has a tons of meme of Star Troopers. Get ready to filled with puns and fight like hell.

I recall some time ago I saw this game in my queue and I took a note of it. Put it on my wish list to check later. Later ended up being nearly two years or however long it precisely was. Several large updates for the game and a whole bunch of minor DLC. Hell might be as good place as any to just hop in. This game is when you cross Magicka with Alien Swarm and douse it in Starship Tropers vibe. In short it's a gem. 

The game on surface level is extremely simple. This is a twin stick shooter you play with up to four people. On missions you have various objectives you need to do, usually hold area for a little bit, defend objective, interact with objectives and so forth. You pick your weapon, your special perk and four slots for strategems (they function similar to magicks in magicka). Off to the races right? Yes and no. This game is deceptively involved. There is quite a lot of depth, tactics and strategy to this. Different weapons will perform differently against the three enemy factions. The HUGE amount of strategems offered really gives room for some inovative and crazy gameplay. Call down air strikes (of various flavors), drop down vehicles or mechs, call down special weapons, support UAVs and whatnot. There is just so much in here to contemplate that made me really giddy with toys that blow shit up.

Then you get to the difficulty. On lower difficulties you will stomp everything, on harder difficulties you face different enemy types from the faction forcing you to have specific properties in your gear. Be it anti tank, bug spray, or whatever. Harder difficulties become both tactically challanging and they also become far more hectic...which leads to a lot more of the good ole team killing shenanigans. If you played Magicka or Alien Swarm you will know well how that goes. My first mission ever in multiplayer here I ended up dying in the first 10s by a person joining my game and dropping down on my face. Thankfully just like magicka, reviving a teammate is simple and easy.

The game has a different design than what you expect. At all times there is a galactic campaign ongoing. This means you can end up joining at the end of one where there isn't much to do (or unlock). Still the cycle is pretty quick (few weeks) so you get your chance eventually. Completing any mission earns standing, and standing is used to progress the ongoing campaign.  

Unlocking stuff is done two ways (besides the DLC items).Leveling your character and completing planet's set of missions. Completing planets gives you new rewards (usually extra xp, strategems, cosmetics and so forth). If you complete one mission and you still have more to do and you leave, when you come back the sector might be completed from the campaign, however your game will allow you to complete the planet, which is really nice.

The game overall forces you to play in multiplayer if you want to finish all the content . You CAN solo it, but looking stuff up like that ends up pretty crazy. It takes specific gear and really knowing the game inside out. So you are more than encouraged to play with others. If you are looking for a singleplayer game, this isn't really it. You can do it, but game design isn't primarily intended for such. Anyway the reason to complete content originally is to progress your character, get better gear, get research points and upgrade said gear. There is a TON of it and it will take a long ass time to max it all out. However don't look at the game that it is the main goal. Main thing here is to play the game, first and foremost. Just doing missions is what this game is about. I find it easy to pick up and put down. I can probably leave this game for however long and just hop back in and have a blast (just like magicka).

This game is worth the price tag, especially on sale. It is far more than a simple twin stick shooter, and there is many of those out there. This game offers a challenge, incentive to get better and satisfaction in doing so. It is tactical, humorous and hectic. Easy to pick up and put down. It's a simple blast with little downsides to what it does. As long as you don't expect it to deliver something outside of its scope this game should give you a laugh, liberty and plenty of freedom.
